Review:
I will continue to buy this series because overall it holds my attention and I, for the most part,  like the hero and heroine. However, in this installment the heroine really tried my patience.  I kept thinking "grow up' as Serenity "hid" a secret that any normal grown woman would have taken care of in routine fashion. Instead, she acts like a thirteen year old with no life experience.  What makes it worse is the heroine is supposed to be a level headed, quick thinking woman, so what happens when she has a personal issue?  We are expected to believe she becomes a wimpy juvenile.  I found my self skipping the pages where she had her "inner turmoil", but the rest of the book was very good.  As for those who think the series is overly explicit, I disagree, romantic scenes are well and tastefully written.  My property is surrounded by Amish farms and I did find what I thought were errors in some descriptions of customs but it is entirely possible the author is familiar with a very different sect of Amish, so I may be wrong.  Though I cannot imagine any group of Amish planning for a wedding in June at the height of farming season, in my area weddings are on Thursday in October, well after planting and harvesting season.  I do recommend this series.  It is well paced and the author is good at invoking the feel and impressions of the surroundings in each scene.
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>
With the given examples, give a score between [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] to the following review by the same user. Only output the score and nothing else.

Review:
As a resident of Amish country, I enjoy this series, it is relaxing like a good cup of tea.  The characters ring true and are likable.  However, even though I can understand the author's reasoning, I wish the main character would actually take a chance and choose Amish farmer (Benjamin) over the safe and predictable choice (local sheriff) - it just would make things more exciting and certainly result in fuel for future stories.  I can imagine the colorful conflicts and mysteries that would result from such a marriage!

Review:
Selena does it again with another visit to the Baumgartners. It's hard to say with all they have done, but I was a little shocked. The kids are grown and have moved out. Carrie has hooked up with an old friend online, but is keeping part of the affair secret from Doc. What would possibly make Carrie lie to Doc, even if it's only by omission? Doc isn't so innocent when it comes to hiding things either. What is he not telling Carrie? Jodie is amazing, but she has a history and past as well. Will it all work out? Well, it is the Baumgatner's, so you know the adventure will be full of some amazingingly hot scenes. A must read if you've read any of the previous books.

Review:
What an excellent read.  The story Gone continues in this 2nd book.  We are again taken into Macy's (Heather) world.  The 15 year old is still dreaming of the day she will get away from her capter (Chester) and get back to her family.  We are given the opportunity to read Macy's thoughts of what ifs and how she would be a better person if only she could get back home.  The author also takes us through the emotion's of Macy's parents, her brother and her best friend.  The book speaks volumes about the terrible loss of a loved one and how it can tear apart and also bring family and friends closer.  We are left wondering if Macy will succeed in gaining her freedom from the evil Chester or be forever his prisoner.  I was given a free ebook copy for an honest review.

Review:
I thought it was a good book. I liked Damien. He was once a rich noble whose father dies with excessive debts. He did everything he had to do to pay off his fathers debts. That includes working the land and doing jobs hired help and servants do. He also doesnt have very many servants. He had one servant who was his mothers maid when she was alive. She became his wife's maid and also his kids governess. Then when his wife died she also took up being housekeeper and cook, when he lost servants because his brother-in-law (Lord Poole) spread bad rumors about him. The lady couldn't cook and didn't do a lot of house work, but he kept her because she was loyal and took care of the kids. Isabella was also a great character. She put up with an abusive step father, then an abusive grandfather and Great Aunt, then decided she was better off on her own so found a job, and became a working woman. She made her own way and did not complaint about things. She was level headed and nice.

It was easy enough to figure out who Isabella's father was or at least what family he came from. There are also a couple of things that do not make sense or aren't explained. They did not bother me, but if you are one of these people that have to have everything perfect, it is not for you. The main one for me is Damien's first wife's death. Why did her horse come back without her, and her glove, hat and handkerchief found in the lake, so they assumed she drown, when her body was found somewhere else she couldn't have ridden to. You have to assume she staged her death, but why would she have staged her death when she had not found the thing she needed to be able to survive. Her death was obviously an accident, but even if she had narrowed it down to a place where she though it was, how did she know someone did not find it before and took off with it. I would think she would find it first, if she was that close, and then staged her death. She could have avoided the person she wanted to get away from a little longer until she was sure.

I like her writing. This is my third book of hers that I have read. So far I like 'How to Be a Scottish Mistress' best. Waiting for the next book related to that which comes out in 4 days called 'Bride of a Scottish Warrior'. Even though sometimes I enjoy the conflict when couples fight, the 3 books I have read of hers, the couples do not really fight, and they know they fell strongly for the other person, even if they don't think they are in love.  It is usually more of a sweet love.

Sex content medium. A couple of scenes. They are descriptive but not too descriptive.
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Pavarotti is wonderful as Radames. Toczyska is brilliant as Amneris. Simon Estes is very good as Amonasro. Margaret Price sings the role of Aida very well. The chorus is very good, the ballet scenes are good, and the orchestra plays very well. The costumes are ok, and the sets are glitzy but fun. They look like Hollywood epic film sets left over from the 1950's. This is a very good production, but not a great one. However, it is better than the dreadful La Scala dvd, also starring Pavarotti. The best all around version on dvd is the Metropolitan Opera production starring Domingo, Millo, and Zajick. It is brilliantly sung and staged. The production, the costumes and the sets are spectacular. As far as this dvd of the San Francisco Opera production is concerned, the main reason that I like it is because of Pavarotti. His performance here is superb.

Review:
My daughter wanted a Princess Peach plush doll to go with her Mario and Luigi and Bowzer which she purchased in local retail chain stores. Peach could only be found online in our area, so we looked at all the options and decided to go with this one. The picture looked like the dress was free and loose, and made with decent quality, but when it arrived, the dress and hair was stuffed and solid.

My daughter was very disappointed. The features were slightly irregular and misshapen. It wasn't cute, pretty, or at all the quality of the other dolls she bought from local retail. It is not soft, but the material is scratchy and rough. The picture shows a red tag. What arrived was a blue tag with Japanese writing.

Beware online shopper. You really don't know what you're buying until it arrives.

Review:
I have several sets of Bodum glasses, and was glad to see this package available. Here's the particulars:

Yes, these work as advertised. The double-wall system keeps warm drinks warm longer and cold drinks cold longer. It also keeps the sweat drops that plague cups in the humidity of the South at bay. That much is true.

I have not seen difficulty with being too fragile. While I still avoid bashing them against hard objects, they do hold well against normal usage. That includes having the 10-year-old hand-wash them amidst other dishes.

The hand-washing is the only drawback I would highlight. This could be our water quality, but running these nice, clear dishwaher-safe glasses through the dishwasher results in cloudy glass. So, ours get hand-washed.

Great, pretty glasses and a good value.

Review:
'Compulsion' is the brilliantly-performed film of a shocking event.  Two young men, after reading Nietsche and speculating on their own world-shaking intellects, decide to commit the perfect murder--a thrill kill.  They kidnap a young boy, murder him, dispose of the corpse, then toy with the police to lead them in the wrong direction and indulge their egos.

Of course, it all goes wrong...otherwise there would have never been a trial, books and movies.  The killers are tied in the cord of their own 'brilliance.'

This film, in fact, is two films rolled into one.  The first, and to my way of thinking the most interesting, film is the first...the story of the crime and the two murderers.  The second film starts abruptly on the arrest of the killers.  Orson Wells enters the movie as the ponderous, anti-capital punishment, defense attorney [Clarence Darrow in real life].  After first pleading 'Not Guilty', then observing the faces of the jurers, he abruptly changes the verdict to 'Guilty, with Mitigating Circumstances.'  This means that the jury must be removed and the case tried by only the judge.

On the other hand, should Darrow aruge an 'Insanity' Defense, a jury must again be empanelled.  Nevertheless, Darrow brings 'experts' to the stand who testify that the killers are mentally deranged and one killer is diagnosed as 'schizophrenic'.  Somehow the judge lets all these shenanigans stand [remember Judge Ito?] so, despite the bias of the movie/directors/producers/writers, we know the bias of the judge.  He WILL return life imprisonment verdicts i.e. no capital punishment.  Nevertheless, Darrow goes on to passionately argue the immorality of capital punishment...and...might I say, his speeches are impressive.

Still I downgraded this otherwise excellent movie from 5 to 4 stars because this is a film with a heavy-handed message, which is just another word for bias, prejudice and propaganda.  In that I am thoroughly sick of high school-dropout film makers preaching to the rest of the rest of us, I downgraded this one star and maybe should have downgraded it more.

So what is the 'message' and propaganda?  It's the same as Capote's 'In Cold Blood'.  No matter how heinous a crime, the death verdict is NEVER justified.  Why?  Because, ultimately, no one is really, REALLY, responsible for his/her actions.  The fault is that of mothers, fathers, society and/or environment.  Afterall, anyone who does anything awful can't be sane....can he?  If he's not sane, how can we execute him?

But I would turn this argument inside out.  If we...in an ultimate sense...are not responsible, how can we put ANYONE in prison?  Truly, it's not really a question of the death penalty, it's a matter of punishment.  If we aren't responsible, how is it possible that we can be punished?  Isn't it immoral?  Personally, I don't know, but do know this:  A society...any society...that acts as if the individual bears no responsibility, is finished.

Ron Braithwaite, author of novels...'Skull Rack' and 'Hummingbird God'...on the Spanish Conquest of Mexico.

Review:
Terrific acting but the direction leaves something to be desired.  Most memorable are the Peter Lorre character, the police commissioner and the miserable old pawn broker.  Lorre's complex character deserves careful dissection.  He lives in abject poverty but, with the help of his poor mother, manages to graduate with high honors with a degree in criminology.  His future--and the future of his family--should be guaranteed except for the fact that our 'hero' is idiosyncratic to the point of deep pathology.  He has a schizoid personality disorder characterized, in part, by truly incredible arrogance and delusions of grandeur.  He commits a murder which is almost a 'thrill kill.'  He thinks he can commit the perfect crime because he is far more intelligent than the police.

Here is where I think the film is misdirected.  It should have, in my opinion, been a study of the unrelenting power of a guilty conscience.  The character should have behaved rather intelligently and coolly until 'done in' by his own guilty soul.  Instead the director produces a character who is so peculiar, weird and unlikeable that he draws attention to himself.  His guilt is a neon sign.  Not just once but over and over.  Ultimately he leaves no room for himself.  Everybody knows he is guilty.

Review:
This is what happens when authors create fiction from historical fact without awareness of those earlier times. For instance, we read about the Germans clearing the snow from Brenner Pass with a backhoe, a machine not manufactured, even in America, until a few years later. The expression "...until the fat lady sings" was unlikely to have been used in 1940's Italy, as it only became popular in the USA in the 1970's. Factual nitpicking aside (always good for laughs), whether intended or not, the message of this novel is the innate evil of mankind,even when ostensibly well-meaning. I can't help believing this book would have better if it had just stuck to the facts, no embroidery necessary.

Review:
For those who enjoyed Langan's first novel, THE KEEPER, this book is a welcome follow-up.  Where the first book was a tragic story with a tight focus on one community, this book is about terror on a larger scale.  Like a lot of good plague/infection tales, it features the accelerating decline of a community through the lens of several families; after all, it is the individualized family unit that denotes civilization and separates humans from the herd/pack mentality of animals.  What makes this book different is that the source of the infection isn't a biological weapon or a zombie plague or anything cooked up in a laboratory, but rather an ancient (and somewhat ambiguous) evil unearthed in the nearby forest.

As the evil spreads, turning ordinary citizens into ruthless killers, we see the rest of the townsfolk band together or pull apart as all of their seething resentments and unspoken emotions are forced to the surface because of the mounting crisis.  By the time the book reaches its final conclusion with suggestions that the plague has begun to spread much father than this small community, no one in town is untouched by the carnage and rampant conflict around them.

This book is a fun read and has enough suspense to keep the reader interested; however, I don't think this book is as successful as THE KEEPER.  The evil in the woods that is the source of the novel's conflict is never fully explored or explained enough to really have a sense of its origin or purpose.  Also, the ease with which it is released and the speed with which it engulfs not only this town but also, presumably, the world is a bit unbelievable - what has kept it in containment so long if it is so easily released?  Still, fans of Langan or of any good novel about the deterioration of "civilized" society will not go away disappointed.

4

Review:
I should start by saying that I have never been much of a vampire fan.  I've read a couple of Anne Rice books (though the first book of her Mayfair Witches series captured me more than Lestat ever did) and seen a few fang movies; the onslaught of vampire drivel that's out there now (especially that overhyped and underwritten Mormon abstinence parable masquerading as teen romance) has done very little to sway my opinion.  Therefore, I approached Cronin's The Passage with understandable trepidation.  Could this new vampire menace really be that much different than all the others?  Well, as long as they didn't sparkle in the sun like diamonds I figured I could at least give it a try...

It only took me a few pages to get hooked on this almost unclassifiable story.  Yes, it's a horror novel, and the horror is there by the bucketful, but the horror dished out by Cronin's nouveau vampires is no worse than the horror humans do to one another (this is nothing new for readers of dystopian literature, but it bears repeating).  What surprised me the most was that between moments of bloodshed, this book read like a literary novel...and a good one at that.  Perhaps I'm jaded, but with a few rare exceptions I have to get my fixes for horror/suspence and finely-crafted storytelling in very different places.  This book, I am happy to say, is one of those rare exceptions.

[SMALL SPOILER AHEAD!]

What I was most compelled by was the way that the story transformed.  After spending a good portion of the story with Amy and her kidnapper/protector/father figure and other characters related to that time period, the book swiftly and effortlessly shifts forward almost a century into the future (with divider notes that suggest a future even further beyond that) where civilization has broken down after the viral plague.  Here we meet new characters who must contend with these manmade monsters and create lives for themselves within heavily fortified walls.  When this new story finally comes back into contact with the former story through the arrival of Amy (not like the other virals but no longer entirely human), the novel takes a dramatic turn that once again upsets the "natural order" of the world and catapaults the characters toward their destinies.

My one complaint with the book is that the author is far too fond of ending chapters with "cliffhangers" that seem to indicate certain doom for one or more of the beloved characters, and then returning to the situation with an almost unbelievable conclusion that puts everything back to rights.  After a while, this overused device takes a little of the suspenseful sting out of these events...why worry if you can be fairly certain that all will be right with the world?  Luckily the author delivers enough surprises (and carnage) to keep readers from fully growing complacent, and the cliffhangers at the end of the novel will have readers impatiently awaiting the next installment.  Let's just hope that Cronin can deliver his sequels on a schedule more in line with the horror writer inside of him rather than the literary author.  Those literary folks love to take their time...

Review:
I trust the Amazon settings way too much sometimes.  I had been shopping for a touchscreen unit for my car for well over 2 years.  Most products, when I would navigate to their page would say, "This product does not fit your car".  This was one of the few products that actually did.  After weighing the options of this with the 2 or 3 others, I chose this, as it had most of the options I desired, and had a reasonable price.

This works very well for phone calls and for blue tooth hand off of your ipod/phone.  When I get into my car while listening to a podcast on my phone, this recognizes and connects almost immediately.  This is very stylish looking and makes my car (a 2006 Pontiac G6) look more modern and new.

I knocked off a few stars because I bought this for the dual functionality of the bluetooth and GPS, and the GPS is just awful.  The voices are awful, and it doesn't seem to navigate correctly all the time.  I have to pull my Iphone out and use Maps a lot of the time, because the GPS cannot be trusted.  I still attempt to use the GPS in hopes that I can figure out its logic.

The options and menus are very lmited - I wish there were a few more options on this - like the ability for music that is streamed via bluetooth to pause during the GPS directions.  Too often I have been listening to an audiobook, and the GPS chimes in rapid fire to tell me to stay left for 500 feet, then stay right for 1000 feet, then merge left - by this point, I've missed almost a whole paragraph.

This also did not come with an adapter/plug that was needed to produce the chimes for door ajar, trunk ajar, etc.  I had to go and buy this additional part for $80, which totally eradicated the point of my buying this product, as it seemed to be the most reasonably priced unit that would fit my car.

All in all, I would say I am mildly disappointed in this unit.  While it does serve its purpose of playing my phone's music/podcast/etc well, I could have just as easily accomplished that with a $20 Bluetooth tuner that plugs into a cigarette lighter.

Here are a couple of review-rating pairs of a user. Review: This review originally published in [...]. Rated 4.5 of 5 Unsold Television Pilots 1955-1989 is an expanded version of author Lee Goldberg's book The Best TV Shows That Never Were (reviewed yesterday). Yesterday's book focused on, as the title suggests, the best shows that were never made. This book is ALL the shows not made between 1955-1989. It is not a simple read. But it is fascinating! This is a great peek at how Hollywood thinks. Compare the shows that made it to these shows that didn't even get past the pilot stage, and you can start to see what the Hollywood TV makers think of the television consumer. But you can also look at some of these pilots and wonder what the heck ever made anyone think it might be a good idea. The book is broken down into chronological order by year and within each year it is broken down by studio and type (comedy or drama). There is a comprehensive list of producers, writers, and actors along with the general story plot for the pilot. In some cases the intended story arc for the potential series is also presented. For those of us with a fascination with television history, this is a gold mine. Whether it's seeing actor names like Harrison Ford in a pilot where James Farentino plays a defrocked priest (The Possessed, 1977) or Dwayne Hickman is the only male teacher in an elementary school (Hey Teacher, 1964); or writers like Earl Hamner (The Waltons) come up with ideas like that in which young veterinarians live in the mountains with a huge tiger and a pair of orangutans (Tiger, Tiger, 1969), this book is filled with little gems. Although I read this chronologically, cover to cover, this is easily the sort of book that one could pick up and thumb through and look at any year. Any producer. Though it has little useful information for daily use, for those of us who love trivia and pop culture and television, this book has so much to offer. The down side is that it only goes up to 1989. An entire generation (or even two) of television watchers won't see the failed pilots from their viewing years. But I can understand how much more difficult it gets as more and more networks begin producing their own shows. And with companies such as Amazon and Netflix also making original programming, just keeping track of these things becomes more and more complicated. This book is clearly a labor of love by author Lee Goldberg. That he is a fan of the business, as well as an insider, is obvious. I would like to have seen a little stronger hand in the proof-reading. I recognize that there are a LOT of names in this 800+ page book, but there were times when the errors (not all of them typos) seemed a little too much. Stor Trek instead of Star Trek is an example, and in a 1979 inclusion of The Return of the Mod Squad, character of Lincoln ('Linc") Hayes is twice referred to as "Line" Hayes. Note that my copy of the book was an advance reading copy and that perhaps some corrections were made before publishing. All in all, I really like this book and will most certainly reference it in the future. Looking for a good book? Unsold Television Pilots: 1955-1989 by Lee Goldberg is a great look at pop history from a point of view that we don't often see ... the things that don't make it to the public eye. I received a digital copy of this book from the publisher, through Netgalley, in exchange for an honest review. Review: This review originally published in [...]. Rated 3.75 of 5 Although I love to read, and I read a lot, I grew up a child of the television age. As one of those first generation 'latch-key' kid, the television was my nanny. And when I moved to Hollywood, it was television that I had hoped to break in to. I am also one of those individuals who has a number of somewhat obscure television references books (and have had for probably thirty years now). And so, this is precisely the sort of book that I really, really like. Television Fast Forward is a reference book about the "Sequels and Remakes of Cancelled Series" from 1955 to 1992. We all know, and probably comment on the fact that Hollywood doesn't ever come up with anything new, but instead just resurrects old shows.. But do you have any idea just how many old series' really are brought back to life on the screen? This is the book to fill you in. I'm fairly savvy about television, even if it's a show I've never watched myself, I often know about it and all its incarnations (thank you obscure reference books!). But even so, I picked up on a few things that were new to me here. (For instance [just one of many], I never knew that there was an un-aired pilot made from The Greatest American Hero, called The Greatest American Heroine.) Because I am a little strange and will even read a reference book cover to cover, I also picked up on some small tidbits. For instance...I never knew that Warren Zevon did music for a television show (a 1993 remake of Route 66) or that Sandra Bullock appeared in a 1989 movie called The Bionic Showdown - a sequel to The Six Million Dollar Man and The Bionic Woman (one of four sequels). There are a couple of things that I didn't like about this book. 1) This book was originally released in 1992 and all the sequel/remake information only is complete to that point. At the end of the book there is an appendix of "Television Series Revivals 1992-2015" which lists the television shows, but doesn't give any of the fantastic background information that Goldberg provides for the older shows. There is also an appendix "Television Series Remakes 1992-2015" which is the same - just a list with no background. Although the Star Trek section does include the J.J. Abrams first 'reboot' movie 2) I recognize that what I have is an Advanced Reader Copy, but the number of spelling, typography, and simple proof-reading errors was disappointing. One would hope that if this was published in 1992, any errors from that publication would have been corrected and that there should not be new errors in the old copy. But we have, about Star Trek, the sentence that it was "just about arty story could be told" (sic) and its creator was Gene Rodden berry (sic). But still, this is precisely the sort of book that I want on my bookshelf (not on my kindle) so that I can refer to it periodically. If you are a fan of television, you'll want this, too! Looking for a good book? Television Fast Forward is a fantastic reference book on the subject of sequels and remakes of television shows. Review:
Ms Hoag has demonstrated that she can write a compelling story.  With this book, she has failed miserably.  Stereotypes abound, with virtually no characters to truly care about.  And the use of voilence against women is exploitative to an almost pornographic degree.

How did I find this book revolting?  Let me count the ways:

1.  There's likely to be some blood and gore in a good murder mystery.  As an avid fan of the genre, I expect it.  But Hoag is so gleeful at taking it to extremes in this story, it actually becomes monotonous after awhile.

2.  Every notable, adult female character in this story is either a pathetic victim, or a monster.  The only female worth rooting for is an 11-year-old girl, who... (Spoiler Alert!)... inexplicably becomes some kind of ninja warrior, apparently.

3.  Our "heroine" is either simpering over a child, or being attacked in a bloody fashion (repeatedly).  Otherwise, she adds absolutely nothing to the story.

4.  The gratuitous use of yet another child, as nothing more than a vehicle for the further victimization of our "heroine," is very simply unforgivable.

5.  The gratuitous use of a mentally ill character as... I give up!  What WAS the point of that one?  This runs a close second in the race to the bottom (see #4).

Ineffectual cops with patronizing attitudes towards every one of the women; endless red herrings that defy logic, even within the context of the story; a secondary villain who comes so far out of left field, it goes beyond a "twist" into the territory of just plain silliness... by the time I gave up and started skipping through random pages of the last fourth of the book (hoping there would be some redeeming value in the end), I can't remember the last time I cared LESS about "Who Done It."  I just wish they had done it faster.

1

Review:
Fans of Nora Roberts will recognize these characters, because they're spot-on true to her boilerplate by now.  Granted, she usually saves that formula for her three-book trilogies.  But for this one, we get a "bonus" of all three of their stories shoved into one book!  The best example:  Right down the line, we get the Gallagher siblings from the Ardmore trilogy, and their love interests.  Even the pairings were the same:  Mal/Aiden with Tia/Jude; Gideon/Shawn with Cleo/Brenna; and Rebecca/Darcy with Jack/Trevor.

If you can forgive that predictability with the characters, the yarn itself isn't half bad.  But... well, that' the highest praise I can think of. I didn't hate it.  And since NR picks out a specific subject for most of her books, to hammer her readers over the head with "knowledge", you'll learn a little something about mythology in this one.

Review:
In the mid-1990's, through a series of questionable storylines (i.e. "Emerald Twlight," and "Zero Hour - Crisis in Time"), DC Comics had disgraced its iconic Silver Age Green Lantern, Hal Jordan, by transforming him into its Darth Vader-like villain known as Parallax.  When last seen, Hal had heroically sacrificed himself re-igniting the sun to save the DC Universe in "The Final Night."  In 1999, DC Comics had writer Geoff Johns bring Hal back from purgatory for more in "Day of Judgment," as the Justice League teams with the Sentinels of Magic (Zatanna, Dr. Fate, the Phantom Stranger, the Golden Age Green Lantern, etc.) to thwart mystical underworld villain Nekron.

Disposing of the Spectre's previous host, Jim Corrigan, "Day of Judgment" sets up Hal's slow road to redemption, as he becomes the new Spectre (with a Green Lantern-like appearance).  DC wisely recognized turning Hal back into Green Lantern full-time (after his numerous misdeeds) shouldn't happen too quickly, so that is how/why "Day of Judgment" is set up.  At best, it is a nice yet otherwise forgettable bridge towards Johns' far superior "Green Lantern - Rebirth" in 2005.  With an included back-up feature, this trade paperback is also a solid piece showcasing Zatanna, Alan Scott (the Golden Age Green Lantern), and the other Sentinels of Magic (a far-less-grim forerunner to today's Justice League Dark).

The major detriment really is the amateurish artwork, ranging from okay to mediocre to atrocious - in other words, it is consistent with DC Comics' declining efforts during the late `90's.  The sole terrific image is of a cover close-up of a ghostly pale Hal.

Ultimately, if you like Hal Jordan as much as Geoff Johns obviously does, this is a decent adult read.  Far better, adult-appropriate Geoff Johns storylines starring Hal Jordan (as Green Lantern) would be the superb "Green Lantern - Rebirth" and even the shockingly gory "Blackest Night."

Rating: a weak 3/5 stars.  At least, it's kid-friendly, best for ages 10 and up.

3

Review:
I discovered Hal Jordan/Green Lantern on the animated "Challenge of the Super Friends" in the late 1970's.  At the time, Harrison Ford (circa 1980's "The Empire Strikes Back") was my perfect choice for Green Lantern's live-action movie adaptation.  In June 2011, Warner Bros. & DC Comics finally release a Green Lantern film, leaving audiences to settle for Ryan Reynolds as the title character.  Of available actors, either he or, better yet, Chris Pine were arguably the best known options.  Reynolds subsequently fails to impress in an estimated $300 million production (upon factoring in all the promotional costs).  His shallow efforts are further deep-sixed by an awful script and gaudy CGI special effects imbuing this vastly disappointing film with all the aura of an overblown video game.

Director Martin Campbell seemed a logical, slam-bang choice to initiate "Green Lantern" into a super-hero film franchise.  Having seen his high octane efforts reviving Zorro (with Antonio Banderas & Catherine Zeta-Jones) and James Bond twice (with Pierce Brosnan and later Daniel Craig), Campbell normally has a knack of capturing sleek, inspired performances from his actors.  This time, though, Campbell's cast  offers a collective sleepwalking job, as I've seen Green Lantern cartoons with better acting.  Additional sabotage comes from this movie's lackluster script incoherently blending elements from various Green Lantern storylines, which leaves its target PG-13 audience to only undemanding viewers in the 12-25 crowd.

The film immediately stumbles into a "Battlestar Galactica"-like voice-over prologue by explaining far too much too soon.  Eerily enough, actor Geoffrey Rush's voice-over even mimics Patrick Macnee's voice from "Galactica."  Without revealing crucial spoilers, the filmmakers should have saved vital revelations about planet Oa's existence and the Green Lantern Corps for a proposed sequel.  There wasn't enough screen time to sufficiently develop Parallax, Hector Hammond, and even Sinestro into villains all in one film.  Although the game plan was to set up the franchise with an awesome Green Lantern vs. Sinestro sequel, the combination of such a crummy script with an over-abundance of obviously fake CGI makes for a dreadful viewing experience.  If the film had plausibly focused on a raw, mysterious origin (where rookie Hal desperately believes he is the only Green Lantern vs. imminent cosmic destruction), the end result could have been immensely better.  In fairness, the movie's best asset is the inclusion of reliable actors in various supporting roles: i.e. the late Michael Clarke Duncan, Geoffrey Rush, Clancy Brown, Angela Bassett, Jay O. Sanders, Jon Tenney, and Tim Robbins.  Unfortunately, the mind-numbing plot gives them familiar characters (i.e. Kilowog, Tomar-Re, Amanda Waller, Abin Sur, and the Jordan family) with so little to do.

This film's worst offense, ultimately, is its flagrant pushing of CGI to hide how crummy the movie really is.  Case in point: the ultra-fake opening sequence depicting outer space is flat-out laughable.  An immediate sense that this movie is in deep trouble continues as even Hal & Carol's jets flying over the California desert is just another helping of CGI.  Utilizing some models (or even recycling stock footage of real "Top Gun" jets) would have been far more credible.  It doesn't take long before viewers will realize they are watching actors lazily going through the green-screen motions, treating "Green Lantern" merely as a paycheck movie.  As this cast carelessly fails to sell viewers on suspending total disbelief, the film's over-reliance on CGI becomes sadly apparent.  Hence, the film squanders an enormous optical effects budget resulting in nothing more real than an emerald fireworks show.

Considering the insane amount of money Warner Bros already lost on this movie, the planned 2020 reboot makes sense, provided there are four HUGE conditions:  1. Hire a compatible director (someone who actually grasps why a fearless Hal Jordan (or John Stewart) is Green Lantern; 2. Get the right Hal (perhaps Garrett Hedlund) or John (maybe Michael Jai White); 3.  The cast must provide inspired, high-caliber efforts; and 4. Far more attention is focused on an intelligent script first rather than simply gambling it all on CGI.

I lucked out skipping the theater experience by later finding the blu-ray at a cheap price.  If only once, my young son and I could be kids together gleefully seeing my favorite childhood super-hero come to life.  I just wish this "Green Lantern" film had met more than just a fraction of its vast potential.  Instead, "Green Lantern" is really a second coming of Ben Affleck's dreadful 2003 Daredevil movie (including Reynolds' smug, Affleck-like performance).

Rating: 4/10 (Updated in August 2015).

Note: There are two gruesome scenes inside a secret laboratory in the film's second half that I would advise not letting children see -- parents will know when they watch the film.

Review:
A most appealing mix of police procedural and amateur detective. The heroine is an astonishing but credible woman, self-made in her career, strong willed almost to the point of obstinacy. Cramer is admirably persistent and quick witted, and delightfully candid and clear-spoken. I don't approve of all the police tactics, which haven't changed as much as most people seem to believe, but Cramer uses them with honest conviction.

The attitude toward Native Americans teeters between annoyingly patronizing and actually respectful, but on balance it shows how difficult it is for two cultures to fully understand each other, but how worthwhile it is to make the effort.

Finally, the mature romance is lovely.

Review:
I bought this unit some months back and used it extensively.
It's light and easy to use.  It served me well.  One day I found the screw just disappeared and it could no longer hold up the camera, rendering the tripod unusable.  I mentioned that in my previous review.  I like it so much I just bought another one  thinking that it's not worth the hassle to try to get the screw. (Different model, though because this model is temporarily out of stock.)

Months later the manufacturer called me trying to ascertain what was wrong.  "Ok, I get it.  I know what you are referring to," she said after listening to my characterization.  "We're going to send you the parts to get that fix.  Even though the product is fulfilled by Amazon, we're the manufacturer and we stand behind it.  If we don't have the part, we'll send you another whole tripod, free."  I was in shock. Yes, it came via UPS!!  Now, that's customer service.

Then I got a follow-up phone call to find out if I got the replacement unit.  Wow!!
I used to get my computer and camera parts from a well-known computer parts company which was very good until about four years ago, The customer service went down hill.  Others on computer forum noticed that too.  It cost me 50% of the value of the product that I returned the same day.  It was defective.  I switched to Amazon thereafter. If Amazon has it and the price is comparable, Amazon gets my order.  It's amazing the bigger Amazon gets, the better its customer is!!

In short, this product is good; the customer service is unsurpassed.  Buy.

Review:
Unlike your earlier screwball comedy movies, this one has a little dark edge to it as it covers issues such as the death penalty for innocent people and police and government corruption.  For its time, it was also unique in that the female lead was treated somewhat as an equal with her other male colleagues which we take for granted today but was unheard of in 1940.  As far as screwball comedies go, I wouldn't call this the best one I've seen as that accolade would have to go to "My Man Godfrey" or perhaps "The Thin Man" but this movie while not coming close to the standard of these two is still entertaining.

The problem with this DVD though is the poor video quality although the sound quality isn't that bad if you have a system with Dolby Pro Logic which simulates surround sound and yet the hissing is still noticeable.  The picture quality is riddled with imperfections and it may be a good idea to wait for a properly restored version to come out or maybe Blu-Ray?  The Biography - Cary Grant On Film was entertaining but it isn't the best biopic on the man that I've seen.  For that you would have to see the special features for the 2-Disc version of "Bringing Up Baby" which by the way is also a much better movie than this one.  The jokes on "His Girl Friday" while they may have been funny 68 years ago have not aged very well and despite the quick dialogue, I guess living in this extremely fast paced society today, I didn't think it was that extraordinary either.  Believe me people in Singapore speak just as fast or even faster as a matter of course.  As far as screwball comedy with jokes that are still funny today go, I'd recommend "My Man Godfrey", "The Thin Man" and "Bringing Up Baby" ahead of this one and in that order.  By the way, the Tony Curtis intro does nothing for the disc and I'm not sure what exactly his input had to do with improving the overall enjoyment of the disc as it clearly didn't do that.

Short on special features, okay sound but poor picture quality on humour material that doesn't age well makes me recommend you give this DVD a miss.
Score:
2

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Content-wise, this is a good movie except that when you consider that this was up against "The Thin Man" in the same categories save Best Actress, I find it hard to believe that this movie is the better screwball romance of the two.  Firstly, the jokes are more frequent and are less dated sounding and I found myself laughing at them although I was born more than 3 decades later and overall "The Thin Man" moves along at a good pace making it for me the true Best Picture of 1934.  Woody Van Dyke was also the better director although I can see how the screenplay award could go down to the wire.

As the second best movie of 1934, this movie has a few good things going for it although to call it the best ever screwball romantic comedy would be ridiculous as there are many better ones such as "My Girl Friday" and "The Philadelphia Story" just to name a couple let alone "The Thin Man", as it does have a pretty good screenplay and both Gable and Claudette have a good on-screen chemistry.  I thought the film dragged on a little though and was not as smooth flowing as say "The Thin Man" and the "logic" of going on foot instead of continuing on the bus and in not telling Ellie why he had to go and get gas in the middle of the night escapes me but what made this film great is the great acting of both Gable and Claudette who both deserved their Oscars although I can see why Bette Davis would feel aggrieved after her great performance in "Of Human Bondage".

The problem with this DVD though is the very poor sound and visual quality of the transfer when compared with "The Thin Man".  Perhaps the original masters were better preserved for the latter film but the difference in quality is night and day if you can get a copy of the DVDs to compare them you'll see what I mean.  A little known fact about this movie though is that the scene on the cover is what inspired the creation of Bugs Bunny as creator Chuck Jones stated that he saw Gable as a "big rabbit" and if you watch early Bugs Bunny cartoons, you'll see more than a slight resemblance to Peter Warne as portrayed in the movie.

To conclude, good movie but poor DVD transfer and certainly NOT the best picture of 1934.

Review:
This is an anthology of 3 sweet, clean Regency romance novellas from 3 different authors.

MUCH ADO ABOUT DANCING by Heidi Ashworth
Miss Analisa Lloyd-Jones is about on embark on her 4th season & feels herself quite the old maid having been on the shelf for so long (shes only twenty) but blames it on the Earl of Northrup who has warned off all her suitors for the past two years while he himself has been away from England.

I found Analisa quite a shallow person. When Northrup returns she is taken aback by how handsome he has become; unlike when she knew (& objected to) him previously when he was a gawky, ginger headed, arrogant young man. She was quite happy to welcome & encourage the attentions of another supposedly charming gentleman but when Northrup appears to pay attention to a friend of hers in one of their "etiquette lessons, she gets jealous & snippy.

The story was somewhat abrupt & I found it quite absurd overall.

SWEETER THAN ANY DREAM by Annette Lyon.
At 28, Lady Olivia has long resigned herself to spinsterhood & living with her dragon of a mother & aunt. She has long molded herself into a quiet, dutiful daughter who never gainsays them & whose behavior does not raise their censure. To escape the bleakness of her life, she escapes to a world she creates in her imagination (that include her Prince!)

A sweet & lovely story tho its hard to imagine anyones mother & aunt being so dour & generally nasty. A little bit oa a Cinderella tale with her brother & his wife who collectively play the fairy godmother! Olivia is sweet & intelligent - she loves to read. The hero Edward is an old school chum of her brothers. The romance is sweet & tender.

AN INVITATION TO DANCE by Michele Paige Holmes
Lady Eleanora Whitticomb, Ella has been living on her own on her fathers country manor for several years since her mother died & her father in his grief took to travelling. The only thing she has from her father is a promise of a birthday gift when she turns twenty, which she has been hoping is his agreeing for her to join him. When a stranger turns up with an invitation to London from her (deceased!) betrothed , she initially rejects the invitation but later reconsiders hoping that the trip will prove to her father that she is mature enough to accompany him In his travels.

Ella is a most likeable heroine. She is more comfortable on a horse, or walking in the country with a fishing rod over her shoulder. Shes unpretentious & wholesome & doesnt care much for the silly rules of the ton or angling to catch a rich & titled husband. The romance between her & Alex  the stranger who brings her the invitation to London is sweet & wholesome with Ella showing him that he can be all he wants to be in spite of his disability - he has lost the use of his right hand.

I've quickly come to enjoy these Anthologies. The stories although short are complete & never feel rushed. The romance is well written & very sweet. Other than the 1st story in this collection, I've enjoyed all the stories so far.

Copy gifted in exchange for an honest review.
Score:
3

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Sophie's family becomes destitute when her father, a wealthy shipping magnate dies in a suspicious accident & his wealth from his successful business mysteriously disappears. Her 2 older sisters try to discover who was responsible for destroying their father (coincidentally they have 3 suspects) & Sophie decides to go back to their previous home & live in a cottage on the ground estates with their former nanny.

When Sophie's nanny has an accident & is taken to a nursing home, in desperation Sophie goes to the Main House with a vague idea of seeking employment. She is met by the butler who immediately takes her for the new cook that they have been expecting which Sophie happily falls in with (being an excellent cook & loving it). The comedy of mistaken identity goes even further with the Viscount who takes her for the courtesan/mistress that he had contracted for from London.

I loved the book! Wonderful writing & storytelling. The author's style of writing is lovely. Fluid & totally carries you along with characters that you immediately feel connected with. Sophie is by no means perfect. She's rather vain. She's beautiful & knows it. She plans to marry a rich, titled gentleman. She still comes across as someone totally likable. Her relationship with Alexander is so amusing! She's quite innocent in a lot of ways & their conversations are full of double entendres which Sophie doesn't realize at all. She's talking about cooking while he takes everything she says in a sexual context (delicious, satisfying his appetite - you get the drift!).

Alexander is totally swoonworthy. The brooding, sardonic hero who, when he falls for Sophie falls hard.

There's a lovely cast of secondary characters - Alexander's butler/valet Dickens is particularly lovable. It was most touching when all his servants took Sophie's part & were very protective of her.

This is the 3rd book in the series. I'd not read the previous 2 but had no problems reading this as a standalone.

Copy received from Netgalley for an honest review.

Review:
So many books, so little time, so why did I waste any on this?
It isn't exactly bad.  In fact, it could have been good . . . if it weren't so, um, bland.  I bought it thinking my mom, who sometimes complains that getting old is killing her, might enjoy this series, but I don't recommend books without reading them so I read it.  And didn't bother to share it with her.  It wasn't that funny.  It wasn't that interesting.  It wasn't that well written, though it wasn't really that badly written.  Just thinly written.  I don't object to mind candy -- I read quite a lot of it -- but this was like eating half a plain rice cake instead of triple layer chocolate cake filled with whipped mocha ganache and frosted with satiny bittersweet chocolate ganache.
In all fairness, I should disclose that I find most television shows deadly dull . . . especially the kind of television shows in the author's credits.  I couldn't help wondering if I'd like this story better in the hands of any halfway decent cast.

Review:
This sprawling, wildly eclectic and endlessly inventive double album forever dashed the notion that 'Purple Rain' would be Prince's creative peak. For my money, this is his finest work of art. Everything about it is  refreshing, the cover art, the packaging the sequencing and most  importantly the music all show him as the restless creative genius we've  always known him to be.  From the bleak, issued-riddled title track, to the  jaunty 'Play In The Sunshine' this album is all over the place. To give a  brief synopsis of my favorite tracks; 'The Ballad Of Dorothy Parker'-  dominated by some sharp Linn-LM1 drum machine programming and supple, funky  bassline that even quotes Joni Mitchell! 'It'- a simple canned beat that  builds to an orchestrated, synth driven climax about "f---in'on yo'  mind", one of his best sex songs ever. 'Starfish & Coffee'-  notable for it's terrific sing along melody and chorus and sparse  repetitive backing track. The lyrics are some of his best. 'I Could Never  Take The Place Of Your Man'- proof that he can rattle off a great, '60's  influenced pop song in his sleep. (Special Note: rent the 'Sign  "O" The Times' film and see the blazing treatment he gives this  song live in concert, his ripping, orgasmic guitar solo is revelatory!)  (Special Note #2 about the film, Shiela E. performs a drum solo during a  jazzy instrumental jam that must be seen to be believed. She plays so hard,  she abandons sticks altogether and slaps the crash cymbals with her bare  hands!)  And speaking of abandoning things, I hereby abandon the notion  that the pleasures found on this epic release can be limited to a handful  of tracks. Buy the LP in any format, and you'll be richly rewarded. A  Classic.
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This was my fortunate introduction the music of Joni Mitchell, and this stripped down, initmate set of songs still gets regular play in my tape deck. The rhythmic acoustic strumming, and 'barely there' percussion that  introduces "All I Want" is a distinctive, inviting intro to the  LP and sets the tone for what will be a very personal emotional journey.  Throughout this sterling song cycle, Joni lays her soul bare in such  beautiful, loving tunes as "My Old Man", "Carey"  "A Case Of You" and my personal favorites: the gorgeous title  song, "A Little Green" and "The Last Time I Saw  Richard" , songs so rich in detail they seem to place the listener  right in midst of what's going on. The sound and overall tone of the album  is understated and serene. With only the sparest of backing ( acoustic  guitar, mandolin or piano ) Ms. Mitchell's pristine, shivery soprano is  right out front where it should be, forcing you to hear and feel every  word. This is the album that made the world sit up and really pay attention  to 'singer/songwriters' for the first time. "Blue" remains a  highwater mark in pop music.  A welcome addition to your collection.

Review:
I'm using these labels on a Dymo 450 Turbo on a Mac.

If you were hoping to use these labels to print Paypal shipping, look for the one-part labels instead. Even after a lot of fiddling, you cannot get these labels to print postage correctly (it will print sideways from Paypal, meaning only a portion of the tracking number is printed, the rest is blank) unless you do a clever workaround in Cups and Photoshop. Even then, it prints backwards (the postage prints where it says "return" and "recipient" and the return and recipient prints where it says "postage". So you have to pull all four pieces (even the bit that's meant to be thrown away) off the strip and pieces them back together on the packaging. It looks incredibly unprofessional, and you have to do a bit of resizing in Photoshop as well because the only settings Paypal has for Labelwriter 330 and 330 Turbo, whose labels are 7.5", not 7" like these.

Normally I'd have given these labels an okay rating, but then I found out that Dymo won't even give out the template for this label, or ANY internet postage labels! According to their troubleshooting page, these labels are only compatible Stamps.com or Endicia. I wish they'd printed this on the box or put that in the product description - unfortunately I wasted $16.

Review:
I was able to play with the pre-release version of this product. The Compute stick won't be a replacement for your desktop, it won't run all the latest 3d Games, but I was surprised that quite a few games from Steam would play on it, and Hulu, Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Youtube all played smoothly on it.

I loaded the device with PowerPoint and other software for doing presentations, and found that for traveling it was more convenient than a laptop in many cases. Throwing this in my briefcase "man purse" (a Filson bag) I could be sure that I always had what I needed to give a pitch anywhere there was a TV or projector.

The size of the SSD (32 Gigs) is a bit of a limitation. You aren't going to load up 16 episodes of Walking Dead in HD from Microsoft Video (what used to be Zune and is also Xbox Live Video) because you will run out of space, but you can plug in a USB card, and with a micro SD in the slot, and a 256 Gig Micro SD in a mini Reader I still had a very small system with a decent collection of media. (This was also helpful for games)

Steam was a use case I was interested in. I don't game a lot, but it is nice to have something to play in the hotel when traveling. Yes I could use my laptop, but again sometimes I want to travel light, and this was a much better way to do that. The Quad Core CPU is faster than a lot of Netbook type laptops, even some of the $1000 laptops don't have as much CPU as this. The Graphics Card how ever is a bit wussy. There is only 2 Gigs of memory and the GPU shares that with the CPU.

The games generally look better than they would on my android phone, but you aren't going to want to try and be competitive in first person shooters. I like Magic The Gathering and it plays well, and I was surprised I could get World of Warcraft to play on it. A bit rough, but you can't do that on an Xbox or Play Station.

I am looking in to if I could use these for small server farm type things. The idea of having a small server that uses very little power and has no moving parts definitely has some appeal.

Bluetooth makes hooking up a mouse, keyboard, and headphones a breeze.

I really loved the unit I got to play with and will be picking up several of these in the future. I am hopeful someone will make a "Docking Station" with a battery so I could just make this a "Laptop" and then plug it in to a screen when I wanted. (a guy can dream)
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
I got an early release version of this product, and love it. While my TV has an HD/ATSC tuner built in, I have several TVs that don't, and this is a cheap way to add off the air capabilities if you already have an Xbox one.

The DVR works well, and the 30 Minutes of chasing playback is great for pausing shows to go to the bathroom, or doing what I like to do of just starting a show 15 minutes late so I can watch it without commercials, but still finish when everyone else does.

You can use this to do a sort of picture in picture thing, which works ok, but unless you are "grinding" in a game you don't have to pay attention too, I couldn't find much use for this feature. Maybe if I was playing a turn based game, like Catan, or Magic?

The picture quality is great, as is the sound. I don't have an Xbox specific remote, which I am more inclined to pick up now that I am using this for Live TV.

This did seem to pick up 3 stations that I couldn't pick up with the tuner built in to my TV, so I'm going to judge the reception to be better than average, but I didn't test 5 devices to know that. It is just better than the one built in to my Sharp TV.

I don't have digital cable at my place so I haven't tried to make that work.

Review:
I will say that this book has a strong narrative drive - that essential quality that makes a bestseller.  In order for the reader to feel engaged, there must be tension on every page.  Mission accomplished.  (Of course, the tension on every page is the knowledge that we know a murder takes place at the end.)  After a while, though, you might find yourself saying, "Just leave the marriage, Janine."  I hate to say this, because it sounds cold, but without the murder at the end, this book would never have been published.  My sympathies to the family but I never saw Janine as quite the victim she made of herself.  Her husband Kurt says nasty things, and can seem hateful and overly-jealous.  In other words, the guy's terribly insecure and she paints him strongly with a series of snotty remarks that build to something just this side of psychotic.  We get enough of the good times to see that he's probably not as bad as she describes him, mainly because she seems smart, smart enough to know better.  Her Dad is a real creep job and she has been horrifyingly violated in a rape she never disclosed to her family.  As her memoir went on, however, I couldn't help wondering if she was leaving out some of her responsibility in the dissolution of their marriage.  After her husband freaks over an imaginary encounter, she announces that "it's over."  However, she still continues to consider herself victimized, saying she will be broke, homeless, etc. when we know this is untrue.  She is the wife of a successful man, who has gone into marriage counseling with her several times, and she will be taken care of.  I found her voice to be spare yet muscular and evocative, and I liked it.  I'm not sure I trusted it, but I liked it.  As for liking the story itself, not so much, though it may be empowering to women who struggle with self-esteem issues in bad relationships.  I am however, sorry for Janine's loss and that of her family.  Her sister was special.
Score:
2

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Some people live for the kind of adventure that is found documenting civil strife, murder and mayhem in dangerous foreign locales.  They usually work and play hard and think of themselves as the luckiest people in the world because they are essentially their own bosses.  The fact that their lives are constantly at risk in the commission of making a living seems to be a minor consideration.  I, like many others, am in awe of people such as this and I found this book to be a fascinating glimpse into what happens when you hit 40 and start to think about settling down.  I think I'd be looking for a nice quiet country place with a yard, maybe a pond too.  Judith Matloff thought it might be nice to raise a family on a block infested with violent psychopathic crackmonsters.  Hey, to each their own!  It makes sense.  If adventure is in your blood, you don't move out to suburbia, even when you "settle down."

I loved reading this book and didn't want it to end.  I found Judith gutsy and compassionate -- two qualities I especially like to find in a person, and so I loved the way she told the story.  She is by turns frightened, witty, compassonate, and ultimately victorious.

I found it hard to believe that some of the people she knew from her reporting days, those who lived in war-ravaged countries where mass murder and rape were common occurrences, were afraid to visit her in Harlem.  When she arrives on the block, and meets her nemesis, the notorious Salami, the local black population knows they've got a chance to get their neighborhood back.  "They'll listen to you, because you're white," one woman says to her.  And it's true.  But it's not only the fact that the author is white that gets things going, it's the fact that she's willing to do the footwork, go to the meetings, chat up the civil servants, and follow through that creates the conditions she, and the rest of the block, are hoping for.

I have never read a memoir of a person who toils in fields of misery for a living.  I finished this book in two days, and wanted more.  The author has a gift for bringing the characters on her block to life.  She sees good everywhere and is only slightly intimidated by even the scariest crackhead.

I got a kick out of the author's husband, who is like many of my Dutch relatives -- a bit arrogant and condescending, in general, and towards the USA most specifically, and I especially enjoyed Mrs. La Dukes.  In fact, this book is packed with indelible characters that I hated to say goodbye to.  I was glad the author provided an epilogue so that we could find out what happened to them.

Five stars, great read!

Review:
Lisa Gardner CAN write; unfortunately she forgot the first rule of creative writing: make your characters likeable.

Charlene was too messed up to identify with.  I'm not sure how many among us can actually imagine living thru the kind of abuse Charlie went thru and not knowing keeps the reader from bonding with the character.

Detective Warren was an embarrassment to new mothers.  And yes, my eldest had me running around like a zombie for the first 3 months so I do know what she went thru but no professional should act the way she did; if she couldn't handle the lack of sleep, she should have taken a leave.  People's lives, not to mention their freedom, depended on police with fully functional wits.  And motherhood should have made her appreciate her own mother.

And what is it with the strong woman portrayal? A woman doesn't need to be a b! tch to be rock solid.  I notice that many woman are being portrayed as men used to be in romance novels: angry, stubborn, and a plain pain in the you know what.

I was all set to order a whole bunch of her books and waited until the very end, hoping the characters would have some redeeming feature I could like.  But even after knowing how abused Charlie was and how young she was when they found her, Detective Warren allowed her fellow cop to go after Charlie with a battering ram of words that was abuse itself.  Sorry, but that breaks another rule of creative writing: never have your protagonist cross the line where the reader cannot forgive her/him.

Det. Warren, mother of a newborn, did so when she allowed her fellow cop to abuse a women who had been horrifyingly abused as a child.

And I, the reader, can not forgive her.
Score:
3

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Creative writing 101 teaches that one MUST have the reader invested in the protagonist.  Unfortunately there is no one to like.  Rachel is pathetic, Anna selfish, Megan self absorbed and destructive.  Even long suffering flat mate Cathy comes off self righteous.  The men are creeps and manipulative.  Yet I kept reading till the end and gave it 2 stars instead of 1 for two reasons. I hate to admit it but I suppose I have a little horror voyeurism in me and like all those people "rubber necking" a car accident, I couldn't stop reading about the truly sad lives of these truly stupid women.  The second reason and perhaps even more disturbing is like those family and friends of addicts who keep hoping that the addict will see the light and STOP, I kept hoping that Rachel would realize that what she got from her addiction wasn't worth what it cost her.  But of course, she kept drinking--and letting the reader down.  In this horrible "hope", the author did succeed in getting this reader to "invest" in the character of Rachel, hating her and this book for doing so.

**Update.  I watched the movie "Gone Girl" and agree.  This book doesn't come close to Gone Girl.  While Girl on the train had no one the reader could cheer on, Amy of Gone Girl was deliciously evil, finding a clever way to get back at her cheating husband.  Again, I didn't read the book Gone Girl, but I really enjoyed the movie. If the book was different, the movie version will have to really change the character of Rachel to pull out a protagonist we could like.

Review:
These are good, but they are not as hot as the real deal/Atomic Fireball jawbreakers. I got these because there was just too much confusion regarding Amazon's Ferrara Atomic Fireball jawbreakers (i.e. whether they were the "large" or "small" size, whether they were fresh or not, etc.). So I decided to try the J.R. version. They're good, and have a nice cinnamon flavor, but they are not nearly as hot as the original Atomic Fireballs. For some folks that might be good. But if you're looking for that true hot fire -- where you actually have to think about taking the jawbreaker out of your mouth because it's too hot -- these won't quite fit the bill.

NOTE: After reading all the reviews of the Atomic Fireball jawbreakers, I saw a consistent suggestion: go to Sam's and get them fresh, at a much better price. The only problem is...I don't belong to Sam's. But I do belong to BJs (such a funny name) and I checked online and saw that their stores do carry the 150 piece containers. So tonight I went there and for under $7 including tax I got a 2.5 pound container of fresh (good through 2017) original Atomic Fireballs. (Though these are made in Mexico, whereas the originals were made in the US.) That's definitely the way to go if you want the hottest cinnamon candy on the planet for the best price. (It works out to just under 5 cents/piece.) If not, these J.R.'s are acceptable, but cost more than three times as much.

Review:
I seriously love these cannisters and can not wait to use them full time displayed on my kitchen bench in my new house.  Right now I do not have the counter space and that disappoints me.  Thy are sitting on an ugly old plastic shelf for the time being.

I've given some thought to how many cannister sets I have owned of various sizes, shapes, designs and materials.  Many with the promise of having a great seal.  I can not count how many times I have been let down.

This set delivers on being air tight.  The rubber ring is ridged and seems to give an edge to the seal they provide, I am hesitant to store things like coffee in cannisters due to sealing issues and instead store it in my freezer.  I am not having these doubts with this set.  We go through a lot of coffee so I was not too worried about being able to use it before it goes rancid, providing I could keep it fresh.

I've even shown tipping the cannister upside down full of beans, I did give it a few good shakes, and trust me I was holding my breath that it would hold haha.  Glad to report to you that it did!  I can not comment as to if it would hold if they were dropped,  my guess is erring to the maybe not, could depend on how they land since they do not screw into anything. I can only say that they are solidly plugged and give a pop when they come off, you do have to give them a bit of a nudge  to break the seal.  So who knows, not something I am hoping to find out any time soon though however.  But then again I am not too sure any cannister would.

I have my beans stored in the smallest cannister, that is a 1 pound bag of beans minus 2 small pots.  A typical bag of coffee is around 12 ounces.

These cannisters are generous in sizing without being overly large or too small to be of any use.

The finish on them is really nice too, high gloss black, it appears to be powder coated, they are also available in a fire engine red.  They are made from stainless steel.  I am most fond of stainless steel anything and the co-ordinating black and stainless finish is a perfect match for my other appliances.  They are also a great weight, while they are not rediculously heavy they are no where near flimsy.

The finish also makes them easy to keep clean and in my opinion a lot more sanitary than anything besides glass.  I love the finish, it is sleek and modern.

The windows are plastic, it is the only plastic thing you will find on the cannisters besides the seals.  They are large so you can easily identify the contents of your cannisters.  I like that the lids do not have knobs or handles on them, it is one less thing for me to accidently knock while cleaning  and prevents spills.  It also adds to the sleek and minimalistic design of the set.

Over all these cannisters offer great eye appeal and would match just about any decor, I really could not be happier.

Review:
This was such a beautifully written book, I have never been to Africa (and never likely to get there) but through Rebecca's words, I felt like I was there. I felt the harsh sun on my skin, I was watching the birds with Iris and I was seeing the smiles and joy from the students that Iris interacted with.

In many ways, this was quite a tough book to read. Iris is given two choices by her mother: marry a stranger in England (who sounded quite revolting) or marry a stranger in Kenya. She choose Kenya and she was very lucky that she had such a lovely chaperone in the form of Miss Logan. Her new husband was a shock to the system and living in Kenya was completely different to everything she was used to, but her spirit of adventure came through loud and clear in the book and I really enjoyed seeing Kenya through Iris' eyes. Things go pretty disastrously wrong for Iris but she also has moments of great joy. I love that this book started at the beginning of the last century - we have come such a long way since then, thank goodness.

The only reason this review isn't getting 5 stars from me today is because there are a few loose ends that weren't tied up and it left me finishing the book and wanting to know what happened. The writing, however, was wonderful, as is the storyline. I give it 4.5 stars :)

Highly recommended read.

With thanks to NetGalley and Bookouture for this ARC, in exchange for my honest review.

Review:
I am not sure what I expected, but considering Trevor Noah is a comedian, I guess I expected it to have quite a few humorous moments in it. I was wrong. That being said, it does have some wry humour, but this is a very gritty, very honest account of his early years and it was an eye opener for this middle-aged white woman.

I loved the relationship that Trevor and his mother have, it shines through on every page, even if he doesn't always agree or approve of some decisions she has made along the way. She sounds like an amazing lady who has overcome incredible odds to give her son the best possible life.  I can't even fathom a world where having a relationship with someone of another race could cause you to be jailed for years, that is just baffling to me. His mother's issues with her ex caused me to shed some tears (some problems are the same the world over and I could really relate) and I marvelled all over again what a strong and also lucky woman she was. You will have to read the book to know what I mean by that!

There were a couple of places in this book that were very uncomfortable reading for me, one in particular because I am an animal lover. So I would like to warn anyone who is as soft as I am,  there is a graphic description of animal cruelty contained in this book (not perpetrated by Trevor Noah, I hasten to add).

Anyway, this was a pretty awesome book and I learned so much more about apartheid than I had any idea about, and what it is like to be born into a society where you just don't quite fit.

Trevor has a great admiration for his mother, but I think he is pretty incredible himself, considering where he started from.

Highly recommended read from me.

Review:
Kimberley Griffiths Little's newest novel, Forbidden, is an unusual, evocative historical YA novel. Set in ancient Mesopotamia, the story follows 16-year-old Jayden as her family attempts to cross the desert to their winter oasis after a family tragedy. Still reeling from her loss and  anxious about the dangers of the crossing (particularly as they've been separated from the rest of their tribe), Jayden meets an unusual stranger who needs her family's help. Of course, Jayden is intrigued by the newcomer.

There's just one problem. Jayden is already betrothed. To Horeb, set to become their tribe's leader after his father's death. But Jayden doesn't like or trust Horeb, who has become increasingly shifty and cruel. Adding to this complication is her sister's growing fascination with the goddess temple to Ashtoreth, which goes against everything Jayden's mother and grandmother have taught them. As the novel progresses, Jayden has to figure out what truths are most important to her--and what she will have to sacrifice to stay true to herself.

For me, the setting (cultural and physical) of the novel was one of my favorite parts. I loved The Red Tent back when it came out, and I enjoyed revisiting a world where the women of a tribe had such a lovely, close-knit bond. Looking at some of the history behind belly dancing was also fascinating to me. Little does a nice job evoking the setting--at once harsh and beautiful. I liked, too, that Jayden's issues with her sister were realistic and complicated, how Jayden both loves her sister but struggles to understand her choices. There were a few places in the last half of the novel where the plot swirled quite quickly, and sometimes I struggled to keep pace with the twists, but I'm not sure that is a bad thing! I'm definitely looking forward to seeing how Jayden's story resolves in the rest of the series.

4

Review:
This world--a desert kingdom inspired by Arabian culture with religious links to the First Beings (djinn and other mystical creatures)--is so vivid. But it's not an easy world, and for Amina, a sixteen-year-old orphan living in Dustwalk, in the middle of nowhere, all she wants to do is get out. Her opportunity comes in the unlikely form of a boy named Jin, who's wanted by the Sultan's soldiers. But as Amina gets farther from the world she was born to and learns more about the politics destroying her native land and the rebellion growing to change that, the more she begins to question who she really is--and what she wants.

I loved this book--I loved Amina's strength, and Jin's humor (even when it got him in trouble. Or maybe especially then). I adored the setting, how I could imagine riding through the night across a Nightmare-haunted desert. The story is wonderfully paced too. It has all my favorite things: a unique setting, a powerful romance, and terrifying and powerful creatures. Really, a book for all YA fantasy readers to enjoy.

Review:
I have owned both a older LG(the battery eventually died and was too expensive to replace) and an ILIFE robot vacuum. The previous two were great for cleaning up hard floors but never really got the carpet clean.  This one does actually clean the carpet.

Pros:
It does actually clean carpet as evidenced by the amount of dirt picked up AFTER running my ILIFE.

It sees better, it does not use bumping into stuff to navigate. I purposely left my house full of stuff (we are redoing the kitchen and stuff is everywhere) and it did quite well avoiding obstacles.

It will go back home and recharge itself (takes about 2-3 hours) and then go back and complete the job.

It does a better job of finding home than any other robot vacuum I have had, and seems to reserve power to do so.

It picks up even fine dust.  I have been forcing it to clean around the house while we are in the midst of a kitchen remodel, and I was surprised by how fine the dust it picked up.

It can navigate over fairly tall thresholds (even an inch high one) which my other vacuums could not.

It is easy to clean the brush and to remove the dirt collecting cup (which holds about 3 times as much as my other vacuum)

It will work without connecting it to WIFI or the app (just wanders around cleaning, sometimes with some purpose, sometimes it seems a bit random)

It can handle the throw rugs in my bathrooms.

It works fine on dark tile.

It extracts itself pretty well from tight spots.

Cons:
It is taller than my ILIFE and will not fit under some furniture.

On Turbo mode it is reasonably loud,  too loud to have a conversation in the room without raising your voice.

It struggles with the three inch fringe on one of my rugs.  Does not usually tangle too badly, but it is often beeping for help when dealing with the fringe.

The magnetic strip to block the vacuum has no instructions and is pretty useless.  You are supposed to stick it down (like perhaps around a litter box?) .

Tall ceilings seem to confuse it, it does a much better job in my kitchen and bedrooms than in the living room with vaulted ceilings.  It misses a lot of spots in the living room unless you program it to clean (rather than letting it wander).

The WIFI and Smartphone app are a bit buggy and difficult.  It appears to be designed for all Samsung appliances.  It is easy to set up but I found using it somewhat counter intuitive.

Overall:

Frankly I am not sure it is worth the price point, you need to consider how often you need to vacuum.  If you have pets and need to vacuum daily, this may be worth it.  If you only vacuum once a week you might want to consider the cost.  It does vacuum much better than my  ILIVE device which is about one seventh the price, but you might be better off with a cheaper robot vacuum and a good upright (to really get the carpets clean) if you do not need to vacuum often.
Score:
4
