Review:
I received a copy of this book from eBook Discovery in exchange for my honest review.  So often, when I receive a gift copy of a book for review, the book turns out to be a disappointment.  Even if the plot is ok (a 50/50 chance its only a sort of "preview" of a book), there is often a cliff hanger at the end (upsetting) or a lot of editing errors.  That is not the case with this book.  This one was an excellent.  I understand previous reviewers' comments about Christian being abusive, etc., however, we have to remember, Christian is, himself, an emotional mess.  He has lost his whole family and received a crippling war injury resulting in constant pain.  He winds up coming home and taking over his father's newspaper, which he has no interest in doing.  He has a LOT of issues.  Then there's Jenny, who is a Jane Doe locked in the hospital and labeled a lunatic.  When they first come in contact she is receiving water treatments intended to induce fear and panic that is supposed to somehow help her.  Christian is mortified at this treatment, while not realizing at the beginning that this is the woman he is there to observe at the request of his friend, a doctor.  When he tries to help her and to let her know he will be coming back for her, she turns the tables on him and he winds up locked in and strapped down while she steals his horse and runs.  Later,  the horse returns to his stable with Jenny still on board, but she is nearly frozen in the winter weather.  Christian makes sure she receives help and the whole household staff take her under their wing.  Christian realizes he has inappropriate feelings for this woman and does not want her around him but she has no place else to go.  Jenny has even more issues than Christian and neither knows how to deal with the attraction they begin to feel for one another.  Throughout the book, the whole plot is to find out who Jenny really is and why there are people who wish to hurt her.  She does not feel she can trust anyone enough to confide in them because she thinks they will think she really is a lunatic.  It takes most of the book to find out what is really going on, who she is and why she's had such a hard time.  This turns into a sweet love story when both Christian and Jenny realize what they have in each other and manage to build trust between them.  I loved the story and the fact that all loose ends are tied when the story is finished.  I loved the writer's style and there were few places in the book that needed editing.

5

Review:
I don't think were all meant to cruise through life at the same speed. I think some of us were meant to go fast and others slow. Its easy to judge and critique, but petty practices like these rarely produce anything productive.

I think the key is to run your own race and at your own pace. Easier said than done. And thats why The Raging Sloth is so needed. Think of it as a much needed guidebook. Heres why.

Most people want to experience a successful and abundant life. But is this possible in a world full of pain and obstacles?

The Raging Sloth provides a positive blueprint on how to move forward, even through the muck and mire of life.

Speaker, author, and coach Eric Eaton shows you a 9-Step process to:

Engage your obstacles and leverage them to experience victory
Find purpose in the midst of your own limitations
Redefine success on your own terms
Live a life free of guilt, frustration, and excuses

Through his own journey Eric reveals his constant struggle with chronic pain while pursuing success in every part of his life. Through these highs and lows, Eric learned his entire life could thrive in spite of his pain, but only if he redefined success on his own terms.

Eric shows how anyone with limitations can live the upside-down life of success by becoming what he refers to as a Raging Sloth.

Isnt it time you became a Raging Sloth and bust through your limits, build your purpose, and balance your life? The Upside Down Life is a life worth living.

Review:
I received a free copy in exchange for a honest review..

4.5 STARS

First let me say that I love the cover of this book. I think it fits perfectly with the story. Now let me also say I had no clue what a tag chaser was and had to google it to find out as I started to read. I have lived around a military base all my life and never heard this phrase or some of the other ones that came up when I searched it so I learned something new. Lol.

As far as the book. I did love it. I absolutely loved Corbin. He was hot, sexy, sweet, and romantic. The perfect freaking man right there. He stole my breath more then once with what he would say and how to he acted. He did have me a little mad at some points with the phone calls but I get it now.

As for Paisley. She is a sweet woman. I have to say that what her dad did sucked butt but for me she made it bigger then what it should of really been. Now maybe I just didn't have the relationship with my dad that she did and I can't see her point of view on it but for me she just blew it out of proportion. That was honestly the only thing that bugged me about this book.

Tanner was a hottie and sweetheart but I really started to dislike him at the end. He just started to rub me the wrong way. You DO NOT try to have sex with a girl after her heart has been broken. That is just low in my book.

So tag chaser.... From what I have read and how this story went. Paisley wasn't a tag chaser. She just preferred to date military guys. She wasn't sleeping with all of them or trying to tie them down and marry them. So to me she is not a tag chaser. But this book was well written and everything played out nicely. Not to fast and no dull moments. I enjoyed it and didn't put it down till I was done.  The ending almost had me crying and I was so glad everything worked out the way it did. Emotion felt real during this book. Especially at the end. I will definitely recommend this book.

Review:
This book is actually a textbook, and assumes that the reader has Sibelius 7 (and possibly other software made or distributed by Avid, like ProTools or the accessories by Neutron), but has little or not experience using it. It's broken down into lessons that are finely detailed and steps the reader through all the fundamental aspects of notating music with the application.

For an absolute beginner with Sibelius 7, this is a ten star book. If you go through all the lessons, an investment of approximately ten to twelve hours, you will be using the application confidently and fluidly. There is even an appendix that explores the basics of music theory, although only superficially, and the book in no way is a course in how to compose music, just how to notate music using the software.

If you are an experienced user, the book may or may not be of use to you. The basic lessons in the various ways to input notes, create, layout and edit scores may be good refreshers but are just likely to be tedious and superfluous. This book also does not touch on how to create the type of complex or non-standard notation that are a common staple of so much post-WWII classical music: in other words, if you want to figure out how to make your scores look like those of George Crumb or Luciano Berio, it would probably be better to turn to the Sibelius 7 reference manual. Also, this is not in itself a reference, even for a beginner, and is not organized for easily looking up how to do things via the index. But for what it is, it's an ideal model not only for teaching but also for how such books should be produced: thorough, detailed, easy to follow, logical and, most important, correct!
Score:
4

Review:
I read, write and speak Italian at a moderately accomplished level.  Of course, I haven't had to read, write or speak it in about 18 months, and so my skills and comprehension have diminished over time.  This set is useful and effective for practice, especially the necessary practice of the ear, of hearing the language spoken and hearing yourself speak it.  If you have some level of Italian and want to maintain it, this Oxford set is a good and reasonably priced choice.  Also, if you want to learn enough Italian to get you through a trip to the country, this would also do the job for you.

However, this in no way is a true course in the language, which means studying Italian in the cultural context, developing the ability to read stories and novels, newspapers and magazine, and discuss daily life with adequate skills - the Oxford set will not bring you to that point.  So, evaluate your needs, and choose accordingly.

Review:
Out of all the power banks I own, the Poweradd Apollo has quickly become my favorite. In this day and age, we depend on our cellular devices for so many conveniences, Including but not limited to: GPS/Maps, Communication, Information, and so much more! By being so dependent on our cell phones, we quickly drain our batteries, rendering our devices temporarily useless, and potentially putting ourselves into harms way. This is where the Apollo bank by Poweradd comes into play. This device quickly charged both my Samsung Galaxy S5 and iPhone 6s Plus in a device test, just as quickly as having the device plugged into a wall outlet. Any device that is powered by a USB charger can be used on this device. This device features 5000 mAh charging power, a backup solar panel for sunlight charging, a micro USB cable to charge the device, a carabiner to clip the device to your bag, and even a small LED light that can prove to be invaluable in emergency situations! This Charger includes 4 blue LED lights indicating how much power the device currently has. 1 = 25%, 2 = 50%, 3 = 75%, and 4 = 100%. To turn on the LED flashlight for this device, simply hold down the red button above the Poweradd logo to turn it on, and again to turn it off.  It is just about the size of a Samsung Galaxy S5 for reference.

IMPORTANT: if you are sitting here thinking you'll only charge your devices using solar power from now on, this isn't exactly ideal. While this CAN be done, it would take a very long time to charge this device solely using solar power, close to a few days. The solar power feature is intended for situations where you do not have access to electricity, such as when camping, backpacking, traveling, or even during weather emergencies. This is especially useful in New England Winter's when the power is frequently out for days due to severe snow storms. Overall, I think EVERYONE should own a solar powered cell phone charger in case of emergencies, and the Poweradd Apollo is one I would HIGHLY recommend!

This lantern is a MUST have for camping, power outages, and even just a general light source, as it gets impressively bright! Simply slide up the light and you're good to go.

Overall, this is a wonderful lantern. The battery life is outstanding, and I really enjoy that you can power the device three ways; battery, rechargeable DC battery, and solar power. Review:
This was a great slow burn contemporary romance that I couldn't put down. I seriously devoured it in just hours and shunned all other activities until I was done. The characters come from totally different worlds but they both have drive and determination. This is a story about second chances and taking what you're dealt and making something from it.

Cole and Summer come from two different worlds. Cole has killer good looks, is an heir and businessman, a first time producer, and movie star. Hes jaded from his gold digger of a soon-to-be ex-wife which is threatening the timing of this project. Summer is from Quincy, Georgia (where the filming is taking place and shes helping with local logistics), has been an outcast all her life, and her good looks and feistiness tend to get her in trouble. It bounces back and forth between the two towns while they prepare for production and we get to see what has made these two the way they are. Once they actually meet in person theres an instant attraction and sexual tension spikes. I loved their banter and those two sure know how to needle each other. They were both fantastic characters (flaws and all) and I loved getting inside their heads.

Despite the gradual build, this book still does a great job of keeping the reader engaged. Its a great feel good book that has that little extra to spice it up. The hilarious dialogue just adds that levity in what could otherwise be a more serious story. Told in dual POVs, its an excellent chance to see what has happened in their pasts to make them who they are. It was great to be able to follow along in their journey of growing, learning, and loving. Alessandra Torre does an excellent job with describing a situation so you really feel like you're in the story with the characters or watching on a movie screen. This was an awesome 5 stars!!!

Review:
I wasn't sure how to feel about this, all I can remember is my childhood and having to help my mom with her hook and eye closures on shapewear. It is not a pleasant memory, and I hadn't noticed the one spot in the description where it mentions this having a hook and eye crotch closure. But I tried it on anyway, with undergarments (top and bottom), and is how I'll wear it - for maximum comfort and effectiveness/cleanliness (I'm the 'weirdo' who wears underwear with pantyhose too, fwiw).

I normally wear a 12/XL, but followed advice/packaging and bought a L - it fight perfect. It was tight, but not soul sucking, OMG I CANT BREATHE tight, just a reassuring "you're sucked and tucked and look fabulous" squeeze, like the hug of a trusted friend. It was a bit harder to get into than the brief bottom version, but not bad. Taking it off.... I will admit I may have said a bit loudly as I tried to get it off "Boyfriend!!! Help!!! I'm stuck!!!" For some reason I think I had the crotch un-buttoned and was trying to get it off over my head - I have the distinct memory of if all bunch up under my boobs and feeling a bit trapped. This may not be an accurate memory, and I'm definitely going to advocate the putting on and taking off like a swimsuit method for this.

To test the effectiveness of this, I put on a dress I love that shows the dreaded "belly button shadow" - and it smoothed out all the lines and made a much nicer shape. I asked my boyfriend his thoughts, and had him compare the dress with and without the shapewear - he said it was subtle difference, but he did notice one. I'm not crazy, I don't think this will shave 50 or even 25 lbs off my body, but I appreciate the smoothing effective it (and any shapewear) gives, and my boyfriend did think the dress looked better with this. The bottom of the shapewear did stay in place, even when I moved/jumped around in an exaggerated fashion as the ultimate test.

I wasn't sure how comfortable this would be over my own bra - it was, and I decided to buy several other styles. It's a great purchase, because even if it's a small difference, there are some dresses (right or wrong) that I feel self conscious in that this will let me without stupid insecurities at the forefront of my mind. No one (myself included) NEEDS shapewear, but I think it can help you feel confident in your body and in your skin, eventually feeling that way without it. I know there are more expensive versions out there, but for me, this did the trick great.

5

Review:
Royce and Hadrian, the former professional thieves collectively known as the Riyria, along with their companions, are on a dangerous quest to recover an ancient horn that has the power to stop the merciless onslaught of the elves. They will discover that their world, Elan, has a deadly secret history and that many key people are not who they are thought to be. Percepliquis is the grand conclusion of the RIYRIA REVELATIONS.

What started out as a straightforward fantasy adventure in The Crown Conspiracy has evolved into a full-blown epic in Percepliquis. Mr. Sullivan accomplished this so discreetly that I didn't even realize how complex the story had become until I cracked open this book. The exciting escapades of two partners in crime have grown to be a world-encompassing high fantasy conflict, complete with many characters who have their own backstories and subplots. That's not to say the sheer fun of it has been sacrificed.

Michael J. Sullivan writes for an adult audience while infusing his novels with all the charm of the favorite stories of our youth. This quality made the RIYRIA REVELATIONS stand out among its contemporaries. All the genre's mainstays are here -- elves, dwarves, goblins, religions and mythologies, medieval settings, kings, princesses, warriors and wizards, magic, and dragons -- but Sullivan uses them all in his own unique way.

Royce and Hadrian started out as a typical "brains-and-brawn" duo comparable to Fritz Leiber's Fafhrd and the Gray Mouser. That's in no way a bad thing, but it enriched the series to see them develop into their own original characters.

While I enjoyed the heroic actions of the Riyria, the noble deeds by many other characters were so endearing that I found myself just as interested in their stories. I don't want to even remotely risk a spoiler, but I will say that this series ending tugged at my jaded heart. That is no small accomplishment, because my usual reading preference is dark-n-gritty tales.

There are some small details throughout the series that might have been done just a little better. Of these, the dialog is most noticeable, at least to this reviewer. At times, the conversations just didn't quite seem to fit in the traditional fantasy setting. However, this is easily overlooked, especially when these books are viewed as a whole, completed work.

The RIYRIA REVELATIONS doesn't suffer from the "middle books syndrome" that too many series do. Not only does Sullivan maintain the level of interest that he set in The Crown Conspiracy, but the story consistently gets better with each book, making Percepliquis everything that the end of an epic should be and more.
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This is supposed to be the Riyria's last mission: to put an end to the master assassin/spy Merrick Marius' assistance to the Imperialists. With no idea where to find him, Royce and Hadrian disguise themselves as sailors in order to board the Emerald Storm, which is the ship believed to be delivering a message to Merrick.

Mr. Sullivan has stepped up the action even more for his 4th book about Royce and Hadrian, the professional thieves known as the Riyria. As they sail the Emerald Storm, unknown enemies conspire against them. Raiders hound the ship's wake and their destination is the jungle islands just past the edge of civilized world, where warrior tribes and outlaw bands plot to ally themselves with the Imperialists. And, their goal now just within their grasp, Thrace, Princesses Arista and Amilia intensify their scheme to free the rebel leader Degan Gaunt.

So far, The Emerald Storm is my favorite book of the series. There are a few elements reminiscent of classic adventure literature, a who-done-it mystery, a pirate tale, and a thriller-type plot twist or two. I particularly enjoyed the warrior-tribe culture of the land of Calis.

As with all these books, parts might be just a little over-the-top, and there are few things, like the system of magic, that veteran fantasy-readers may find too simplistic, but that's the kind of story this series is. Mr. Sullivan is focusing on just having fun. The theme is in tune with the likes of The Three Musketeers or Pirates of the Caribbean. It's a series that could be considered more or less kid-friendly, but definitely not categorized as YA. When thought of in those terms, RIYRIA REVELATIONS is on its own out there in the fantasy genre, or, at least, the only story like it that stands out.

Review:
Let me first say this is an awesome idea especially for someone like me who has been around since the Sinclair Spectrum and had significant computers like the Commodore Amiga plus also probably owned just about every console ever made.  Sadly PC games need support nowadays, it is market under siege from the PS4, XBox One and Wii U.  This is because people love the flexibility of consoles.

So here we are and Alienware has made a bold market move - a PC console but also a full Windows 8 computer (if you add a mouse and keyboard).  First thing - installation - uh don't get me wrong, I have been around the block with install this and that so I am no slouch but this presented me with an issue which I still don't get.  Yes it hooked up fine, only power and HDMI so easy enough and even setting up wireless internet was fine.  Also setting up the Xbox controller was simple enough but note that the pairing button on the controller is the tiny button on the front left, so look at your instructions.

Now once everything started, again I was fine and all went well including saying I had an internet connection but then it decided there was an update.  This is where things went wrong, it said the update server was offline.  I didn't believe this, no way are Alienware not going to have the server working correctly.  Anyway I messed around forever and even accessed the Windows desktop ( hold alt-ctrl-del keys) and updated Windows but with the console mode the same thing kept happening.  Finally I connected a LAN and it worked.  I don't get why the wireless didn't work but eventually everything installed and set up OK.

Once it loaded up then it is very simple to use and very much like most modern day application type menus.  So load Steam, pick the game you want and download - simple and straightforward or just play ones you already have installed.  I would say the preference is controller games but it isn't a problem to play any game if you have a mouse and keyboard connected.  I downloaded one of my old classics called X-Com UFO Defense and it works perfectly and this is crazy on my Panasonic Plasma TV! It is one of those games that shouldn't be allowed to be played like this but fantastic that you can.  I have more modern games like Metro Last Light and this looks staggering and plays exceptionally well with the Xbox controller.  One thing I did notice is with some games, a reset is needed before you start another game so bear this in mind.  I am not sure this is an issue that can be sorted, I would imagine switching from one game to another is going to overuse the resources so I would get use to the idea that you might have to do this.

As far the the computer side of this, you get a fully functional Windows 8 computer so everything you can do with a normal computer.  So if you want to download Eve Online because you already have an account then yes you can do this and play it normally.

Now to the actual Hardware itself, this comes in various packages so you can chose to what level you want this as far as CPU etc.  For classic games this package is more than good enough and also for modern games and I would certainly recommend going for the highest spec if you really love your PC games and Steam.

Build quality looks to be excellent, they put a lot into a console size PC but it works well and doesn't overheat like your PS3 does.  It always looks awesome, bold block with blue neon lights (yes mine is blue and not red)  and that wonderful Alienware logo :)  The controller is XBox and for me it is the best one on the market so I am good on that.

Will this catch on?  I think it is a brilliant idea and if the quality of games can meet the quality of the console then I can see this in most households because you have the chance to play classics and also modern games and the PC catalog is HUGE.  I give it the big thumbs up, for a PC retro-maniac like me who also loves modern games like Fallout etc this is something I have been waiting to have since my Amiga days.  Only sad part is, it will kill the walk in a store and buy a boxed PC game but Gamestop etc pretty much sanctioned the end of this quite a while ago so it is something we have to accept.
Score:
5

Review:
I am a HUGE Anime and Video game fan and so when I saw the Dead Space anime I just had to get it, but I must admit it's not for everyone. Dead Space Aftermath crosses two paths, the path of those who love the first and second Dead Space video games and just crave more of the story, and the second if you like violent bloody anime.

Dead Space delivers 100% on both. If you don't like violence in your anime then DO NOT BUY IT and do not complain about it afterwords, it is Dead Space after all. Dead Space Aftermath is basically a "prequel" to the first video game. So if you're interested how the entire story began then you should definitely pick this up.

However, my one and only complaint is that I wasn't impressed with the quality of the anime, I felt it was cheaply made, it kept cutting in and out of sub par computer animation to decent quality pencil animation.

Other than that 4 out of 5 stars and long live the Dead Space Series!

Review:
As another reviewer's pointed out, in American Meth the author intersperses his own tragic story of losing virtually everything he had to his spouse's meth addiction with intermittent chapters addressing the  history of methamphetamine. I found the historical sections interesting - they were short, clear and to the point. But even though the author is reticent to the point of gentlemanliness about the details of the almost complete destruction of his life and family that came from his being unlucky enough to love a wife whose meth addiction came to blot out everything else in her life. However, the downward trajectory is clear, and we are able to fill in the blanks ourselves.

What I respected about this book is that the author didn't depend on sensationalism or lurid details, because, really, he doesn't need to. And it is precisely that kind of not-quite-but-almost objectivity which makes this account so chilling, and so real. The sense is that of hearing a witness account of seeing his house fit by a category F4 tornado. It's horrible, and it could happen to anyone.

When I finished the book I felt a terrible sense of loss. I would recommend this book. If you're unfamiliar with the subject of meth (not that I am; I'm not), it seems like a good place to start.

Review:
This book is the third story sequel:  I suggest to start with the Lion's Lady, then The Guardian Angel, The Gift and lastly, read Castles. The characters in all 4 books are friends/related to each other. It is more fitting if you know each character before reading the next book. If you read it in this order, I think it will bring more excitement as some questions are answered on the later book. Some secrets are also revealed beforehence.
The heroine, Sara, is not a whiner in my opinion.  When she was but a little girl, she  was described as awkward and clumsy, who fortunately, (or unfortunately, depending on the reader) has only outgrown that flaw just a little bit. However, in my opinion, her clumsiness are humorous and somewhat sweet. That made me enjoy this book even more. It is the spice of this book.  Since, she was married to Nathan as a child, growing up, she have already condition herself as a WIFE.  Even when she hasn't seen him for over 10 years, and even after her family insist on her that Nathan is an enemy, somehow, deep inside of her heart, She longed for love and acceptance from her long lost husband, especially since she didn't get such at home.  She kept waiting for him to finally come and collect her.  The collection part was also hilarious.  That's when the fun began...
The hero, Nathan, is so manly.  Too manly that he doesn't even know a single terms of endearment to call his wife.  He's never been in a serious relationship, therefore, know nothing above loving a woman.  The learning begins with both of them.  He decided he can control the situation, being married to Sara shouldn't be all that hard, afterall, he's always been a controlled, discipline man.  Or so he thought...
The patience of learning about one other...  The adjustment of each other's character, routine and lives... the acceptance and finally, the love...all made this book compelling.  Sara's determination to be accepted not only by her husband but by his staff on board was the funniest moments of all.  She means well, plans well.... but......  Aw~!  It does embarrass me reading about her parasols and her accidents.  I had to stop my reading, close my eyes and cover my face every incident.  After I gather myself together & get over my embarassment, i continue reading, praying she doesn't get into another "INCIDENT" again.  If I get to react this way about a book, I believe it is worth the buy and worth my time.

5

Review:
For me, this book is one of Julie Garwood's many best novels.  I have read more than 10 of her books yet each time, it's a new different adventure.  Yes, I agree that she sometimes described her herione pretty much with the same physical descriptions such as freckles in noses, smells like roses, etc...  However, I find this flaw rather inciting.
Madelyne's strength, courage, patience and love for others simply captivated me to read on.  Despite all the miserable times she had encountered during her growing up years, she still manages to keep her heart & spirit intact.  Even after all the beatings and living life without a mother and a father, she still counted and appreciated her one single blessing of having an uncle who loved her.  She doesn't dwell on the past, doesn't hold onto hate... and what's even more amazing is her unselfish side of wanting to help others find peace and happiness.  Duncan is a true warrior in every way.  He's honorable & patient. Practical & very disciplined...until love sinked in, and that's when practicality & disciplined became somewhat a burden.
The slow realization and acceptance of love between the two was simply perfect.  Each scenes, little gestures of passions made this book irrisistible.  There are many heart warming and humorous scenes in this book as well... The warming of Duncan's feet, the wedding, the learning of archery, the finding of the WOLF, the beginning of friendship with Duncan's sister, Adela & a whole lot more.  I could go on and on but I don't want to give it all away here for those who haven't read it yet. Oh, I must add that I find Madelyne's clumsiness entertaining. The secondary characters all contributed to make this book worth reading for as well.  Perhaps J.G. will write a sequel or a seperate book for Duncan's brothers and Adela's love story?  The family twist and complications added spice and thrill from front to end.  A must read & a keeper!

Review:
We gave this watch to our six-year-old girl once she had learned how to tell time.  For about two weeks, she would not take it off except at bath time (it is waterproof).  The wristband is easy to operate and has been dependable for us so far (we have had it for about a month); the band will loosen over time, so we do need to cinch it up occasionally.  The watch is attractive and keeps time accurately.  It ticks softly every second, which I think is a good way of learning about the passage of time.  There is a little flower that moves with the second hand -- very cute.  There are two rows of numbers around the watch -- one set of the 1 to 12 numbers and also an outer set of 5 to 60 (by fives).  This second set of numbers is what makes it so helpful for 'watch learners.'  I highly recommend it!

I admire his effort and really respect his background and survival story, but the reading here was tiresome, even endless, with no motivating points along the way either. Review:
I bought these chains because I had ordered a few necklaces recently and the chains never seem to be long enough or durable enough. I've become a big fan of Jstyle due to ordering a lot of their products recently, so when I needed a chain they were the first people I thought of.

Firstly, these chains are a great length for me personally. I also really like the design. They are 'chunky' enough to be durable but still slim enough to be worn my a female and still look delicate. I like the fact that the chain has the 'twisted' design, as its unique and pretty...but also because it rolls over my skin smoothly, and doesnt pinch or pull tiny hairs from my skin as many other chains eventually do.

Also, the material is high-quality. I break out very quickly if any jewelery contains nickle, and will usually break out within 2-4 days even if a piece of jewelry is coated but contains nickel on the inside. I have worn the silver chain for approx 3 weeks now, and am not breaking out at all, and obviously have no discoloration of my skin.

I also like the clasps, as they are well made and have not morphed or bent at all. I have a two year old son who has recently started grabbing my necklaces, pulling them close to his eyes, and exclaiming 'I like your necklace mommy!' because of this, I've had a few chains break from him pulling on them suddenly. I am glad to report that these are sturdy and have held up really well to both daily wearing and my son's enthusiasm for pulling on them!

All in all, I am still a fan of jstyle. These chains are obviously well made, and just go to show that their product quality is consistent. Great seller who specialize in great products!

Review:
Oh my goodness.  I was completely blown away after reading this book.  I think I'm still trying to pick my jaw up off the floor. I wasn't expecting what I read. I have never read anything by Jessica Prince before and now she will be an author that I will add to my reading list.  I was completely hooked from the very beginning to the very end.

After having to grow up at such a young age Marley is trying to make it own her own.  Her father was some random guy that she didn't know and well her mother was an addict.  She didn't care about anyone except for getting her next hit.  Finally at the age of 18 Marley escaped to set out and make a new life for herself.  She was going to college and had a job.  She wasn't looking to let anyone into her life. She only had two friends that she considered her family.  Then she met Gabriel Bertozzi.  She tried everything that she had in her to stay away from him.  He was demanding, cocky, sex on legs and he didn't let anyone stop him from getting what he wanted.

Gabriel is what we called the bad boy.  He has his secrets and his caring and tender side when it comes to Marley.  He would do anything in his power to protect her.  He had an instant attraction to Marley from the very first time he set eyes on her.  She wasn't the easiest person to catch.  She fought him as much as she could until she couldn't anymore.  He loved her feisty side.  He was very persistent and new just what buttons of hers to push.  Gabriel I found him to be a ladies man.  He could have his choice of any women he wanted.  He never let a women get to his heart.  He had walls put up after some past events in his life.

"So is the Italian stereotype true?  Are you hung like a horse?" - Carmen.  Carmen is Marley's best friend and I couldn't contain my laughter when it came to her.  Her witty comments just put a smile on my face.

This book is a cliffhanger and the Love Trilogy will be continued.

Review:
This stuff got rid of the crickets! Before turning to pesticides I had tried orange oil, horticulture vinegar, and cedarwood oil with no success. Then someone at the home improvement store recommended Triazicide, but that didn't work either.

I then tried the niban and it worked. After about 4-5 days, no more crickets.

The bottle says not to apply other pesticides along with it because the insects might not take the bait. For me it was too late as I had already applied the Triazicide. Maybe that's why it took a few days for the niban to work.

It comes in a big gallon (?) size bottle and I probably only used about a cup of it, if that. I wish I had bought a much smaller size (if available?).The directions say to put it out in a 2-foot wide swath, but I wanted to apply it in a much smaller strip around the foundation of the house. It has a shaker top and it was hard to apply in the smaller area that I wanted. It would be no problem to apply it in the 2-foot area they recommend. One of the areas I applied it was on a patio and I could see where it blew around and accumulated in places I didn't spread it (along the edges of the door mat, feet of the patio furniture, etc.) So be careful with pets and children and tracking it into the house if applying on hard surfaces.

Review:
In Lions of the Grail I found myself transported to a time and place I am not too familiar with, the history of Northern Ireland and the invasion of it by The Bruce Brothers.  It seems that most everyone in that region wanted to rule Ireland except maybe the Irish who were too busy clan fighting to resist the English under King John or the upstart Scottish King Robert the Bruce.  It is in this chaotic period that we meet our protagonist Syr Richard Savage, formerly of Ulster but who joined The Knights Templar as a personal quest to find meaning in life.  Unfortunately for Savage, the Templars are declared heretics and are condemned by The Pope so after being betrayed by a former Templar now turned Knight Hospitaller, he has been incarcerated for 5 years awaiting his fate.  Fortunately for Savage, King John(the son of Longshanks) has a pressing need for a former Ulsterman to spy out what is happening in Ireland regarding the Scots and the rumors of invasion.

The author has given us a tale with an intriguing cast of characters from the effeminate King John, the duplicitous Templar turned Hospitaller, The Bruce brothers Robert and Edward, a host of Scots, Irish, and Norman descendants, loyal mercenaries and witchcraft accused mother and daughter.  The story runs the gamut of human emotions, love, hatred, loyalty, loss and redemption, to name a few.  It also has The Grail and how it came to be in possession of Robert the Bruce and how he uses it to gain allies.  Given the many Grail stories and tales that are out there I found that the author gives a credible rendition though perhaps not as good a one as in the Monty Python movie.  :-)

All in all, Lions of the Grail is a fast paced, intriguing story full of twists and turns, full of villainous treachery, full of valor and courage.  A thoroughly enjoyable story.  I rate it at 4.5 stars.

4

Review:
Richard Savage is back.  The former Templar knight is now a farmer in France, that is until he is compelled to take on a mission back in Ireland.  An Ireland that is undergoing a power struggle between the Scots, who have taken control of the north under the command of Edward Bruce and who seek to subdue the whole island and the English.  However, they have a problem in Ulster as Castle Carrickfergus is somehow surviving a siege and a famine.

I was riveted to the pages as the author has produced a book at full throttle.  The action is relentless, the politics are insidious and the main characters, both the villains and the good guys and girls, are portrayed in a most entertaining fashion. Emotions run high, hardships are endured and intrepid resourcefulness are the order of the day as the story winds it way through a few surprising turns of events.  It is indeed a most enjoyable read and what's even better is that this isn't the end of Richard's involvement in the battles between the English King Edward and the Bruce brothers, Robert and Edward.  I am looking forward to the sequel.  5 stars.

Review:
A great book and a great adventure. Two techies, both rebounding from failed marriages, meet in California. Almost on a whim, at the prompting of aircraft designer Bert Rutan (Dick's brother), they start the project: to fly around the world without refueling. They start building the aircraft on a shoestring, on $100 donations and with Burt's and his company's help. They fight with each other. Dick fights with Burt. Somehow, they build the plane, test it, work through the many problems of a hand-made, one-off design. Dick comes to hate and fear the aircraft -- a barely-flyable, grossly-uncomfortable machine. They suffer through 4 1/2 days of flying 12,000 miles nonstop, in loops off the California coast.

On the strength of this record-breaking flight, they get more support, fix the problems, take off around the world in late 1986. Weather and airplane fight them the whole way. They fix the mechanicals as best they can and forge on, nonstop for just over 9 days and 26,366 miles aloft. They make a triumphant return to Edwards AFB just before Christmas, 1986.

Then they go on the road to raise the $400,000 or so they needed to pay off their debts. And write this book. Which I can't recommend too highly. Amazing aircraft, and story.

Happy reading--
Peter D. Tillman

Review:
Remarkable photos of Africa from the air, many from a motorized hang glider in remote areas. Minor downchecks for more photos of shantytowns than I cared to see, along with gratuitous social commentary. But Steinmetz is a great aerial photographer, and at his best, he's *wonderful*. Cool stories of his flying adventures too.

I didn't feel the Abrams product was quite up to their usual high standard, and I found the the wide, short book format awkward.  And it sure would have been helpful to put page numbers on the photo index thumbnails, in the back of the book. But these are minor nits for a remarkable piece of work.

My compliments to Seattle Goodwill for prompt shipment of a clean copy for $7 (including shipping).

Happy reading--
Peter D. Tillman

Review:
After reading the reviews, I was a tad skeptical and nervous about this product. I'd already purchased another one that did not fit and so I was worried about this one.  My Streamlight 75458 DS LED HL fit flawlessly in this holster. Yes, it is a tad bulky but so is my Streamlight, so what can you expect?

Other reviewers note a snap issue. Yes, it was a tad difficult to snap at first but it did snap with little effort. As far as unsnapping goes, unless the other reviewers were grabbing the very end of the flap and yanking it carelessly, I can't see how the snap would ever tear away from the flap. If you are firmly grabbing the flap at the snap, it comes right off with little effort. Either way, yes it is getting easier (if that were possible) with use.

Another thing to note in regard to the snug fit.... There is a small ridge or flap of fabric at the inner base of the holster that grabs the flashlight at it's base and does make it a bit difficult to pull out of the holster at times.  It also can interfere with inserting the flashlight completely into the holster. I've found that with use, that issue goes away as the holster loosens up.

All around great holster for this type of flashlight. A+

Review:
Escape Clause (Resort Romances #2) by Mary Billiter was a sweet, fun loving romance that had my all gushy on the inside.

The second book in the Resort Romances series, like the other books this can be read as a stand-alone. Moving on, this time we are taken to The Point Resort, were we meet Kelsey. Trying to start over, she is a devoted mother and worker. I loved her character and felt like she really stole the show, well as much as she could when her son wasn't trying to steel my heart. No, he totally stole it.

Oliver was alright, he had his good points but, other then being sweet and hot, there wasn't anything real special about him. I know this is a romance and as a couple Kelsey and Oliver had mad connections, I just feel like if Oliver wasn't in the picture, then the story would've still moved on, and still would've been great. Don't get me wrong Oliver as a whole was a well rounded character. He just didn't add that much, for me, to the story. Like say, he was a woman, overall outside of the smut, the story would have played out the same. Now I would like to point out that I did love them as a couple, and loved their interaction and growth. I just wish Oliver wasn't, so, boring. Again this is my personal opinion, so don't take it too much to heart.

Over all I did very much enjoyed this story. Like the other books in this series (I read all these out of order) the writing is outstanding, the plot is steady and has a clear goal. The tone had that light, funness to it, that kept you smiling and engaged. I had a hard time putting this book down. Take my high recommendation that you will fall hard for this sweet love story that starts in a lighthouse. ... Yes lighthouse. Curious?.. You're just going to have to read this book and see.

Happy Reading

-E.A. Walsh

Review:
pirited Away (Resort Romances #4) by Mary Billiter was an sweet, fun read that had me hooked from start to finish.

To start if you haven't read the other books in this series, no worries, each book is a stand alone, with some crossover characters(In saying that, you need to read the other books cause they are outstanding!). They kind of pop in quick, so you don't need to know their backgrounds. This is told in dual POV so you get to experience both Cody and Reese inner thoughts and struggles.

I have to say, I loved Reese. She was spicy, down to earth and funny as hell. I think we would make great friends. She's a fighter and a realist, but she was willing to open her mind to explore the whole Haunted Hotel rumour. She gave this book that extra something special.

Cody... oh boy, where can I can one? He was a little bit alpha, but not overbaring, he knew he couldn't go in guns-a-blazing with Reese. It was a slow burn situation, and it was worth the wait!

Overall this story is that perfect summer day read, with just the right mix of romance, mystery, danger and of course, hot, hot, smut. So take my high recommendation that you will not be able to put this gem down.

Happy Reading.

-E.A. Walsh

Review:
I have owned many different kinds of wine openers and I must say that I've always really liked the rabbit-style openers for their ease and consistency of use. The corks always come out with very little effort and never broken. This little set is a great for either a gift or a starter set for anyone who drinks wine at home. It comes with a foil cutter, which is much easier to use than the sharp end of a knife. There are 4 circular blades that clip against the bottle, so all you need to do is squeeze and turn. You will get a perfectly cut foil. Once the foil is removed you can snare the cork. Simply place the rabbit over the top of the bottle and lift the top handle up. You will squeeze the other silver handle and black part of the opener in your opposite hand to hold it onto the bottle. Then just press the lever down - the corkscrew will go into the cork - and then pull the lever back up - the cork will be removed from the bottle. To release the cork just do the exact same action without being attached to the bottle - the cork will fall off the screw as you pull the lever back up. From there yu can use one of the two re-cappers to cap off the bottle until you are ready to pour again. They even give you an extra screw in case you should ever need a replacement in the future. The set comes beautifully boxed so if you choose to give this as a gift, it will look and feel as elegant as it is. I've seen many similar products sell for much more in the department store, so the price point is really very good too in my opinion. I did receive this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

Review:
I had never owned an electric wine opener before and quite honestly until I tried this, I was completely satisfied using my tried and true waiter's corkscrew to my wine open bottles. However, it did not take long for me to become completely spoiled with the ease of use and speed of this opener. The opener will come with 4 rechargeable batteries (at least mine did even though the description says they are not included), which fit into the top of the unit. Just take the end cap off and look closely at the area where the batteries go and you will see the + and - signs for how to place the batteries before replacing the end cap. While I could use my opener right out of the box, it is recommended that you first charge the unit with the charging cord, that also comes with the wine opener. Simply plug the male end into the opener and plug into the wall. The red indicator light will let you know that the batteries are charging. To use this could not be more simple. There are two soft rubber buttons, one turn the corkscrew clockwise, the other counterclockwise. The advantage here is that once you place the opener over the bottle, hold down the button and remove the cork, you can then reverse the direction to discharge the cork into your hand. There is no twisting, pulling or clever wrist action needed to use this. If you can press a button, you can open a bottle of wine, which will be wonderful for anyone with painful hands or hands with limited movement abilities. You will also receive a replacement screw in case you should ever need it. To date, we've had no broken corks and the unit has never jammed. I also like that the screw is always completely enclosed in the plexiglass surrounding it so that nothing can get tangled in it during use. It also helps protect the sharp tip. My guess is that after you try this wine opener, the rest of the ones you own will all sit in a drawer. I did receive this product at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

Review:
What would you do if your school was mysteriously transported from Earth to an unknown planet? That is what the students of suburban Milwaukee high school must find out in The Woods.

There are a few different groups that form in the aftermath of the sudden move. One goes out to explore the world around them, while the others try to create a semblance of order within the school building. This split drives the plot of the book, with the story jumping back and forth between these two sides.

Some of what happens implies that there is a deeper story about why this school was chosen, if indeed it was. The character personalities felt distinguishable from one another, though they were somewhat shallow at times. The book is a little shorter than most and could have used the extra space to develop these out a bit more. For what is in the book, I think the characters are done well. I look forward to seeing what happens with them.

One thing that kind of bugged me is how quickly things turn sour. It is literally within a day that a tyrannical regime tries to take control of the school. Again, space may have helped here. A slower development to that, even over the course of a couple days, would have seemed more believable. The characters seem to ignore some of the things that happen on an emotional level. I could see the alien environment having an effect on them, but it should be stated more clearly.

I feel like I am bashing on the book a bit, but it is quite good. It sucked me in quickly and had me rooting for certain characters. And the art is great. The strange landscapes and creatures have just enough basis on things from our own world to give the reader a reference point. From there, the creators have some fun letting their imaginations go wild on what might populate this world.

The book may appeal more to high school age students because they would more easily identify with the characters. However, it should appeal to a wider audience.
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Disclaimer: I received a free ecopy via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

Well that was a blast. Joyride is a seriously fun, action packed space adventure. Earth made contact with alien races and is now ruled by a dictatorship that restricts anyone from leaving the planet. With this premise, the book could have gone really dark and turned into a dystopian story. Instead, everything about it is bright and energetic. There are conflicts to keep things interesting though.

I love the characters. From the rebellious Uma to the hitchhiker Kolstak. Every one of them adds personality to the book. There is enough variety to keep me engaged and prevent things from becoming flat. The development of the characters individually and as a whole over the course of the story is great too. Despite some differences, it sort of makes sense that they would keep travelling together.

But the stand out portion of this book is the art. I really like the style for the characters. Most of them are little more than kids and the art captures that. Their expressions are detailed and support the text. The colors do a lot to create the tone of the book. I think the panel work is awesome too. They do a lot to draw the eye down the page, so even if they are used in an unusual way I didn't feel confused as to where I should be looking or reading next. Then there are the scenes that juxtapose two characters. These go a long way to show how the characters are similar and different without spelling things out. I liked this one so much I went out and bought a physical copy. Can't wait to read volume 2!

Review:
*I received an ecopy of this book from the author. This has not influenced my review.*

The book was very gritty, grungy, and dirty (literally dirty, like with dirt and sweat and other bodily fluids). The main character lived in the slums. The book was filled with drug addiction and lots of mentions of prostitution and rape (though no explicit sceneswell, except one scene in which Andi and some others were touched without consent). There were graphic descriptions of various sorts of disgusting things, including injuries and dead bodies. Every other word in Andis head or out of her mouth was some sort of guttermouth slang. So basically, it is not a book for the easily offended or weak-stomached.

Speaking of Andis voice though, it was very different from the usual that you find in books, which was refreshing. It was full of slang and completely colored by her life and situation. I cant really explain it, but I recommend reading a preview of the book on Amazon (or somewhere) to get a feel for it if you're unsure about whether youll like it or not. (Reading a preview will also show you how gritty the book is.)

There was also a great message in this book not just about being intersex but about being who you are and letting people be who they are. The main characters didn't want to be assigned a binary gender, they were happy just being themselves with the bodies they were given, and all they wanted was to be given the option to keep those bodies.

The plot/pacing was where I think the book lost me though. I didn't understand/believe/see the point of some things (for example, I felt like there was no way Andi wouldnt have died of infection after everything her body went through), and I just wasn't gripped. Also, the timeline for how their society came to be the way it was didn't make sense, unless I just misunderstood (which is possible because I was confused). And to be honest, I think the language and Andis voice got to be a little bit too much for me after a while.

However, overall, it had a somewhat unique premise, it included representation of a part of the LGBTQIA+ community that you don't see often in books, and the writing had a deep POV with a unique voice.

Rating: 3 Stars

Review:
Amy Clipston has become another new favorite author of mine.  She  writes a clear, flowing story with concise characters and the Plain people become a live in A Place of Peace.
Sometimes we all need A Place of Peace to retreat to. Miriam Lapp is called home to a mourning family as she heads back home after her beloved mother's death.  But Miriam has been gone a long time . . . three years to be exact.  Three years of change in her, three years of change in him and three years of change in the community.  Can all the change be good?
Home again in the small cabin of her sister's abode she prepares for the evening when she hears a horse and buggy come to the cabin and it parks near her honda.  It's not Zach as she expects  it's . . . Timothy Kauffman!  Oh, the agony!  Oh, the joy!  "She stared into his eyes, and the time they had spent together flashed before her like a movie. All of the love she'd felt for him in the past boiled up in her soul, and she wanted to reach out and hug him.
Instead, she stood still and held his gaze as his blue eyes studied hers.
"We were fed lies," he whispered, his gaze so intense that her breath paused.
Speechless, she nodded."
Sometimes circumstances aren't as we see them.  Sometimes people think they have a better plan for a our lives and mistakes happen.  Such is the case in Miriam and Timothy's lives.  The misunderstandings and the judgments that came between Miriam and Timothy will make your heart break for them.  Can they get past the misunderstandings and forge ahead to a new path in their lives?  Not such an easy path but a 5 star story for the reader who loves Amish fiction!  There are also wonderful gut recipes included in this read.
I've read A Gift of Grace so I dove into A Place of Peace but somehow left out the second book A Promise of Hope.  This is the Amish Bakery Series and A Place of Peace is the third book.  In my opinion one can read these as stand alone books but it would be better to read them in order.

Review: A sometimes ponderous tale of the first Commanche, an offshoot of the more northerly based Shoshone people, this book recounts the birth and adventures of the war chief who would one day lead his people to a better way of life by discovering the advantages of horsemanship on the open plains ahead of other Indian groups and tribes. The young warrior, Horseback, grows to manhood in the shadow of the mythic story of his birth, heralded by a horse who circled the birthing lodge at the moment of his emergence into the world. His early youth a constant struggle in the harsh terrain to which his people have long ago been banished by their enemies, including the Utes (Yutas in this book) and Apache (Nah-vonuh), Horseback through a series of spirit visions sees a better future for his people and embarks on a quest south to find more ponies and learn about the lands and peoples that lie beyond the range of the "True Humans" or Noomah as Horseback's people call themselves. Named Komantcia (or Our Enemies) by the Yutas, they soon become "Comanche" to the Spanish who, typically, decide to betray and enslave Horseback while he is paying them a visit. The young warrior soon learns to culivate a new hatred as he faces Spanish perfidy and cruelty while continuing to grow his renegade Shoshone bands into a new Comanche nation and rekindle an ancient blood feud with the Apache. There's a lot of spirit stuff here and we even get a horse's eye view of the world for a couple of chapters. The book, overall, is chock full of good information about the Plains tribes and the era of the early 1700's when these peoples were formed into the tribes America would ultimately remember from its Western expansion in the mid to late 1800's. But the story itself is uneven in parts, frequently slows down and, in the end, does not achieve much more than the traditional image of the noble Plains Indian that has become a part of the enduring American mythos. It was an enjoyable tale but the narrative wasn't overly tight and the characterizations were fairly routine, from the hypocritical and sadistic Spanish friar, to the noble and ignoble frontiersmen, to the shortsighted, arrogant Spanish military leaders, to the spiritual Indian warriors, etc., etc. Still I liked the book enough to finish it and would recommend it to anyone interested in the beginnings of the Comanche nation and the early days of European contact with native Americans west of the Mississippi. Stuart W. Mirsky author of The King of Vinland's Saga Score: 3 With the given examples, give a score between [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] to the following review by the same user. Only output the score and nothing else.

Review: A very fine narrative concerning the history (both the rise and fall) of the Native American people known today as the Comanche (from a Ute word meaning those who like to fight or who fight a lot). An unsophisticated group of stone age hunter-gatherers who had eked out a living on the edges of better territory dominated by larger and more formidable Native American peoples than themselves, the Comanche eventually discovered the horse, left to run wild and multiply in North America after the Spanish had retreated south in the face of rebellions against them. The Comanche soon realized that horses were good for more than just eating or dragging tent poles behind them when the bands moved camp and became the most effective mounted warriors in North America and, Gwynne suggests, maybe in the world. A small, stocky people well suited for riding, they rapidly came to dominate the central and southern plains of North America, placing them directly in the path of the expanding American Republic as it moved westward via new settler migration and war with Mexico over the western territories held by that country. Gwynne intersperses his tale of the rise of the Comanche and their fierce war with other Indian tribal nations (including Apaches and Tonkawas, both of whom would develop an undying hatred of their foes and align themselves with the incoming whites to eventually bring the Comanche down) with an account of the background, birth and rise of Quanah Parker, the half white war chief of the Comanche nation who would lead them in their final struggle with white civilization. In the interim, the Republic of Texas broke away from Mexico to become the Comanche's most dangerous enemy. But not at first. Initially, the early Texans were outclassed because they were used to the forests and mountains of their eastern homes. Armed only with the slow-to-reload muzzle loading rifles of the era (which required plenty of cover between shots and could not be easily reloaded on horseback), they could neither outshoot nor outride the wild Comanche warriors in a country where cover was scarce and often non-existent. It took a series of disastrous defeats before the Texans slowly got it together and learned to fight with the relentless ferocity of the Comanche from horseback, mastering the trails and redoubts of the country itself in the process. Nor did it hurt when the advent of the revolver in the mid 1840's gave the newly formed, and still green, Texas Rangers a marked advantage over the mounted Comanche warrior equipped only with bow and arrow. The book recounts the gradual erosion of Comanche dominance as it gives the history of Quanah's mother, Cynthia Ann Parker, captured as a nine year old girl and adopted by members of the Comanche band that took her. Eventually married to a Comanche warrior, she is finally retrieved by whites only to pine away until her early death because of her lost husband and sons. Quanah, her eldest, is left to fend for himself at the age of twelve and eventually grows into a large and powerful warrior in his own right, the man who will lead the last free band of Comanches until he is finally run to ground and beaten by the U.S. Army -- having at last learned to fight Indians the Indian way. This is a fine book that deals with an important part of Texas history as well as the history of America's western plains overall. Importantly, it offers a comprehensive and vivid picture of the Comanche nation from its first appearance as a competitor for the resources of the Great Plains until its final defeat in the late 1800's. A very valuable addition to any library of the west. Stuart W. Mirsky author of The King of Vinland's Saga Score:

Review:
That statement might make fans pretty mad, but from what I've heard from Tyr and their previous 4 albums (Asgard, Eric the Red, Ragnarok, and Land) , this is the first one that seems to finally be giving metal fans what they really want to hear, and that is creative guitar-driven heavy metal. Or at least, getting more creative WITH their guitars and finally balancing them with their vocals.
Northern Star, to the metal veteran might just seem like your typical fare of Viking-themed music with really great vocal work. The lead vocalist in this band, if you haven't heard him yet, is one of the best vocalists in all of metal if you ask me. Not necessarily because he can hit great highs and lows (hence he's not a classically trained singer, because he actually never attempts to hit epic highs or gutteral lows and doesn't seem to have the ability to anyway), but because he's been gifted with a naturally powerful and melodic vocal tone, which translates well into singing for a metal band... although to be honest, he would fail at singing for any other genre of music, but might make a good career of doing voice-overs for books and such. Listen to some clips to see what I'm talking about. Anyway, the metal veteran with taste in melodic metal bands will see and hear the originality in a Viking metal band that decided they will not use harsh growling or death/screeching vocals. This is NOT Viking black metal, this is NOT Viking death metal, not even close; this is epic pulse-pounding Viking metal. This band doesn't mess with those other sub-genres because it wouldn't fit with the mountainous, cloudy skies and epic journeying atmosphere this band wants to create. This music isn't dark music at all, nor is it angry, it's actually very leaned towards heroism, bravery, victory and celebration.

What disappointed me about Tyr in previous albums is the, to put it bluntly, sheer BOREDOM I found in their songs; simply mediocre and lazy songwriting. All they seemed concerned about was their vocalist - he sounded great, so any sort of creativity with guitar work and atmosphere was put to the back seat. Sections dragged on, riffs were plain and flat, solos were just filler, choruses were unimaginative, lyrics were unintelligible, contrived and overly historical and metaphorical... I seriously have no idea why they still remained as popular as they did. Just name me ONE memorable hit Tyr has had in their past career... unlike other bands like Blind Guardian who wrote 'The Bard's Song' and Ensiferum's 'From Afar' and 'Old Man,' there is nothing that Tyr has written to banner themselves as a band that can contend with the greats. I don't mean to sound like their old music was absolutely unbearable, there were a FEW good songs (although even the good ones still dragged on in sections and were still overwrought with some of the same habits).

But that was former Tyr, now this album represents what I see as Tyr taking a new direction. I think they finally realized that they cannot leach off the melodic vocal tone of their singer anymore, and decided to finally write REAL guitar music that could contend and be well balanced with their lead singer, and in this album, unlike the other ones, has guitar music that will keep you just as interested in the music as the vocal work. Listen to it a few times, and the songs become more and more charming and addictive, it just takes a while, but this album does grow on you.
Lyrically the band even seems to be taking a new direction. Things are more comprehensive now, things flow better and are well paced. Some fans may think that the lyrical content was 'dumbed down' significantly from Tyr's historically intellectual roots, and maybe they have been, but if you're going to water down the lyrics and song themes to create better MUSIC, I'm all for it.
Most songs on this album follow a more direct flow of verse/chorus/verse/chorus, and that isn't always bad if a band is experimenting with a new direction; some bands work better with this formula and some bands are competent and talented enough to go beyond it. It's not a bad thing, as there are some bands who go the extra mile whose music is just simply worse than those who have more of a knack for a verse/chorus/verse/chorus formula, and vice versa - it's all a matter of personal ability. Creativity beats out technical chops any day. I don't care how many guitar notes you can hit in a second, if it's a boring lick or solo, I'm not interested. Perhaps Tyr can soon stretch their music to the former progressive attempts they used to make and actually write BETTER songs with it, but right now it seems they've decided to let go of those progressive stretches, and I say more power to them! This is their best album to date, and for any new fans I'd definitely recommend this one to pick up first.

As much as I hate to say it, Tyr is a band who has the image of musical prowess, but their past work has (to me at least) proven otherwise, and while it sucks for a band to have taken so many attempts to finally create a good and balanced album, this band is finally doing so. I am excited to hear new things from Tyr, as I feel this is a very good album and that there is simply not enough of it (it's actually rather short). I hope that for future albums they take this new appreciation for songwriting and try to advance it. Take Turisas and Ensiferum as examples if you have to, just keep putting out albums people can actually relate to!
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Let me start off this mostly negative review by saying that I do think Tyr is a very talented band... TECHNICALLY speaking, as they seem to have all the pieces down that would make up a great Viking metal band - Fantastic vocalist (honestly one of the very best I've ever heard), great production, full on bass, intense drumming, great guitar chops, great potential in their musical atmospheric techniques. The problem here, and what I've noticed in EVERY album from this band besides the latest, 'Northern Star,' is that the pieces simply aren't put together well or used to their fullest potential to make a memorable album. I honestly don't know what all these other reviewers are listening to, but if you're trying to convince me that this is one of the greatest metal albums ever created, I simply have to laugh at you, you most likely have no other metal albums in your entire collection.

I won't break down each song one by one, but on the whole this album mostly bored the life out of me, although I was able to see what kind of atmosphere the band was going for, the songs in the end just weren't very GOOD. I think the reason most people tend to fall in love with this band so quickly is because of the vocals - the guy's gifted with a very soothing natural voice, and when he puts it in song it has a very VERY epic and "viking" feel; this only is emphasized in the sections when the band sings together in unison for certain parts. The second track on the album is sung in their native tongue (a dialect of Norwegian) and the vocals in the song are produced to stand out, and if they were just sung with no instruments it might work, but the thing with heavy metal music is that you NEED some good guitar work to stand behind the vocals. ....the guitar work here (riffs and licks) is so overly simplified and sounds as if they just made it up as they went along, and just wanting everyone to hear their vocals more than anything else, the guitars really just taking a back seat.

There are 2 songs on this album that I decided to keep on my Ipod, because while they aren't masterpieces, they do have some pretty good choruses (which honestly feels more like luck than anything else). Still, even within these 2 songs the choruses are too few and far between, and mostly surrounded by more substandard guitar work (in the realm of creativity at least); I wish they would've just listened to these songs more and trimmed the fat off of them.

A masterpiece?? I don't think so, not even close. This is one of those albums that gets by on the band's image, cover art, lyrical themes, and bare bones vocal work (if this band had a different vocalist, I seriously think EVERYONE would hate this album)... but when it comes down to actual creative and engrossing songwriting, this album drags lazily and never makes any attempt to pick up the pace. If you're into bands like Ensiferum, Wintersun, Blind Guardian, or other melodic metal or viking metal bands, this album will do nothing for you. If you're curious to get into Tyr, I would strongly suggest only picking up their latest album - By The Light Of the Northern Star, which finally feels like the first album where the band finally decided to take more time into making good guitar-driven songs (it only took them 4 albums to finally get it somewhat right).

What could be hotter than a werewolf cowboy? In Krystal Shannan's third book To Win a Mate from the VonBrandt Family series Jared finds Elise.
Jared was asked to represent the VonBrandt Company at a charity fundraiser auction. He is suppose to be there to purchase a painting for his pack alpha's wife Tonya. The next item up for bid after the painting is a date with a woman. Jared had no intention of bidding on a date until Elise Blanchard walks on stage. To his complete surprise her scent calls to him.
Elise has a secret...she's a werewolf. She doesn't know if she is the only one though. She hasn't ever met another one. She has hidden away from everyone for years on the night of the full moon. She moves every couple of years to keep her secret.
Jared can scent Elise's wolf. He is determined to win the date with her no matter what it cost him.
Jared and Elise have a lot to share. Secrets, explanations, passion, lust, love and maybe a future.
Krystal Shannan does a wonderful job progressing her character dynamics in such a short novella. You connect with each character quickly. The passion quickly turns to love but it didn't feel rushed since they are actually wolves that mate quickly and for life.
I hope there are more stories to come out of the VonBrandt ranch...after all according to Jared there are 10 to 15 people/wolves that live at the ranch regularly. I would love to read Aaron and Tonya's story. I received an ARC of this book for giving my honest review.

Review:
I love books about Homesteading. This book is about the Brides who agreed to follow and support their menfolk in unchartered territory. To think what people did years ago with hope of a better future. They would travel far away, to the unknown, to seek a better lives for themselves and their family in hopes of  building a strong foundation for future generations.  They left most of their relatives at home. They took very little as far as money and possesions. Mail traveled so slow that they knew they would be cut off from news at home. Would they ever see their parents or siblings again? Things from their homes they left were of little use on the prairie. During the cold harshest winters they knew they would be trapped for months in a sod house just trying to survive without freezing or starving. There closest neighbors were miles away. They had very little to eat for years while trying to get crops to grow in the harsh soil. Mostly their fuel was cow patties they hardened and dried in the summer, because there weren't any trees for wood. Sometimes the harsh weather or other things like tornados would ruin their crops. They got free land in exchange for living on it for several years. They were very sturdy determined people who wanted to carve out a future, and they overcame so many obstacles to succeed. The stories were written by several different author's. Each of the stories were really interesting and I learned things I didn't kniw. I stayed up two nights and read all day to see what the next story was about. I highly recommend this book.  I was given a copy of this book by Darlene Franklin in exchange for an honest review. These stories will touch your heart, and make you thankful for all the advantages we have today , while enjoying stories from long ago.

I set it on 5 to begin with, and the toast was really crunchy, which I liked, but I tried it the next time on 4.5 just to check it out. It was all right, but I'm going to set it back to 5. I like the snowflake icon for frozen food items; the circle with a slash means cancel, btw. Be sure to remove the cardboard piece under the control, peel off the two pieces of tape on top, and you'll have to cut off the plastic tie on the cord plug. (Cute scissors icon there.)
