Review:
Game Of The Year.. IT'S on the COVER for goodness sakes!!

Coming from a seasoned hardcore gamer, this game has left nothing behind.  Both the single player and muliplayer aspects of this game are nothing short of astounding.

Just when I thought gameplay just couldn't get any better for a FPS, this game came out and just blew everything I knew about FPS out of the water.
Everything down to the intuitive button configurations and ability to modify button configurations is just fantastic.

The story line is phenominal and totally realistic. The physics are barnone the best I have ever seen/experienced. The weapons are as real as they come, and the multiplayer environment is fast paced and well thought out.

Introduction to class creation, weapon customization, ranking and xp points unlocking various weapons, and challenge bonuses just make the replayability of this game endless.  Sure a few of these just mentioned have existed before in other games, however I don't think that they have all been combined and interweaved so beautifully.  Also, when you get to rank 55, you get to make a tough choice.. I won't spoil it for you, you will find out when you get there.

The graphics are some of the best I have ever seen in a game, and is up there on par with Metal Gear Solid 4, Uncharted: Drakes Fortune, and Gran Turismo 5 Prologe.

Going back to the storyline, in the single player mode seeing the nuke's being launched and a nuke being detonated gave me goose bumps and brought a tear to my eye.  Bringing back memories of what all our forebearers gave their lives so selflessly to protect us from such evil.. just phenominal.

AHH Yes you knew it was coming... the CONS or downsides of the game.
1. OPEN MICS!! Sounds like a GREAT idea right? Well not so much.  You have people playing that have a fan blowing on them, or aspiring to be a future rap star, or music in the background, or kids crying in the background, or parents yelling at their kids.. well you get the idea.(Just.. should have integrated a button to activate mic channel) To be fair, you can selectively mute people, but you shouldn't have to do so to begin with.
2. The lack of a server based online environment like Socom 3 has. Which makes it more difficult to locate friends if they are already in a game.
Yes you can invite a freind into the game, or have a "party" before launching the auto find game feature.  But a friend saying "Yea, I'm in US Central 5 Server, Game Name is Yo Momma" system I think is better suited for online gaming.  Perhaps having both features would be more helpful than just one or the other.
3. The complete meaninglessness of clan tags, anyone can dupe your clan tag without being invited to the clan.  In Socom, you sent out invites to clans, in this game you just type it in without any control of the clan.
4. Seperate map pack.. now comon, I just spent 60 bucks on this game and you want to double dip another $10 out of me for 3 more maps?  Get real guys, just include the maps to begin with please. To this day I have not purchased the map pack and don't really wish for more levels to begin with.
5. The knack of you being able to spot someone 200 yards away with the naked eye and pick them off seems a little unrealistic.  But I think this gets caulked up to HD graphics/HD Tv's to be honest with you.  We for so many years have been squinting at that dern TV saying.. honey come here, is that a guy in the bushes? So that when we can finally SEE what we are doing it just becomes unnatural feeling somehow.

Overall the cons do not outweigh the benefits by a long shot, and do yourself a favor and get this GAME!!  You will have a hard time putting down the controller, I guarantee it!!

4

Review:
This is not a great book; it is an INCREDIBLE book. Although, it is geared predominantly toward outlining the soft skills necessary for becoming a successful and influential project manager, these skills are applicable to anyone in any job or in everyday life. I believe anyone can achieve success with these methods.

Project managers operate without any formal authority, so they use informal power by influencing team members and other stakeholders. There are many traits that enable a project manager to gain influence over time such as by being authentic (say what you mean) and acting with integrity (do what you say). Trust is of utmost importance and that has to be earned. Mentoring is another level of influence and so is the act of influencing others who then become a positive influence for someone else (this type of influence has a multiplying effect).

This book is 179 pages of easy reading written in a conversational style that guides the reader on how to gain the power of influence.  This advice can be applied to other professions as well. For example, in the develop commitment chapter, the author says "Persuasion encourages someone to do something once.  Influence is about encouraging them to keep on doing something and to keep on supporting you." In that chapter he describes how that is done in several ways. The hook is one way to start influencing someone we never met. He goes on to describe three hooks that work for him.  When I was reading his example, it brought to mind the hook I used about 12 years ago when I was trying to raise $1,900 for a 60-mile breast cancer walk.  I thought this was impossible at the time but I made a pact with myself that since this would be the only time I would ever raise a large sum of money I would give it my all.  With this in mind, I decided to contact every acquaintance I knew and some I did not know.  I wrote each one a brief email that established a personal connection with them by reminding them how we knew each other or how I came upon their name. Then I told them my goal and asked for a donation. I figured most people would ignore a bulk email but not an individual one and I was right. In the end, 91 people donated a total of $5,470 to sponsor me which does not include the $550 in donations made by 2 other acquaintances who donated to a different breast cancer organization in my name. In total I was able to raise $6,020. It was the hook I used that allowed me to influence most of the people I wrote including several who I never met and who never met me.  When the walk was done, I sent a handwritten card and a story I wrote about the event to thank each of the 91 sponsors. I even attached a picture of me in those cards I sent to the people who I never met so that they would see who they had supported. The hook got them listening and the thank you helped them remember and established a rapport.  Hooks are used by sales representatives as an influencing tactic and this example can be seen as selling someone on a cause.

On another note, there are brief scoring exercises at the end of each chapter that I used to rate my influencing skills.  A couple of exercises I found confusing. For example, in the active listening chapter it is unclear to me how I was supposed to use my scores because the author mentions they had to be broken down into five dimensions, yet the questions were not broken down by those dimensions.

I do think this book is way overpriced at the current price of $38.84 even though the advice is excellent. Personally, I would not pay more than $23 for this small text.  Nevertheless, this book will help most people understand and acquire the soft skills necessary for becoming a successful project manager or successful "anybody." I found it to be an incredible read with outstanding and sensible advice.

5

Review:
Stacking The Deck is written in a conversational tone unlike some managerial change books that are full of exercises and charts.  In part one of the book, the author describes the nine steps toward achieving favorable change.  These stages include developing a sense of urgency, unifying the team, communicating a clear vision, etc.  Part two of the book focuses in the broad sense on how to lead this change which is mostly about effective communication and good planning.

There are some gems of wisdom in this text.  For instance, as part of step 8 (which is assessing, recruiting, and empowering the broader team), the author makes it clear why you might hire someone who failed on a project. The reason is that those who failed and learned from their mistakes may offer priceless insight.

In the communicating and connecting to inspire chapter he makes it clear that it is not about what you say; its about what they hear.  You may think your message inspires and motivates, but if your team has not heard it that way, you have not succeeded.

Two more quotes that I found inspiring were:

1)  We earn the right to communicate electronically by the time and energy we invest in communicating personally.

2) Electronic communication is a tool for communicating informationnot for inspiring passion.

In combination with the excellent advice, I would have liked examples with more substance, however.  For instance, he told how Howard Schultz (Starbucks CEO) inspired his staff everywhere by penning a weekly Transformational Agenda that he released on Mondays.  I would have liked a sample agenda in the book that dissected why and how this worked.  In another example, the author himself mentioned that he was questioned by an employee in a town hall meeting about how he and other executives received multi-million dollar bonuses and wanted to know how this equates with the culture of economy and expense control he was espousing.  The author mentioned how he publicly congratulated the employee for asking such a difficult question but never said how he answered it or why his answer worked and was inspiring.

Overall, I feel this is a great book from which current and aspiring managers can gain some insight on how to lead change and inspire others. For me, I would have to read this more than once to make the concepts my own as it is chock full of good advice.

Review:
Vera wants the experience of a lifetime, so she decides to go to Spain and spend a month teaching conversational English to business men and woman; this way she can forgo spending a summer interning for her major (astronomy). She will get to meet new people have fun all while getting free room and board on a beautiful remote resort. She never expected to meet HIM and fall in love.

Mateo a retired football/soccer star turned business man is captivated by Vera and her free spirit. She is unlike any woman he has ever known. As their time together and sessions go on they grow close and something changes between the two. Feelings get in the way and soon everything Vera thought she wouldn't become she turns into (the other woman).
Vera:"You're married!" I yelled. "I cannot be the other woman!"
Matteo: "You already are the other woman!" he yelled right back.

Guilt consumes her but she can't stay away. She knows this can't go on but she's never felt more alive.
Vera: "I stared at the ring on his finger. I thought about what it meant. Then I thought about what he meant to me."

I'm not spoiling anything because it tells you in the blurb what is going to happen and YES it has cheating! I hate cheating (probably the reason I couldn't give it the full 5 stars) but somehow the author made it work in this book. First, you didn't get to know the wife, in so many books it's a love triangle where you like all the characters and it just becomes frustrating. Second, Matteo was unhappy and truly in love with Vera, he made bad choices but acted in the moment. Third, she felt so much guilt the whole time. I liked both the H/h and I love when that happens in a book. Matteo did piss me off in a certain chapter towards the end of the book and I won't say anything about that because it could be slightly spoilerish but he definitely had me thinking twice about him. Another great thing about this book was Vera's younger brother Josh (which I'm hoping to get a book about). He was so supportive of Vera and her choices.
Josh: "I don't think it can be wrong if it comes from a pure place. I suppose you could be like one of those chicks who just keeps it all inside and secretly pine for someone for their whole life until it kills them. But your not. What you feel isn't wrong, Vera...it's not black and white like that." Another insightful Josh quote.
Josh: "You just fell in love with each other at a very messy time. It's life. It happens. Matteo never set out to fall in love, to hurt his wife..." I'm not wring the rest of this quote because it could be a spoiler. I really thought the age difference would bother me too, but it didn't. Karina Halle just made the whole thing work, cheating, age, and distance. I'm so happy I gave this book a chance.

Review:
The prologue of this book had my mouth hanging open and wanting to know what was going to happen. Rachel has a way of doing that to her readers. Her prologues get you every time.
If the island was an organ, it would be my heart. Isolated, lost and misunderstood.
I took my time with this one; talk about a slow burn, the buildup to this book is insane. You see this relationship go from banter, friendship, romance, steam, angst, and love. It happens slowly and keeps you turning the pages to find out whats to become of these two unique individuals.
As they learn more and more about each other they form an intense bond. Tahoe our hero has relocated to a small town in Florida and all his sights are set on one thing and that one thing didn't include the heroine. It did include her and her fathers airport, but in the process of trying to convince Caroline (heroine) to use it, his heart has other plans. Once Tahoe has committed to something he isn't going to give up, (whether it is the girl or the airport). This is where the slow build to the story happens.
Heartbreak tells you the love was real. You cant be afraid of the end at the beginning. Go full throttle and see what happens.
Tahoe has had his own heartbreak and has had a hard time moving on from it. Caroline never thought shed find love in her small town and never wanted to give herself to anyone until she starts dating Tahoe.
You get this feeling when you want to keep something. Its scary and vulnerable. It makes you feel like your skin is flipped inside out. It changes everything. Keeping that quality, keeping it, has to be protected at all costs. You become obsessed with keeping that which you cant sacrifice.
The both start falling hard and it scares them but as I said earlier, Tahoe is committed, but he is also obsessed with perfection.
Her world is already open. Im excited to show her another piece of it.
This is a sweet story of two people that find each other at the right time.
This is a favorite quote of mine between the two characters; it is simple but so clever and really made me feel.
Im falling for you, Caroline May.
Im flying for you, Tahoe Holiday.
Im going to lie and say Tahoe didn't piss me off, he definitely screws up and Caroline is a tough girl and held her ground with him, I loved that.
One thing I found that I really enjoyed about this book was its not the typical virgin romance and youll understand that once you read it.

Review:
I'm not sure that author, Rebecca Simmons would classify Nobody's Business as Christian Fiction, but I must say that the book really ministered to me.  While the books primary focus is on relationships, the inclusion of Godly principles brought out a great message and worked wonderfully in the plot.  We all struggle from time to time with ourselves and the main theme present in this book is to love yourself first and foremost.  When we learn to look after ourselves, we're a better help and comfort to others.  As a first novel, Ms. Simmons' book has left a lasting impression on me and I see potential for greater works incorporating the same themes.
Clara works as a psychologist at a women's crisis shelter.  She is involved in a relationship with Jason, who loves her dearly and has asked her to marry him.  She has refused, even though she loves him, because she has decided that she never wants to marry or have children.  This understandably causes a rift in their relationship but they struggle to hang on.  The stress of Clara's job and non-addressed issues of her past threaten to destroy Clara as well as her relationship with Jason.  She's taken to drinking to drown painful memories and actions. She feels that her work at the shelter isn't effective, that she's not reaching her clients.  Her mother is an alcoholic and her older sister has coupled booze with drugs to bury the painful sting of her past.  On the outside Clara is listening and providing counsel to people who need to talk about their problems, while on the inside she is need of counsel.  As her world spirals downward she decides to seek help for herself.  Enters Justine, Clara's counselor.  Justine is laid back, casual and very open to discussing things at Clara's pace.  The only requirement is that God be central to any advice given.  The bible is the instruction manual by which the counseling center operates and Justine prays for and with each of her clients.
The plot thickens. Clara teeters on the edge of sanity when her mother is hospitalized near death, her sister is out of control, an old flame comes back into her life after Jason removes himself, and her clients are sinking deeper into their problems - her only hope is to turn to the Savior.  Never a religious woman, Clara finds solace in her choice to give her life to Christ and she finds comfort in continued counseling sessions with Justine.  Uncovering her past, and finding that her past is tied to a client of hers that has a split personality, talking about what she's always considered to be Nobody's Business is helping her climb out of the pit of despair that her life is in.  As Clara discovers painful truths about her childhood, she becomes supportive to others.  As she learns more about herself, she is able to share more with others and take her own advice.

4

Review:
Marley is the central character in this book and the central theme to me was family relationships and dynamics of the bond between mother and daughter and the ever-present greatness of God in healing bonds.  How important bonds are and the nurturing it takes to make successes of these bonds made this Christian Fiction book, more real that the word "fiction" implies.  Ma Grand and her daughter Pam had a strained relationship at best.  Ma Grand was from the `old school' so to say, where it wasn't as important to say those three magical words `I love you' as it was to show them.  She had inherited those traits from her parents so saw no need to give that type of attention to her daughter Pam.  When Marley came along, Pam felt differently about that towards her daughter and willingly lavished not only positive words, but also influence and affection upon her. It is this relationship that propels Marley to experience the same in her relationship with Gerrard her fianc.  As the novel begins, we are transported to the engagement party of this socialite couple and while things appear bright from the heavy hitters on the invitation list, looks can be deceiving.  As Marley soon finds out, her fianc has other interests that don't place his relationship with her in the forefront of his decisions and this leads to their eventual demise.  As Marley searches for strength in the midst of this pain, illness strikes home with her mother Pam.
Shrouded in seemingly dark clouds, an invitation to join her secretary in church provides a ray of sunshine to Marley.  As if God is speaking to her with every word that proceeds from the Minister's mouth, Marley has at last found solace - a resting place for her heart and soul.  An added bonus is the introduction of Lazarus into her life a God Fearing Christian, upright man.  Not many of them exist today and what a treasure when one is found.  It is through this relationship, with this Godly man that Marley reconciles in her mind the relationship between Ma Grand and her mother, and the relationship between her mother and herself.  God creates and nurtures bonds on an individual basis because of his omnipresence.  Marley blossoms into a strong Christian woman through the love of a great man and the love of great family.  Through That Faith, That Trust, That Love that Marley has for God, the manifestation is seen throughout her relationships others.  This is a very inspirational read to those of us who want our lives to be used by God for his purpose.

Review:
Personally I think this is a great collection of Elton Johns best. For anyone growing up in the late 19060's early 70's this has what I believe to be his best work. After looking at a few of the single CD's in this 5 Classic Album Collection. This collection cost much less and in my opinion it sounds great. There is outstanding articulation in both the words and music. Nothing sounds flat or muffled like so many of the analog to digital transfers do from that area.

The Collection of Cd's are all in jewel cases carried within a very nice well made heavy duty cardboard box. The box has an outstanding look and feel to it and is designed so that you can see the title of each CD clearly once opened. On the back of the box is a list showing the names of the albums and all of the songs on those albums. The dark blue color of the box and clean white lettering make a great contrast so reading the information is very easy.

The sound Quality is very good on every CD in the collection. All of the songs display good to outstanding dynamics and clarity. It might have been nice to have seen these titles remastered in the similar box set, but there's nothing really wrong with the audio quality here. It's only my opinion, but so many of the songs on these CD's are such classics that they deserve to be polished listened to at highest possible quality. After saying that I have to say there really is nothing wrong with the sound quality, and the set is a great bargain at the current price of $20.98. It would have just been nice to hear as much detail as humanly possible in these classics.

Honestly I love everything about this set. Personally I feel this collection is rich with some of the best songs ever written. Crossing lines in just about every genre. Many of these songs where played on radio stations specializing in everything from Country to Rock. Each CD is loaded with songs that put Elton John on the top of the charts and kept him there for years. Many if not most of these songs have stood the test of time, and still carrying the emotion and feeling that Elton John was so able to share in his music.
Score:
5

Review:
Depicted in the movie "American Sniper", this book is about the Navy SEAL Ryan Job and his life after the devastating injury he suffered in Iraq that left him blind.  Carried by his Christian faith and an immense amount of determination, not only did Ryan Job survive being shot in the face and left blind, but he continued to lead a productive life despite facing huge challenges until a tragic error ended his life well before his time was up.
In this book, Robert Vera, a close friend of Ryan Job's, gives the reader an in-depth look at Ryan Job as a person, a soldier and most important a human being. He describes his sense of humor that lifts up others when they need help and a determination that makes Ryan seem invincible to those close to him and put seemingly nothing out of his reach. Most importantly, Robert Vera shows that Ryan Job after the injury in Iraq was able to recover and achieve a sense of normalcy that involves miletstones such as college graduation and hunting elk.
The book is broken up into three main parts, entitled Tested, Transformed and Redeemed that stand for the progression of Ryan Job from battle injured in Irag to finding a new life and normalcy back in the USA. Overall, while the book has strong Christian overtones in certain places, it does give the reader a good insight into the character of this extraordinary soldier and being written by a close friend gives the book an authenticity that makes the person of Ryan Job come alive.
Disclaimer: I received a free copy of the book in exchange for an honest review. The opinion expressed in this post is solely my own and has not been influenced by any third parties.

Review:
The Cat's Woweo!

What a fun book all about the ugliest cats in the world. You will discover some of the strangest cats you have ever seen or probably never heard of. Each of these feline species are discussed covering all the information, size, weight, coloring and disposition including special things like health problems, if there are any. Most cats have few health problems. You will learn that some species love all human companionship while others have a love for only one family member. Some do not like other cats and some love dogs the best. This little book gives you an interesting educated look into cats not just the ugly ones.

Most people try to compare cats with dogs but they are a entirely different creature. I have always considered myself a dog person but I have ended up with five wonderful indoor cats, it is a long story. My point is this book showed me that one of my cats which I have always considered as a Black Siamese, is really an Oriental Shorthair. He is exactly as described by author Daphne, he is called "Super Frank" as he is able to leap tall seven foot cabinets in a single bound, fetches his toys over and over, will disappear when a visitor enters the house (after three years I still can not find his hiding place) and really a one person cat. Other than the jumping, all of this is uncat like behavior.

Your entire family will enjoy this fun adventure to the Feline world. The rare photos will tug at the strings of your heart. A great book to share with your kids. There are several lessons they will learn from Butt Ugly Cats.
Recommended!

5

Review:
First, this book wasn't written by Bird and Magic. It was written by Jackie MacMullan.

Second, the book is fairly interesting and fun to read.

Third, the writing is sloppy and feels like it's a first draft. The editing isn't tight, the narrative wanders around, and ideas or controversies are treated superficially. The passive way the game is analyzed (players "submit" stat lines so many times it'll make your head spin) really leaves a lot to be desired.

Fourth, there are some dandy typos in this book, another indication of the sloppy editing (my favorite was "break" for "brake," for instance).

So, a fun read if you're from the era and remember Showtime v. Celtics with fondness. Otherwise, there are better books out there.

Review:
When I opened this book I was loving it. I was feeling like this might be a 4 star read, then things went downhill... rapidly.

When I pick up a book I don't want to find mistakes. Now I will say I understand if a few mistakes are found along the way. But this far surpasses a few mistakes. By the time I finished the book was filled with little yellow tabbies. Yes, I mark all mistakes in every book I read with tabbies. It wasn't just a few misspelled words, there were those, but it was added words that made sentences not make sense.. at all. I would find myself re-reading sentences over and over trying to figure out what I was missing, only to discover it was never going to make sense.

I will say it is frustrating to sit down with a book you want to enjoy only to be plagued by errors that could have been prevented had someone read the book before it went to the press.

Summary - Milo is troubled. He hates his brother and is addicted to drugs. When he realizes his life is over in his home town, he moves and starts fresh. There he meets Maya, who was equally as troubled but is clean. She is facing her own demons. Both her parents are dead and her brother is dying. Milo and Maya start dating and learn to trust each other with their secrets and demons.

The storyline held promise. I was looking forward to reading a book where the characters are imperfect and face challenging times. Unfortunately the execution fell flat. The beginning was good, the middle focused too much on the instant love story, and the end felt scattered and cheesy.

I was hoping to read a book with a relationship that built throughout. Again the beginning of the book held promise of that. Milo even stated that he was going to chase Maya. I liked the idea of seeing him woo her, but no... apparently there is no chase they just fall madly in love with each other before the first date even starts..

One problem that annoyed me was how the author flipped on Joey. Here is a young woman who sees a troubled young man and tries to help him. He didn't want to go to the meetings and found it difficult to stay clean. She helped him through those times. She was his best friend, like his family. She was likable at the beginning of the book. Enter Maya.. as soon as Milo has Maya in his life his perception of Joey changes, but only when Maya has a problem with her. I feel the author turned on Joey at this point. She made Joey come across as selfish, rude, and unlikable. There is even a moment where Milo completely turns on her. Some people find that having a sponsor is more helpful to them than going to meetings. Others find the opposite helpful. Who are we to judge how someone is able to get and stay clean? That upset me.

By the time I hit the middle of the book I was upset with the direction it was taking, but even the story seemed to slow in its pace. I was struggling to get through the middle and the end. It became way too cheesy for me. I wanted more than the instant cheesy love story that was delivered.
Score:
3

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
I actually liked this book!

I will admit that I started to read it a while ago, but wasn't in the mood so I set it aside. I recently picked it back up, having forgotten what it was about at all. So I went into it blind so to speak.

I liked reading this book with no idea what it was about or what the concept was. I felt like I was reading a contemporary romance, but a good one. I was intrigued by the storyline, liked the characters, and was even surprised by an added element at the end.

Summary - Jona has spent the last 12 years of her life in an orphanage because her mother dropped her off there. Jona is bitter, she has turned to the streets and gets caught quite frequently. After getting caught this last time her sentence is to live with her mother, aunt, and her uncle in France. While there her mother seeks for forgiveness and she makes a friend in Julian.

Like I said I felt like 98% of this book is a contemporary romance, but when I reached the end I realized there was a paranormal aspect to it. Normally the paranormal is something I really have to be in the mood to read and it has to be really well done for me to enjoy it. With this book it makes up such a small part and it is done well that I didn't mind it at all.

One thing I am going to harp on is the amount of mistakes. I debated rating it 3 stars just for that reason, but the story was a good one so I nixed that idea. I just feel like mistakes take away from the ease of reading. I want to sit down and immerse myself in a book, not to be drawn from it by rough sentences.

The love story is really well done. I liked that it was a relationship that felt realistic and grew through the entire book. Jona and Julian really get to know each other and learn to trust in one another. I found myself wanting to turn the pages to find out how Jona and Julian were going to connect next or what problems they needed to work through.

Review:
I loved this album. I'd have given it 5 stars if not for one problem I had with the DVD. But before I get to that, I want to state for the record (no pun intended) how good this album is. If you loved 12 SONGS, you'll love this one, too. It's that simple. They are done in the same style and Diamond's catchy melodies really work with the expanded band used for this recording. It's pure Diamond. Any Neil Diamond fan knows what I'm talking about. I purchased the version with the bonus tracks and the DVD. As for the bonus tracks the Dylan cover is great the other cover not so much. I don't know if this is due to the fact that both of he bonus tracks are not Diamond compositions so they don't quite gel or what. The Dylan one is very good the other just seems a bit out of place. Perhaps further listenings will correct this.

As for the DVD, it should be great! You get a couple of live performances and a couple of studio performances. My knock against it is that, after the first tune, you can't hear ANY vocals. They are either mixed down to a whisper or were poorly recorded in the first place. On the last tune, The Boxer, they are just gone. You can't hear a word. I thought perhaps my DVD is defective in some way. Has anyone else encountered this problem.

But if you're a Diamond fan and have your eye on the single CD version of the album, then I can't recommend it highly enough. Just be wary of the DVD. It's an exercise in frustration. There's Neil singing his heart out and you can't hear a word!

However the album is one of the best I've heard this year.

4

Review:
I think it's time to shelve this book.  It does not deserve a place on the children's classics.  There are a number of problems with the book.  First off, it's a dull tale.  It could have been exciting--the tale of two children running away from home and living in a museum--but it ends up being mundane.  There is precious little suspense in the story, and the children never seem overly concerned about getting caught.

Indeed, the children do not seem overly concerned about very much at all.  They give scant thought to their parents (who after a hours would be going crazy--after a week would suffer psychological damage).  They think little about lying, betrayal, cheating at cards, swindling a friend's money at cards, stealing coins from the museum fountain, trespassing, or the harm they might be causing others. Such problems can be excellent fodder for a novel!  Who wants angelic characters?  BUT such problems need to be confronted and overcome--not ignored.  In short, they address almost none of the moral dilemmas posed by the novel.  They just drift through the plot in a narcissistic manner.

As if recognizing the tedium of her own tale Konigsburg gives us the mystery of the Angel statue.  It is an implausible and poorly resolved mystery which never adds much momentum to the story.  My 6 year old and I were not dying to find out the answer to the mystery.  The novel's apex comes when Frankweiler and Claudia conspire in secrecy and share the potency of secrets.  It's a powerful notion, but there is a risk is glorifying secrecy for children.  Having a personal, burning secret can be a source of pride and intrigue, but it can also be a harmful tumor.  As with all of the moral issues in the book, Konigsburg does not address the multi-edged nature of secrecy.  Undeserving of the Newbury, this novel is now undeserving of our further attention.
Score:
2

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
I had pleasant memories of this book from childhood, though something amiss lingered in my memory.  There, in my gray matter, after three decades, remained a sense of unease with this book.  Now, having read the book aloud to my daughter, I can see what went wrong.  This book has on every page jokes and vocabulary that would challenge my college students.  And yet the book is targeted to small children.  Let me throw you a few examples: The Senses Taker, Dynne (a play on "din" and "djinn"), Kakofonous A. Dischord Doctor of Dissonance.  Some needlessly tough words: salve, disdainfully, brandishing, gelatinous, and countless more.

To be fair, there are a great many things accessible to children, such as (literally) jumping to (the island of) Conclusions, the watchdog (a dog with a clock in his middle), and Alec, the floating boy who is growing down.  Moreover, the Jules Feiffer illustrations are superb.  They greatly help to make sense of the difficult concepts in this work.

Charitably, one could say that the author intended a whole set of bon-mots for the adult reader, and a more innocent story for the young.  But I don't think this is the case.  I think that Juster terribly overshot his audience and created a book better for adults than children.  For those determined to read this book, reserve it for older children who are very strong readers.  This is not a book that translates well to the young.

Review:
Two years ago, I had purchased the The Wolfgang Deep Gloss Total Concours Kit which includes the autobathe, clay bar, clay lubricant, paintwork polish enhancer, deep sealant 3.0, and instant detail spritz for my spouse to use on his beloved Mugen Milano Red 2010 Honda Fit. Unfortunately, that car was totaled in a rear end collision, and he was unable to use the kit as intended. Fast forward to the present, we needed a new car, and ended up buying a 2016 Aegean Blue Honda Civic that looks very sporty. Immediately, my husband washed, polished, and sealed the car using his Wolfgang kit and PORTER-CABLE 7346SP 6-Inch Orbital Polisher. The car of course looked absolutely stunning, but more importantly, weekly and monthly maintenance is much simpler after adding the sealant.

AUTO BATHE-In terms of the Auto Bathe solution, my husband used the recommend amount for a bucket of water, and felt that the 1 oz recommended amount was overkill for one bucket. He said half would do a great job for next time. In terms of the cleaning properties, he liked it a lot more than the cost effective Armor all brand shine and wax auto bath that he's used in the past. He said that the soapy water was more soapy for the amount of solution that he put in the bucket, and that he would need to add a lot of the armor all brand car wash to create the same amount of soap. He said that the auto bath had a pleasant smell to it, but more importantly he felt that the auto bath did a great job of cleaning dirt off the car. Since the car we have is brand new, it was hard to assess its cleaning abilities, but since my parents recently visited from L.A., my husband said that the bath cleans really well when it was used on their 2004 honda civic after a 6 hour road trip. Although more expensive that other brands, my husband said that if he were to use 1/2 an ounce for each car bath, given its a 16 oz bottle, and that he washes the car from head to toe at most once a month, it should last him at least 24-30 months. And for that many baths, he said he felt the extra cost to have a good, thorough clean was worth it.

CLAY BAR/CLAY BAR LUBRICANT-Althought the clay bar does what a clay bar is supposed to do and there was nothing spectacualr about it, it is very important to have for someone serious about detailing their car. Since my husband wanted to learn how to use the kit right, he watched an hour YouTube video about the the wolfgang product line, where he learned about the importance of claying the car, especially if its been awhile. According to the instructional video, claying the car allows you to remove, dirt, grime, and other foreign material that have embedded themselves on the surface of your car and do not come off after washing. If you do not clay the car, the polish, sealant, of wax you add to the surface will not adhere as well if the embedded materials are not removed first. One tip as described in the Youtube Video is to take the bar, break it into 3 or 4 pieces, and turn those pieces into pancake looking discs which are easier to clean with. VERY IMPORTANT!! Never use the clay bar by itself, and always use the lubricant on the surface of the car and on the clay bar itself.

PAINTWORK POLISH ENHANCER & DEEP GLOSS PAINT SEALANT 3.0- Once the car is clean, clayed, and dried, find a cool spot to apply the bread and butter of the Wolfgang kit. Keep in mind that if you have a beat up or older car, you should instead use a compound and swirl remover solution prior to polishing the car. Since we have a newer car however, the polish enhancer and sealant 3.0 were fine. VERY IMPORTANT!! After application of the sealant, let it sit for 40-50 min in a cool area. He made the mistake on first use of wiping away the sealant after maybe only 15-20 min not knowing any better, and apparently the 45 minutes are supposed to help the sealant BOND to the cars surface. A good way of knowing if its ok to wipe of is the "finger test". You wipe with one finger across a part of your car with the sealant on the surface after the 45 min are done. If you wipe and it is still creamy and seems like running a finger through mayo, its not ready. There should be a shiny, clean surface when you wipe away the sealant.

INSTANT DETAIL SPRAY-The sealant can take 3-4 strong car washes before starting to come off. Thats about one a month, so application every 3-4 months is advised. There are wax/sealant friendly car wash solutions out there that can extend the life of the sealant/wax. One of those is the Instant Spray Detail Spray that is included in the Wolfgang kit. Its been over two months since waxing the car, and though my husband is the one mostly responsible of maintaining the interior and exterior of the car, I have cleaned the exterior of the car occasionally using the Instant Spray Detailer which my husband, and myself love to use. He of course uses the spray liberally at least once a week, and has already ordered the 128 oz refill as well as the spray sealant to supplement orbitally sealing the car every 3-4 months. In the few occasions I myself have used the detailer, I've noticed quite a few aspects of the detailer spray that I like.

1) The smell of the detailer is nice and not offensive in any way. Being around different car cleaning chemicals in the past, those with a strong or offensive chemical odor just make me not want to clean the car at all. Since the detailer has a nice smell to it, I don't mind at all being the one to "detail" the car every once in a while.

2) The shine and clean surface that the spray leaves behind are amazing, especially if you've done some compounding, polishing, sealing, or waxing work before hand. My parents made a visit from L.A., and we used the detailer on there 2004 blue civic when they got here, and after my husband orbitally compounded, polished, and waxed their car. The detailer cleans and shines but it definitely amplifies previous detailing work that has been done to the car even more.

3) Because the detailer spray can be used on glass, plastic, and pretty much any part of the car, my husband said that he was able to get some stubborn glass water stains that remained from his first car wash using the detailer spray. He said it was pretty easy to do, and didn't involve as much manual pressure as he though. He just made sure to let the solution sit for a bit before cleaning the car.

Overall, this is en excellent kit, with excellent quality items that may seem pricey up front, but are a good deal when you get them all together at once. If you are serious about auto detailing and maintenance, this is exactly what you need. Keep in mind that you need to supplement this kit with other car care items as needed for glass, rims, tires, plastic, leather, etc. But in terms of the actual paint of the car, unless you have an older or beat up car that requires the use of the compound and swirl remover solution, this kit gives you everything you need for a cleaner, shinier, car.

Review:
I had been contemplating and debating whether or not I wanted to make the investment and pay for this water filter. I was debating whether to buy it because of the price, and the fact that my husband needed to install it and I wasn't sure how complex it would get (don't want him to break our sink/kitchen). Up to when I had purchased this filter, I had been doing fine buying filtered water at the grocery store and using a water stand since we only needed to refill three 5 gallon bottles maybe once every 2-3 weeks. But we went ahead and made the investment, and so far it has been a really great decision. Regarding the installation, the kitchen and sink area definitely did get messy. I'll go over some of the issues that my husband faced when installing the filter.

1) You need to make sure you have the right drill bits to drill a hole through your sink. Whether porcelain or stainless steel, you need the right tools to get a hole through your sink without creating any extra damage. If you make an awkward sized hole, the water tap may not properly seal and water may drip under the sink.

2) Make sure you are comfortable with tools, drilling holes into your sink drain, and drilling holes into the sides of the sink cabinet to install the filtration system. not so much for the sides but some people may not like the idea of drilling a hole into the sink drain which you have to.

3) My husband had a VERY hard time because of the angle of the faucet and sink drain connecting the cold water metal connection that connects to the filter. Hopefully your sink is spacious, because if it's small or cramped with weird angles, some tubing and parts of the installation that require tightening nuts may be tricky.

4) Lastly, you have to be confident that once you start the project you will finish it, and that you will do it correctly. There are so many tubes and connections throughout the filter installation that involve so many areas such as the water line, sink drain, and the filter itself, that there are many possible areas for leaks, disconnects, and other issues. You can't just install and leave it, for the first two days after install, there was a total of 2 leaks that occurred. Two were due to tubes not being properly pushed all the way in, and a one took some time to develop and was hard to spot at first. It needs to be installed right because realistically if you leave home for hours on end, or for a long vacation, the connections need to be right or else it just takes one tube to POP and there goes your savings.

Other than these points, as other reviewers have said, the water filtration and taste is excellent. The water appears crystal clear, and health wise it is an excellent investment since I find myself drinking a lot more water and taking water from home since it is so easily accessible. I hope my review has been helpful, enjoy your filter if you buy one!

Review:
Awesome PtP bridge devices.  Get a pair for a 'wireless fast ethernet' installation; other wireless applications possible as well.

Sure. not gigabit but they are affordable.  My garage is now seamlessly connected to my home network LAN.  Garage HTPC is on the domain, WMC shared library streaming, PLEX streaming, Unifi AP to extend my WiFi network proximal to the garage, even allows for WMC recording via HD HomeRun Prime wirelessly and reliably.

I'm a long time user of Ubiquiti Products and a big fan.  AP's are Unifi, have Nano's and Pico's for various applications, ToughSwitch Pro's for wired network & POE.  Still use my pfSense router as i can't complain about it but often consider Edge Router...  wish I could demo one to see how the network would benefit from an entirely Ubiquiti system....  Maybe one day if my pfSense machine bites the dust...

If you have never used Ubiquiti products, set up may seem a bit daunting at a glance - don't stress this - it is much more simple than initial impressions may lead you to believe.  The beauty is in the flexibility of the software. You aren't limited by anything really, can do whatever you want during setup.  The user knowledge base and forums have clear examples of anything I have ever dreamed of trying to do.

When in Patagonia in the antarctic winter, we had a solid and reliable wireless network across multiple tug boats, crane barges and a wrecked vessel - all through a single sat connection.  This was largely based in Pico Stations used as both PtmP bridges, then other Pico's used as AP's.  For simple bridges and end points/CPE's/wireless-to-wired though, use the Nano's i would think.  Anyway, when you can attain better wifi in Patagonia than you can in most coffee shops, you are using the right gear.

Review:
No question, this is an effective product. Using pheramones [sic.] to attact moths then trap them with sticky paper appeal to my love of science and technology.

Today, the product is already folded into a triangular house for the moths to fly into. The interior is coated with adhesive so the moths become trapped after entering the house. Users must removed a pheramone-infused tab from a sealed package, then insert the tab into a slot to get it inside the housing. But almost always, the tab falls out of its intended spot and is stuck to the interior. I've used it this way and it seems to work fine, but the manufactuer can help users by making three changes in the way they package the product.

1. make the little pheramone-infused tab already correctly  positioned and attached to the interior so that users don't have to open the sealed package and handle the tab.

2. They should cover the whole item, including the sticky paper, with wax paper, score where the folds go, and indicate how to fold it into the housing shape. Then users would just have to peel the whole wax sheet off to expose the sticky paper and the pheramone tab, fold it up, and voila, done!

This way, the manufacturer can also save on packaging by shipping the items in a flat envelope rather than a mostly empty box.

3. Make the sticky housing attachable to something so it doesn't knock around my pantry.  This can be as simple as a hole to hang it on a nail, or a weak adhesive like that used on Post-it notes to attach the trap to a wall.

Review:
I read most of the longer than-a-sentence-or-two reviews and have to agree with many of the positive comments.  This book is excellent.  It is one for which I would warn you that you will want to read slowly and contemplatively.  And I read it in one day, starting early in the morning and ending late in the evening.  PLUS it is one I will re-read.

The premise that Lizzy doesn't refuse Darcy at Hunsford but instead asks for a week to consider is one which is difficult to swallow.  BUT this author does a credible job of having Lizzy display a different reaction, knowing that she also has suspicions about his interference in Jane's and Bingley's life and that he sabotaged Wickham's chances for a happy life.  The fact that she doesn't love him while the knowledge that he does love her are first and foremost in considerations for both parties.  And how contradictory in the light of the advice Darcy gave Bingley!  Oh, the author does a wonderful job here of putting the onus where it belongs and having characters consider who is responsible for the final decision and outcome.

I had tears as Lizzy, late in this courtship and after observing how Darcy removes himself emotionally from socially interacting with her friends and family, so expertly humbles him by relating acts on the part of Sir Lucas, her aunt and her mother.  (Don't judge a book by its cover...a lesson for all here.)

And while ODC is open about much of what they feel and have observed, they both have some secrets, which eventually come out and have to be dealt with.  There are points in this story at which you can wonder if we are going to get our HEA.  Both Elizabeth and Darcy reach a point at which they consider if they are fair to make each other keep their word to marry...both wonder at how the other can put up with so many affronts, so many rude comments, so many in each family not happy with this engagement.

As others have said there are no new characters and the story follows much of canon.  But the step-by-step process of really getting to know each other, of learning to be open and also accepting each other with good and bad traits displayed is very well done here.  And we also read some realities about other characters, i.e., Mr. Bennet accepting his role in the whole dowry debacle and in changing his mind about Brighton.

Well done and despite the high price a book not to be missed.

5

Review:
4.5 stars

It is rare that I give a novella 5 stars but I contemplated such here as I must say that this story touched me, brought me to tears, even sobbing.  Few books do that to me.  I read this book due to seeing it recommended on Goodreads and then reading the Amazon reviews and the Sample.

I know we have all read or heard about people who have met with near death experiences and how, usually, the life goals, the values, the meaning of life are changed in a deep and lasting way.  Darcy has such an experience and it is one which gives him months to dream, to contemplate and to plan.  He also updates his will and writes letters to all who might need to know his wishes.

This book has many parallels to canon but there are several differences: one is that the Netherfield Ball is now a masquerade and another is the resulting duel as Wickham is found seducing one of the guests.  I don't want to post spoilers here but will add that this author does a good job with slight changes to or new happenings.  I really liked reading the thought processes from both Elizabeth's and Darcy's POV.  Elizabeth's powers of observations as to even the type of clothing worn by her mystery man and then discernment about subtle changes in behavior bringing realizations as to who is lying and manipulating circumstances were well written.  Darcy's eavesdropping does, as we all know it will, bring pain but also achieves what the Hunsford proposal did in canon.  Darcy does a good deal of soul searching and gains some insights.  He acts as a man of honor and justice and protection towards those he cares about.

The only chord which might read as out-of-tune was the affect of the final lie from Wickhams mouth.  It might be interpreted as Wickham putting in one last effort to wound Darcys soul as he did his body but then, although Darcy had moments of misgivings about Elizabeth which were disappointing, they were just that, MOMENTS, immediately after which he did suggest an anvil visit to Elizabeth.

I would have liked more at the endespecially of the relationship between Darcy and Elizabeth, even the reaction of friends and family.  And I do love epilogues.that heir to Pemberley, etc.  But overall this is a book which I will say I do recommend to all.  It was a short read but well done even in its brevity.

Review:
An enormously long, twisted novel by an exceptionally talented writer that fascinates. Overly long, to me, sub-plotted to within an inch of its life. But much of it grabs and holds the heart and the mind. Why only four stars? One thinks some of it could have been thinned out. Pieces could have been removed -- and should have been. But I will read every one of the Hole series. This one was my first. I could do little else with attention while reading it. That counts for something, doesn't it?

Update: 8/12/14  Having reread The Redbreast, I realize that I should have rated it five stars to begin with -- as I do now. The book is not unduly long and could not have been shortened without leaving out needed things. (I confess that I did not cope well with the Norwegian names, all of which and all of whose connections are hard to remember and take into account as one moves along in the tale, with everything coming together toward the end. I did better the second time through.) This book is not only fascinating and gripping in its own right, but essential to understanding Harry Hole's key romantic relationship, started here and integral to what else happens, played out in subsequent novels. Without spoiling things, I cannot reveal why such close attention to what Harry learns here, and thinking about it and who else knows, is so important, but it is. The first two Harry Hole novels are not linked to this, perhaps explaining why they were published later rather than up front. I recommend Redbreast without reservation and it ought to be read first, before getting into the later books. Having done that, read them all. All of them are superb!

As my title implied, I have now added this author onto my "favorite author" list.....and look forward to reading more by him.  This is contemporary fiction and doubt my husband would find it to be his cup of tea, but I would highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys women's fiction. Review:
~This review is based off an ARC received from NetGalley~

This is the part of this job I really don't like. I always try so hard to find one redeeming quality in every book I review, but with this one ... I just can't.

The 1 1/2 stars is for all the potential. I think that was also the most frustrating part. There were so many little, awesome details in this book that I felt were a set up for something E-P-I-C but then ... nothing. Literally nothing really happened in this book at all.

To be honest, I shouldn't have kept reading. But I did. Because I was so sure something huge was going to happen around the corner of each page. But it never did.

~Mild spoilers ahead~

I also hate doing reviews with spoilers, but on this one I can't help but give out some mild ones to make my point. Starting at the beginning...

Mia goes to Milan after she's been possessed by a demon. Her strange relatives arrive and save her. She is immediately attracted to Emilio ... her cousin. Who has a girlfriend no one in the family likes, and who doesn't like any of the females in the family. This plot tangent is never dealt with, only mentioned briefly.

Her relatives go on and on about how they can't teach her about demon catching because than the demon will know everything she knows, but they tell her a whole bunch of stuff and let her help with exorcisms anyways. The demon knowing everything that she knows thing is never dealt with.

There are two incorporeal spirits in her room that only Mia can hear. They show up at random intervals for no particular purpose. Their presence is never explained nor explored.

Mia has a five second crush on a guy named Lucifero, a Satanist. He takes her out for coffee, gets possessed by her demon and then after that is sent to the hospital and disappeared off the face of the earth. He and his group-who tried to "infiltrate" her family a little earlier in the book-are never heard from again.

~Spoilers end~

What DOES happen in the book then, you ask? Pages upon pages of cooking, getting to know Mia's HUGE family cast and Milanese history. Also, Mia talking like a teenager straight from a sitcom.

I really can't adequately express my frustration with this book. I think it's worse because I believed in this book SO MUCH despite SO MUCH evidence to the contrary. In the end, just when it seems like the book is about to get started, it ENDS. Just ENDS. With nothing much ever having happened in the first place.

When I was at my last writing workshop, I wrote a piece of flash fiction, and the critique was that it seemed like the real story began where I had written "The End." That is exactly the problem with this novel. Beyer could have begun this series after this book says "The End," summed up what happened here in a paragraph and had a much stronger novel. Though there will be a sequel to this book, I don't believe I'll be reading it.

2

Review:
No, this isn't a ya novel. But as a die hard Richelle Mead fan, I couldn't resist requesting this when it popped up on Edelweiss. Perhaps it is because I'm such a die hard fan that I couldn't help but be disappointed by this book.

Besides being a huge Mead fan, I picked up this book because the premise seemed freaking fantastic. In this, at least, I wasn't disappointed. Mead has created a huge world with a diverse population-did I mention huge? This book travels like nobody's business. The very idea that the Republic of United North America is cracking down on religions, or as they say "belief in fictitious entities," is really cool-especially because it's obvious right from the get go that there are some larger forces at work. The involvement of the various gods-and especially Justin's ravens-kept me engaged in this book even when everything else wanted to through me out.

This book is told from multiple points of view, mostly Justin and Mae's. The story is told in the third person, yes, but there still never felt like there was much of a difference between their narrations. The characters themselves came off as a little flat, which was strange because so much time was spent investigating what made them tick. Mead was very thorough in giving background on her characters, and all of them had multiple facets that I enjoyed. But there was still something that kept them from lifting off the page for me, a kind of stiffness that I can't explain. It was quite strange.

The plot and pacing of the book also seemed to drag on a little. Mead, as usual, is all about plots and subplots, but I wasn't as invested in some of them as I could be. Perhaps it is because some where mentioned in the book but then not really addressed. The character of Tessa bothered me especially, because I didn't understand the point of watching this girl from the provinces adjust to life at high school while Justin and Mae were out playing with gods and murderers. Most times she just seemed like a human plot device, whose actions only facilitated certain events that needed to happen.

Overall, however, I think this was a successful book. I might have gotten bored in places, but I always kept reading. The intrigue with the multiple deities running around kept me hooked, and will keep me hooked for the next book. I would recommend this book for people captivated by the world Mead is creating. It's not one I'd urge you to buy in hardcover (especially because it's an adult book and gollywhiz those prices for hardcovers), but if you see it in paperback or at the library and think it might be interesting, I'd be all over that.

(And if you missed this at the beginning of the review, this is NOT a ya book. It is an adult book and there are sexy times. If that's not your thing, you've been warned.)

Review:
OK, first off:  I am not a spiritual person.  I don't follow any organized religion though I have tried several denominations of Christianity over the course of my life.  These days I am a religious skeptic and definitely tend toward the scientific view in most things.

All that said, I REALLY LOVED this book!  I have recommended it often and with fervor.

The author, through his story, manages to show the reader a view of God and faith that I found refreshing and much more in line with what I feel a true God would and should be.  I know that probably sounds pompous and sacrilegious but this author showed me a way toward faith such that I actually felt encouraged to consider following that path.  That is HUGE for me to say but that is how powerfully I responded to this book.

Twenty years ago I had read "Ebola" by William T. Close, M.D. (actress Glen Close's father) who was an MD in Zaire in 1976 during the first outbreak of Ebola.  I just this week (Oct. 2014) finished re-reading the book and came across this quote attributed to one of the Belgian nuns when she was talking about the difference between two father's style of preaching:  "The God of the Old Testament is a God of rules and vengeance.  Ours is more like a father who understands human nature because he created it.  Dogma controls through fear; spirituality through love.  God gives each of us the freedom to choose how we behave in the face of nature's disasters or even our own defeats."

I was raised by preachers of the Old Testament where fear is the vehicle of faith.  "The Shack" showed me that there can be another way, the way of the New Testament where love really is the guiding light of faith.  The author further states that religion is the invention of man and that God may not be particularly happy about it nor endorse man's creation of religion.

In fact, to take it even a step  further, it is the difference between beating a child as discipline and disciplining a child through love, patience and guidance.  The first teaches a child "respect" through fear and that physical force is the answer to differences and conflict.  The second shows the child the wisdom and patience of a loving parent who approaches the child and his indiscretion with an age-appropriate discussion and a discipline that teaches the lesson through love and appropriate consequences for his actions.

I definitely appreciate and endorse the latter--hands down--every--single--time!  So here's to love, light and life through the love, wisdom and guidance of a loving parent or mother/father figurehead!

5

Review:
I loved this book and I am not a murder mystery fan.  Then again, this book purports to be about a possible murder and it is in more ways than one.  Now that I'm thinking about this review, I am finding it difficult to talk about the book without giving something away and I definitely don't want to do that.  This book is so well written and so clever and so well thought out by the author and one of the characters that I found it mesmerizing.  This is some great storytelling!  This would make a great movie if it were well done.

I found myself thinking about marriage and what makes them work--or not.  My daughter recently told me how much she loves her husband and how she works to make their marriage work.  She is willing to overlook things, to forgive, to look for the good things and to be willing to work hard to find the good and the happy things and she recommits to that idea every single day.  She strives to be happy.  She makes it a commitment for herself, her husband and her family.  In this book, the couple became complacent as so many of us do and things become untenable for both parties but they dealt with it in very different ways.

This book also presents the reader with a character whose single minded determination and sheer will to make the marriage what she thought she had been promised with the end justifying the means.  She becomes the worst version of herself in all her psychotic "madness".  Her husband took a different and much more conventional approach.  In the end, I suspect they both won and they both lost.  You'll have to be the judge.

The ending quite surprised me.  I'll have to leave it at that but the characters explain their decisions and in the context of their characters, it made a certain kind of sense.

I've heard that the author's other two books were no where near as good as this one.  I'll just have to wait for the next one and hopefully there WILL BE a next one!  In the meantime...have fun with this book because you most certainly will.

Review:
I'm the kind of music fan that pays close attention to the bands I like.  I always remember which songs are released as singles, whether they become major hits or not.  Every time a band puts out a "greatest hits" album or a "best of" album, they ALWAYS end up leaving off some key songs.  I'm not saying that EVERY single has to make the cut, but at least get all of the successful hits!  Nope, they always leave off 1 or 2 major hits just to anger you enough to go out and buy one more thing to round out your collection.  After all, most of these compilation albums are put together by the record company, the band rarely has much involvement.  Not in this case, though!  Seether did the incredibly obvious thing to do, which also happens to be something very rarely done... THEY PUT EVERY SINGLE ON HERE!"  I've been listening to these guys since a couple weeks before their first album was released, and I can tell you that they didn't miss anything here.  The first album (Disclaimer) is represented with Fine Again, Driven Under, and Gasoline.  The version of Broken on here is not the original album version; it's the more popular re-recording that they did with Amy Lee from Evanescence.  Then the second album (Karma & Effect) is represented with Remedy, Truth, and The Gift.  From the third album (Finding Beauty In Negative Spaces) we have Fake It, Rise Above This, Breakdown, and the cover of Careless Whisper which was released on later pressings.  Finally, the band's fourth and most recent album is represented with Country Song, Tonight, Here And Now, and No Resolution.  These are all fantastic songs (although I was never crazy about Careless Whisper), and I think this will make all you casual Seether fans very happy!  However, don't be scared to check out the band's individual albums, which are all very solid.  After all, some really great songs like Sympathetic and Fur Cue never made it to the radio.

However, things don't end there.  We get a whole other disc containing B-sides and other rare songs from the band.  This is cool for devoted Seether fans like myself, but it would make more sense to release this seperately.  Obviously this was packaged together to ensure sales from both casual AND diehard fans of the group.  (This was probably the record label's idea.)  Oh well, at least the price is cheap!  This disc begins with a cover of Seether, a song originally recorded by Veruca Salt and most likely the inspiration for the band's name.  It sounds pretty good, but it seems a little mellow and I was thinking the band was really gonna rock out with it.  Then there's Safe To Say I've Had Enough and Weak, which I believe are both newly recorded songs.  Out Of My Way and Hang On were recorded for movie soundtracks, but I don't understand why they put these on here since they were included on Disclaimer II.  We also have Let Me Go from the Remedy single, and No Shelter from the NCIS soundtrack.  The rest of the songs are demos from various points in the band's career.  All of this stuff is pretty good if you're a fan of everything else from Seether, it's just nice to have some lost gems.

This will make a great Christmas gift if you know a big Seether fan out there, or anyone who likes modern mainstream rock.  Let's give a round of applause to Seether for putting together a collection of popular songs that is solid and complete!
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This CD/DVD package is a recording of Evanescence's live performance in Paris during their 2004 world tour. Let me start off by saying I love the band's major-label debut, "Fallen", but this is really for the die-hard Evanescence fans. I did enjoy this package very much, but there were a few things that disappointed me. Here's the rundown...

CD: The band sounded excellent when I saw them in concert during the U.S. leg of this tour. Although they perform well, I don't think they sound as good live as they do on the album, unless you're actually at the concert. Don't get me wrong, the band is VERY talented and Amy Lee is an amazing vocalist, but there are several times during the show when she is struggling to hit notes. I don't think she used "studio-magic" when making "Fallen" because during the back-stage segement of the DVD, she is singing beautifully. I just think that when she runs around on stage and gets out of breath, it gets hard for her to sing as well. As for the band, they sound fine, with the exception of the guitarist still trying to keep up with the solo's Ben Moody wrote before leaving the group. Ben was an amazing guitar player...the other guys are good to but during "Going Under" the solo is a little loose and is only about a quarter of the length as it is on the album. Aside from those things, the disc is really good. The guitars and drums sound very heavy, especially on the opening song "Haunted". For this show, the band performed 10 out of the 11 songs from their "Fallen" album, as well as 2 b-sides ("Farther Away" and "Breathe No More") and even a beautiful cover of Korn's "Thoughtless". I think these songs alone are worth buying this package for. Finally, the CD ends with a previously unreleased studio track called "Missing". It's a very nice song but I wouldn't say it's one of their best ever. Pretty good overall.

DVD: This is the same performance as the one on the CD. Rather than just filming the concert with multiple cameras, lots of effects (such as slow-motion, repeating frames, blurred images) were added to make the performance more dramatic. This could be good or bad, depending on your outlook. I think it's good because it makes the performance more interesting to watch...but it could also be bad because it feels like your watching more of a music video rather than a concert. The backstage footage is pretty interesting, there's no interviews, it's just the band goofing off left and right, but it's pretty funny. You'll see brief cameos from the guys in Seether, Breaking Benjamin and Three Days Grace. Also included on this disc are the band's 4 music videos: "Bring Me To Life" / "Going Under" / "My Immortal" / "Everybody's Fool". The videos are good and it's nice to be able to watch them whenever I want.

Review:
Book 1 Consequences
This book was absolutely amazing.
For once it was so great to read a story that was not sexually based. Alethea Romig has written a novel that keeps the reader on their seat until the very end.
Claire Nichols is a young woman, stuck in a rut. She's lost her job at the local tv station, due to redundancies and is currently working as a bar tender in a local establishment.
Anthony Rawlings is the owner of Rawling Industries and has noticed and taken a liking to Claire.
That's where and when the niceties of this man ends.
This novel is a psychological thriller that will have the reader experiencing all the gamut of emotions. Ranging from fierce anger through to love and sympathy.
It is NOT a love story by any means.

Book 2 Truth
Truth continues from where Consquences left off.
Claire is now pardoned from her incarceration and is out to seek vengeance against Anthony Rawlings.
What follows is a book of mystery and intrigued.
Claire delves into Anthony's past and finds more mystery than what she originally expected.
Along with Harry Baldwin and her Close friend Courtney Simmons, she sets out to destroy the man she previously grew to love.
Once again this book contains as many twists and turns as Consequences.
Once again it is a psychological thriller that will have you not wanting to put it down.
As Claire learns more and more about the truth, she discovers that appearances are not what they seem.....something she has learnt a lot about.

Book 3 Convicted
Aleatha Romig has written a brilliant conclusion to this phenomenal series.
Convicted is written in many time frames.
It begins in the future in 2016 and then transports the reader back to when Claire is on her island paradise.
Through numerous twists and turns, that we have come to expect from Ms Romig, we are given the entire story of Anthony Rawlings, Catherine and many other characters. We see how everybody is interconnected.
Ms Romig answers many of the readers questions from Books 1 & 2, but she also introduces the reader to new questions and answers.
The novel is an unwinding puzzle right through to the very final word.
Did I come out loving Anthony Rawlings - YES!!!!!
The man changed throughout the series, however he still retained that touch of dominance.
Congratulations Aleatha Romig on an absolutely BRILLIANT and thought provoking series.
Next up the novellas from Anthony's POV.
Score:
5

Review:
I have read every book out there on Tammy Wynette and George Jones. If I was asked to compare the book Tammy's daughter Jackie Daly wrote to the one Georgette Jones wrote, I would have to say that I enjoyed Georgette's book considerably more. Although I feel that Tammy's death was surely tragic, Georgette brought her Mom "to life" in her book.  She shared many wonderful memories about Tammy, letting readers know that there was far more JOY in Tammy's life then most people think. "The Three of Us" was a wonderful, poignant read.  I could feel the love coming through Georgette's writing, and also the gripping angst she felt when things happened that were beyond her ability to control. I loved all the pictures and even felt a sort of longing to read more when I finished the book. If this talented woman decides to write any future books, I would definitely want to read them. Thanks for sharing your life with your Mom and Dad with us, Georgette!  It was a total reading pleasure.
