Review:
Okay before you look at this anime's title and roll your eyes with "been there, done that" theatrics, allow me to immediately put your mind at ease: This is not simply an animated version of the classic Shakespeare play.  Instead what we have is a uniquely animated drama based loosely on the classic source material from anime masters, Gonzo.

Released for the first time ever on DVD, Romeo x Juliet from Funimation breaks the 24 total episodes into a pair of two-disc sets.  The first of which (reviewed here) is known as The Romeo Collection and contains episodes 1-12.  Packaged within an appropriately artistically decorated cardboard exterior slipcase is a pair of thin disc cases each containing a single dvd (with 6 episodes on each).

Total runtime comes in at 290 minutes and the show wears a conservative TV PG (13+) rating, based presumably more on the grander adult oriented themes (we do all know how this tale will end) than it is language, sexual scenarios, or gore.

Language options are standard fair sub & dub meaning the original Japanese dialog track is presented (in stereo) as well as the option of instead watching an English dub (in Dolby Surround 5.1).  Finally English subtitles are available with either vocal option.

To paraphrase the opening set-up:  The story takes place once upon a time, in the sky continent known as New Verona where the all-powerful ability to hover in the distant sky breathes life and prosperity upon the people. However, foolish passions will someday transcend eternity. Now let me introduce to you the tragic story of innocent pure love tormented by fate in the midst of chaos, Romeo and Juliet.

In the event that this doesn't help you understand the story better, imagine a blend of European 1600s culture with some mythological elements peppered about for greater intrigue.  The main source of transportation on New Verona happens to be winged horses and let us not forget that this continent is in fact floating high in the sky.

Just like with the play, Gonzo structured the classic Montague versus Capulet struggle as the immediate and driving force of the prose.  However the show does take some interesting liberties fairly early on in the form of young Juliet donning a wig and mask to pose as a male superhero who delivers justice in a severely corrupted and hierarchal society.

The star-crossed lover angle between the lead characters takes little time in starting but develops quite slowly; oftentimes painfully so.  There is little doubt that this show could have succeeded as a 12 or more-standard 13-episode show but was pushed to 24 due to Japanese broadcast television specifics.  As such, expect some story threads to fizzle out and others to drag on needlessly.

In the spans where things are progressing smoothly, the lead characters and their motivations are quite well done (save perhaps for the few times a wig can completely baffle everyone to the fact that Juliet is a female; especially when Romeo and his winged horse encounter the "male" version).
Visuals are definitely high budget Gonzo territory and this fact is clear nearly immediately.  The character cells maintain a sort of washed out appearance that adds to the feel of antiquity to the equation while the backgrounds are lavish and rich with impressive lighting effects throughout.

Sound work is solid with a dub that succeeds on some levels but fails at others.  A very deliberate approach was taken early on by the voice talents to eliminate the old-English speaking style of the original work but then often (and out of nowhere) a character will slip into a bit of cliché old style of speaking only to nearly as quickly recover.  The Japanese audio avoids these pitfalls entirely but comes off as lackluster in some of the key critical moments.  Choose your poison, as it were.

Music score is very appropriate with nice fluctuations at the tense moments and subtle inflections when things get delicate.  In all I came into the show with hopes of Gonzo having duplicated the effort that made Gankutsuou work compared to Alexander Dumas' Count of Monte Cristo.  Unfortunately, it appears as though the problem with Romeo x Juliet is that the source material on which it is based was simply too ambitious from the onset.  In effort to make a modernized tale of the Shakespeare play feasible, blown tender moments and miscued romantic scenarios were perhaps inevitable.  Still, you have to give Gonzo credit for even attempting such a feat.  In the end it comes off more as a minor derailment than a total train wreck.  However, suburb visuals, smooth music work, and deliberate pacing may make this one worth looking into regardless of how it compares to the source material.

Review: This is a short term review, I've owned these for only 3 days and just want to get my initial thoughts out. I'll update later if necessary. If you're like me you've read way to many reviews on these and got a lot of mixed messages so I thought I'd clear the air. Comfort: They're not comfortable. I'm an adult with a medium sized head and they're a tad too big on me after adjusting them to the smallest size. They are still wearable but not an ideal fit. They are also a little heavy. After a few hour or longer gaming sessions I'd have to take them off for periods. The Sound: I currently have a Bose 5.1 setup. (those mini double speakers) These sound about the same as it. If you're using your tv speakers you'll be blown away but if you already have a good sound system don't expect much. Though I was geeking out when I plugged them into my PC and got to hear the difference between my stereo 10 year old harmon/kardon's and these. I do wish these headphones had more base. They have a little but they are certainly not as good as the beats by dre headphones I've tried out. Also one little tid bit, the high pitch sounds come in almost too loud. On one of the songs I listened to anytime they pronounced an S word the S sound was almost painful. Maybe good for footsteps but not music. One thing I'll give these headphones over my 5.1 setup is you can place sounds extremely well. In Bf3 I got a nice extra kill hearing someone behind me. Also someone mentioned a .2 sec or something delay in the sound - the sound comes out at the exact same time as my regular speakers so ignore that. Current setup, HDMI to receiver for my home sound, then the separate dongle with optical out (xbox 360) into the XP500 for headphones sound. You can have both on at once. Batteries: They eat your controller batteries (xbox 360) if you do the wireless chat as well as having a demand on the headphone batteries. You plug a blue tooth thing into the controller which lets you talk via xbox live and it eats up your controller batteries. The headset also takes 2 double A batteries. I ordered a wired talkback cable Turtlebeach X31/X41/X11/PX21/PX5/XP400/XP500 Xbox Live Talkback Cable Puck Black (TB450-2181-01) Official Replacement Cable NEW to try and help with the battery thing. I'll update if it helps. As soon as you unplug the blue tooth the controller low battery indicator goes away. Rechargeable batteries don't keep as much juice as fresh new batteries and mine were just not lasting at all... Update: the talkback cable preserves your controller batteries pretty well. Use it instead of the Bluetooth. Wireless Interference?: I have Verizon Fios and their wireless router with my wifi PC, wireless mouse and keyboard and they all work just fine with the headset in use. THOUGH, if I walk to the other side of the room the headset will start picking up static. Also a funny little bit, if I connect my phone to the wifi and start browsing pages on my phone, the headset will pick up static each time a new page loads. So I guess it depends on what you have for wifi in your house. Setup: I felt it was kind of limited. You have to use Optical cable to the wireless transmitter for surround sound. It has an Optical in and an Optical out. It also has the old Red and White in for stereo sound. I believe you can hook your headphones up wired if you get a toslink to toslink optical cable (or you can buy adapters) It looks like headphone cable end except it has an optical tip. That's how I setup my PC to use its sound. I have an iMac and all apple pc headphone jacks double as toslink optical cable outputs. (I'm not an apple buff, I'm currently running windows on this thing, just had to mention) And of course for power there's a usb to transmitter wire. Oh and you can only have one wireless headset hooked up, you can do another wired but one is the max for wireless on the transmitter. Max 2, one wired, one wireless. Oh, I did fail to mention it has blue tooth so you can connect it with your phone and play music on it that way. Pretty cool. Hold the blue tooth button down on the headset when turning on blue tooth mode and it should say blue tooth pairing (or turn it off first). Then look for it on your phone. It uses the chat (blue tooth) volume control, not the main one. Programmable: Don't care, haven't tried. Btw presets are just bad. I was thinking about returning them but I'll probably just hold on to them. I mean they work so why not, can't say I'd recommend them to anyone though. If you just want to spoil yourself and don't care about the money then maybe. That's where I was when I bought them. :) But don't expect them to redefine sound for you if you already have a good speaker setup. Score:

Review:
My "thing" has always been organization (especially before having kids).  Diagnosed with OCD (obsessive compulsive disorder), I feel the need to put everything in a specific place in a specific order.  I am especially particular about my kitchen spaces.  After working in restaurants for over a decade, my kitchen is my place of zen.  So when asked if I'd be willing to review the Silicone Stove Counter Gap Cover by Kohzie in exchange for a discount, I quickly agreed.

Nothing drives me more nuts than when food drips into any crack I can't easily clean it from let alone the side of the stove.  When it drops down there, it requires me to move my oven completely out of it's cubby space and clean.  Well needless to say since I knew I had spilled a ton of rice down the side a few days prior when my glass bowl holding it shattered, I still had to move everything out and thoroughly clean the area.  When we did this I was beyond disgusted AND thrilled to have the new gap covers to try and keep things like this from happening again.

These arrived made of a thick quality silicone material which matched my black stove and black granite counter top.  Because my stove is so large and the space it has to fit in is barely big enough for the stove, we did have a bit of a struggle getting these into place in a way.  My husband had to tip the stove up as much as possible while I pushed the cover into place and then again on the opposite side.  They worked though perfectly and are not moving or shifting anytime soon!  I love being able to wipe the surface clean easily and it acts as a ledge of sorts too keeping spills to the top of the stove only.  For $18 these are well worth your purchase and I am thinking of scooping them up for my mother now too!

Review:
I was pretty excited about it when Jollylife asked me to review their Silicone Non-stick Healthy Cooking Baking Mat in exchange for a discount.  I had been shopping around for something similar not too long ago and had given up on finding one.  It never fails, the kids complain about their chicken fingers being soggy on one side or the fries we bake just aren't crunchy all the way around.  I really wasn't too sure about this one and whether or not it would truly work especially if I tried my homemade fries but I was psyched to give it a try.

The minute this arrived we decided the kids needed to have some chicken fries and tater tots for lunch over spring break to test it out.  To my surprise this actually worked.  Because the air gets all the around the food instead of the food sitting flat on a pan, the entire piece of chicken (fries, etc.) gets cooked all the way around.  I noticed an obvious difference with the first batch although the kids didn't say a thing about it.  I will say if you use a lot of seasoning or something that drips easily this does require a bit more cleaning than other pans or silicone mats but nothing that a simple dish scrubby won't solve.  I haven't had an opportunity to make my own fries yet but I am even more psyched now.  Plus with the inexpensive cost being under $10 I think this is totally worth the purchase.

Review:
My constant 'serious' reading companion for some six weeks, this is a book I have thoroughly enjoyed reading. Demanding and rewarding close attention, this is a spellbinding biography from Leonie Frieda that makes for as compulsive reading as any fictional thriller. It demands close attention not because of any shortcoming in the writing style of Frieda, but rather because of the capricious, labyrinthine, lives of the principle characters. Wife to a king, mother to three others, Catherine's life is far more complex than that of the other dominant woman of the 16th.century , Elizabeth Tudor, encompassing, as it does in the period of her widowhood, nine French Wars of Religion. Superb and fascinating reading that is highly satisfying.

Review:
Widely regarded as the standard biography of Oliver Cromwell, I must have read this book for the first time some thirty years ago. Since then I have re-read it three or four times, but unfortunately, like the first time, without a great deal of pleasure. Put bluntly I find Antonia Frasers writing style downright tedious. There can be little doubt that her research is extremely thorough, regrettably she chooses to unload every last scrap of her researches onto the page like some school student over-eager to showcase the full extent of their knowledge. This is evidently common to much of Frasers work. Recently I heard her on BBC radio, reading from her autobiography, everything she attempted to describe was lost in a welter of elaboration and qualification.  Some reviewers criticise Fraser for a  pro-Cromwell bias. Contrary to this view I find there is barely a topic covered where Fraser does not display a strong subliminal pro-Royalist agenda. It is to be hoped that one day a far better writer will accept the challenge of writing a truly definitive biography of one of British history's most interesting and important figures.

Review:
This time of year, I find myself baking with nuts fairly often.  One thing I hate is that I end up having to pull stuff out to chop them, and it seems that it means I almost always have dirty stuff from chopping 1/4 cup of nuts here, 1/3 cup there.  And I end up needing to grab a ziploc or something to store the unused nuts.

This package solves both of those problems.  I can use just a little bit, seal up the bag, and have it ready next time too.  I don't have to chop either, depending on what I am doing (sometimes I like a bit finer chop than these are).

Fisher always seems to have a good-tasting product, and this is not an exception.

I think what I like best, though, is that with this, I feel a lot more willing to do something like add a teaspoon of chopped nuts to a bowl of oatmeal.  No muss, no fuss.

Review:
What I like:  These taste exactly like what I try to do when I make oatmeal.  Nice and thick, without powdery filler.  Nice chunks of fruit.  Great texture.  Sweet.  Very easy to prepare -- I put water on to boil in the teakettle, shake the package up, add water to just above the oats, and let it sit for a few minutes.  I always end up letting it sit longer than the recommended three minutes, and it always is wonderful.  The oats don't turn to mush, the fruit almost tastes fresh.

What I don't like:  currently, at almost $18 for a six-pack, this is more than I can spend for breakfast (there are six of us in my home). I think I am going to keep some of these on hand for that.  Well, not from THIS six-pack, as I finished it off tonight so I could write this review.  Also, this is a bit sweeter than I would prefer.

Review:
and I expected a bit more attention to be given to editing in order to put her best foot forward. The book has a good concept: lonely wife tempted by a single dad of a child in her own kids class. So, first off, we are disliking the heroine a bit. She becomes a cheater. But beyond that, she separates from her husband and soon after, the new boyfriend is staying overnight in her home (shes still MARRIED) where her three young daughters are also sleeping. Okay, shes a bad wife, and a bad mother. I feel a little sorry for her, but then the author makes her heroine give a snide comment about drivers of hybrid vehicles. Yikes! Way to piss off the huge automobile industry!

There were quite a few holes and inconsistencies in the story. Example: first the truck had wrapped around a tree, then it was wrapped around a stop sign, and later it was mentioned it was wrapped around a tree. So was it a tree or a stop sign? In Chapter 27, there is mentioned to be candles lit everywhere, which it would need to be dark to see these, right? Right after, its mentioned His sunglasses, but it doesnt say WHAT about the sunglasses, whether they're on the face, peeking out of a pocked, or hanging at the neck. Anyway, if there are sunglasses, there is also sun, right? Well, then the lit candles are mentioned again. A professional editor would have caught and fixed these problems.

There were problems on every single page of this book. Im told there were beta readers that caught a lot of mistakes, but beta readers are not meant to be editors, and the mistakes were still numerous, too numerous to count. I didn't mark all of the mistakes, but marked enough so I could make my point. If I had marked them all, I would expect to be paid as an editor. Im not a good editor, but I am a reader with a sharp eye who knows when theres been no editor at all.

The problems included the following:

*Misspelled words, misuse of words, wrong homonym, and several other similar problems.
-Mouse in his brown hair, instead of mousse
-Her breathing became rugged, instead of ragged
-The character Kristinas name was spelled Christina once
-Knick in his neck, instead of crick
-Machine beeps louder, more consistent, instead of insistent
-Giving met support I need, instead of me the
-Twuntwhat IS that? I couldn't figure it out. Nickname, maybe? It was only used once and not explained.
-Dialed brown eyes, instead of dilated
-Extend of his injuries, instead of extent
-Couldnt bare the thought, instead of bear

*Could care lesscommon misuse of the phrase couldn't care lessI wouldnt mind this as much if it was only used once in dialogue, as in the character misusing the phrase, but it was also used in the narrative.

*Capitalization mistakes

*Punctuation mistakes

*Paragraphs are chapter-length, and are not broken up between dialogue of different characters. Many times I lost who was saying what.

*Similar problem with phone conversations. The way they were shown were the same as how texting was shown. I didn't know if it was a conversation or texting, or who was saying what.

*Run-on sentences. And on. And on. And on. Run-on paragraphs?

*Tense changed randomly back and forth between past and present.

*Contraction useHe lets go and sits down, instead of lets.

That, by no means, is a comprehensive list, but only a taste. A professional editor would have caught and fixed all of these problems. Im begging the author to pull the publishing of this book and rework it. If I had paid for this book and didn't consider the author a friend, I would have returned it before the second chapter.

Ava, DO NOT QUIT WRITING. Live the dream. Care enough about the words you're putting out to the world to baby them and give them all the care necessary for your readers to like what you're doing. You have successfully published a book. I can only imagine how good it would feel inside for people to really like what youve written. I hope youll take this review as the loving kick in the pants you need to get an editor.

Youve said English is your second language, and thats all the more reason to be impressed by you, but also the biggest reason to have an editor with a better grasp of English. ESL is not an excuse to publish a book full of English grammar errors. Never in my life will I even ATTEMPT to publish a book in German. Im still working on that first book in my first language, English, but Im also going to use an editor, and get as many eyeballs on the manuscript as possible before its released to the world.

I received a copy of this book from the author in exchange for an honest review.

Sadly, 1.5 stars...

Review:
I am discovering that every single Choc Lit book goes in the re-readable category. This is another hit from Kathryn Freeman that provides laughter, tears (GOD, the tears! There is a spot in the book where it states that Tess is not crying, but *I* was! This book causes serious leaking of the eyes, which then rain down your face.), spontaneous grinning from ear to ear, and a continuing education for this American in British slang and other words different than over here. Seriously...HOMELY, in this book does not mean ugly. I thought it was a typo, but NO! The British definition of homely is the American word homey.

After coming out of the crying haze, I was so hungover from this book, I couldn't write my review. So, here I am today, several days out, still feeling like I just read this romance novel with an alpha male, but a really strong heroine who holds her own with him. I will read this book again. And maybe again.

I received a copy of this book from the publisher through NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

Review:
When Elspeth's friend Brydda and his fellow rebels seem to be pushing for war against the council, many of the misfits feel that they should be joining in the fighting. After all the council has been hunting people with misfit talents and burning them at the stakes for years. So when Maryon, a member of the futureteller guild, sees Elspeth traveling to Sutrium, where the rebels are stationed, Elspeth and Rushton realize that this is the time to strike. Elspeth has another task on her hand, returning a gypsy woman to her people. Elspeth soon realizes that neither of these tasks will be solved easily. The gypsy woman is dying, and Elspeth doesn't know where to find her people. Worse yet is the rebels. Very few of them are willing to accept misfits with powers as their allies. It looks like the only way that they can be convinced is if the misfits prove themselves, a very dangerous task indeed.
I absolutely loved this book. After The Farseekers, I didn't think that the series could get much better. I was wrong. Not only is Ashling the longest book in the series so far but it's defiantly the best. Characters that were introduced in the last two books have really grown and developed into different people completely. The most obvious is Domick, the coercer who's job at the council has turned him cold and heartless to everyone, even his own bondmate. The plot is fast paced and exciting. There is rarely a dull moment in this 450+ page wonder. Another perk is the new places that your introduced to. Not only Sutrium but in another country entirely (read the book if you want to find out). Amazing revelations are made about the beforetimers that are strikingly prophetic to our own world. Isobelle Carmody ends up telling an amazing fantasy story while weaving in serious question about the lives we live ourselves.

Review:
In the country of Bamarre there live two Princesses, as different as night and day. One of them Addie is timid and shy but loves no one more than her sister Meryl. Her sister Meryl is strong, stubborn and brave. Meryl's life mission is to one day find the cure for the grey death, a plague that kills people very quickly. Addie only wishes to stay safe inside her palace but her wish is not granted. When her sister is sticken with the grey death she knows she has to do something. But when this something turns out to be leaving her home and finding the cure, facing specters and dragons she finds it hard to deal. Even with the help of a sorceror. Can she save her sister? Or will she be too timid to follow through.
I found this book to be very impressive. It was entertaining to see Addie's transfomration through the book from timid little sister, to something more. I reccomend it to fans of Levine's 1st book Ella Enchanted. I hope you enjoyed it as much as I did. The only complaint I has was some parts where a tad bit predictable. Other than that it was great. Enjoy!

Review:
The idea of an emergency tool with the ability to break a car window and cut a seatbelt when necessary seems like a good idea.  But this device is quite bulky and after carrying it in my pocket for a week I gave up.  The "siren" mode is loud enough to be annoying but not loud enough to be useful.  The flashlight and red blinker can be turned on easily by accident -- it takes just the lightest touch on a button.  After the week it spent in my pocket the battery was dead.

I can't say whether the window tool works because it is one of those things that you really can't test.  The tempered glass in car side windows and the laminated glass in windshields are expensive and inconvenient to replace, and testing it on ordinary window glass wouldn't tell you how it would perform in a car.  I have not been able to test the air pressure guage because the battery went dead.  Similarly, I have not tried to cut a seatbelt.  But my rating of the product at two stars is not based on my inability to test these features.  It is based on it's bulk and the fact that I could not rely on the battery to be working when needed.

Review:
Somewhat disappointing entry in a, to this point, fine series. Part of it may be bad marketing. The back cover intimates that the O'Brien family goes to war over Doc Holliday. A guest at Dromore and under their protection, a bereaved father demands he be turned over to be hung. Honor precludes Shamus O'Brien from not protecting a guest even though he doesn't personally like the man.

It was self defense on Holliday's part and he only wants to get to the sanitarium where he will die of consumption. The father swears war will break out if he doesn't get Holliday.

It never happens. Last minute changes must have been made in the manuscript that didn't get to the cover people. In the narrative, the father is Colonel James Stuart, an Irishman that served in the Confederate army just as Shamus O'Brien did. But the back cover says his name is Colonel Robert NcHenry.

The main plot is an Aberdeen bull named Bonnie Prince Charlie gifted to Shamus by Queen Elizabeth. He sends Luther Ironside and one of his sons, Shawn, to pick the bull up. It gets stolen and the pair set out to find it with the Englishman sent to deliver it and his daughter.

Shawn gets badly wounded and the hunt stops. The bull is never found, dying of neglect by the thieves, not willing to lower themselves to cowboy work. Johnny Sligo and Black Tom Church are the two gun men and Jacob is left to deal with Sligo. But even there a little Jewish peddler, who has popped in and out of the story, saves the day.

The worst entry in this fine series.

This brand was mentioned in several of the thousands of reviews, or was it hundreds of thousands, I read when deciding what grain-free kibble to switch my adopted dog-boy to.  When I got him from the local Humane Society, they said to feed him grain free food.  The prices of grain-free products are ludicrous, and I've never had a dog that required grain-free before, so I ignored that advice.  He developed a very small hot-spot under one front leg maybe a year after I brought him home with me, but I was able to keep it in check and I never made the connection, so, no problem.  Then I picked up a sack of turkey chunk kibble and everything went to hell.  He broke out in rashes in all sorts of places and scratched everywhere around the clock.  You'll find my other reviews in Curoseb, SynergyLabs Veterinary Formula Clinical Care shampoo, Sulfodene Wound Care related to that ordeal (with props to Desitin and Benadryl).

The Merrick Lamb & Sweet Potato kibble is apparently yummy.  He'll finish his serving and lick the bowl for a very long time after it's gone. The feeding instructions for his weight seem a little high, since it sure looks like he's put on some weight at just a little under the recommended daily rate.  I can't be sure yet, but it appears that this 25# bag will hold him for a month. He's been eating it for 9 days, and, with all the shampooing, topicals, underdoses of Benadryl, and this food, his allergic reaction seems to be almost completely gone.  The ingredient list and manufacturing process both sound pretty fantastic, so despite the expense, I am delighted.  I will likely make more purchases, maybe the buffalo and/or salmon, too.  (Anyone know where a retired old girl can get a job and pick up some cash? lol)
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This was purchased following what ended up being my dog-boy's allergic reaction to a chunky turkey kibble (with grain).

There is almost nothing he hates more than getting wet, whether it's rain, the spray-bottle I use to train all my beasts to stay out of the kitchen during food prep (theirs or mine), and BATHS!  A tease will get me ears up when I ask, "You wanna?" until I get to the end of the question with "bath?"

It had to be done.  At first, I wasn't sure about the reason for the rashes and even more damaging scratching he was doing, and he had started to really smell bad.  He hated every minute of it - and so did I.  The instructions say to "allow" it to remain on the beast for 10-15 minutes after lathering, but *insisting* would have been more accurate.  I had to bathe him twice within 2 weeks because the other things I was doing were not effective fast enough.  I got smarter about protecting surfaces from frequent shake-offs in my one and only bathroom tub, and he didn't seem to mind as much the second time.  He actually may have appreciated how good his skin felt afterwards.  He acted like he did.

Once calm had been restored each time, the stink was gone, the gunk from a couple different medications was gone, and his fur was fluffy and soft - even the coarse guard hairs to some degree. As everything in my yard was suffering from some kind of mildew and/or fungus last summer, and while there probably aren't any fungi that are transferable to animals, it became my final choice based upon the description and the reviews.  It certainly didn't harm him in any way, and now I'm prepared for any future fungal or bacterial infections.

Review:
Ah, Charles Band. The master of low budget horror with a cast of demonic creatures and barely-talented actors. This film is so-bad-it's-good. Anna Sophia Berglund is easy on the eyes and quite enjoyable in this film. Basically, a quasi-Leprechaun figure -- more sympathetic than scary -- and other creatures get involved in a talent/beauty reality show being filmed at a mansion in Los Angeles. It's all pretty low budget, oddly-paced, and poorly acted, but somehow it's just a guilty pleasure, empty-calorie, enjoyable film. A deluxe version of this DVD came with a Lucky Charms the cereal-esque ripoff cereal (grain and colored marshmallows), which I thought was cool (if ultimately perishable (?)). (This isn't that product.) If you like horror-comedy, hot but ditzy women, cheap CGI, and so-bad-they're-good films, this may be your Citizen Kane. A cult classic in the making, I suspect.

Review:
Overall, I enjoyed this. I'm not really part of the Chucky cult following, so I'm pretty objective. After a rough and cheesy start, I think this film starts getting good from the chili dinner scene onward. Chucky is like the Leprechaun, or an evil Santa or murderous Easter Bunny: something (a doll) we previously thought harmless, but full of harm. And, like the Leprechaun, Chucky has a sense of sarcasm and insult. Even though it's set in the ol' low-budget setting of one single setting for the most part, it keeps the viewer engaged, and ties things back to the first Child's Play film. It has a few jumpscare moments, and is mostly well-filmed and executed. It seems to have a level of quality for what it is that's impressive given it's the sixth film in a long franchise. Chucky's atheism and bleak philosophy on life (told via his little girl friend, Alice) is a high point.

Review:
I did not expect to be the first person to review this great product, but here goes.

The system shipped and arrived before the scheduled date. I used to to sharpen my 20 year old Benchmade Stryker Auto and was very impressed with the results. Called a friend and said, "Bring me some knives!" He showed up with a pile of +50 year old forged Bowie knives and other knives that were in very bad shape. He said he bought a box full of knives from some old guy for $20 and the guy said he had them for a long time. They all took a lot of work to bring them to a decent edge, but they all are now razor sharp. Since I recently moved, I had no knives, so I went to the store and bought a set of cheap non-serrated steak knives and got them cutting like scalpels. I also needed some kitchen knives, so a bought a few cheap ones. All are now sharp and usable without a lot of effort.

CONS: Is this device perfect? In a word, no. Let's talk about the faults for a moment.

1. The swivels tend to stick sometimes, but a little oil on them and they loosen right up. I can't complain about that. I can't expect the swivels to work without some lubrication.

2. The vice attaches to the stone base with two machine screws with grommets on the bottom of the base. This forces you to use stick-on rubber feet at the corners. These stick-on feet do not stick very well on the rough surface of the bottom of the stone. Had the bottom been polished like the top and sides, they might stick better. I would have preferred to see the holes for the screws countersunk so the screws sit flush with the bottom surface, and that would allow a full sheet of non-slip rubber (shelf liner) on the bottom of the base. I will probably make this modification myself, but it should have been right from the factory. This is minor and not worth taking away a star.

3. With the price of this unit, it should have come with the Low Angle Adapter. You cannot sharpen a knife with a small blade, such as a classic multi-blade pocket knife without this adapter. The adapter cost ~$70. Still, I knew this in advance and I will not remove a star for it.

PROS: They got a lot right. This is a well thought out machine. I believe this is the third generation.

1. Set the thing on the table, grab a chair and get to work. It takes some time to get the bevel right from the hilt to the tip of the blade, but it is not hard work. Once you get finished with the 100 grit, you will progress through the others in order very quickly.

2. There is a ruler that attaches to the dual pin alignment tool. Use this, so that you can record how each knife is setup. This will allow you to get repeatable results the next time you sharpen the same knife. This way, you won't have to start with the 100 grit. You will be able to just start with the higher grits and do a quick touch up. As a tip, each time I do an original sharpening on a knife, I set it in the vice with the ruler and take a good photo of it. I name the photo of the knife with the brand, model, where the tip measures on the ruler, whether I used the top or bottom hole, and what angle settings I used. I then organize these photos in a folder with the owner's name.

3. The stones that the device comes with will be all that the average person will need. I seem to be doing a bunch of heavy Bowie knives and they need a lot of metal removed, so I did order the 50/80 set of stones to hog off that metal a lot faster. BUT, these are all diamond impregnated steel and they cut very aggressively. They remove a lot of metal in a hurry. These are not your grand dad's whetrock. Unlike other devices that use stones that don't stay flat, these are metal and they will remain flat and function properly for a long long time. TIP: Wipe down the blade before switching to the next finer grit. This is very important.

4. Leather strops are available and I did purchase these and use them with diamond paste. For most knives, I don't need them. Only a few knives really need the show polished edge. Regular old butcher knife? No. Filet knife? Yes. Steak knives? No. Your everyday carry pocket knife? Yes. If you buy the strops, PLEASE store each one in a separate zip lock baggie. You do not want them to touch each other and contaminate the different micron diamond compounds. I cannot stress this enough. Wipe down the blade between each progression to a finer grit to keep from contaminating the compounds. The compounds imbed themselves into the leather of the strop, so if they get contaminated with a different grit, you will have to throw that strop away. These things are way too expensive to be tossing them in the trash because of user error.

DANGEROUS: Use extreme caution when sharpening knives.

1. If you have children, setup in an area where you can keep them out. The same goes for pets.

2. You are going to be working in a moving pattern just an inch or less from the edge of a sharp blade. Be careful. Be sober. Get "cut resistant gloves" and use them every time. Repeat, EVERY TIME! I recommend these. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0119UBIYG?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00 They are soft, flexible, comfortable, washable, and there is no reason that you should ever sharpen knives without them.

3. Don't reach over the knife that you are working on. Setup your work area so that everything can be in easy reach without having to get close to the sharp blades. Your blades will be sharp enough to cut to the bone with little to no force.

4. Do not sharpen knives if you are taking medication that might make you drowsy. Do not sharpen knives if you are drinking alcohol. Do not sharpen knives if you are not in a good mood and able to completely focus on the task at hand. If you feel distracted, stop! It's just not worth the risk.

5. Setup your work area with good lighting from multiple directions. Get a big (5 inch) magnifying glass to inspect the edge as you work. I use one like this. http://www.amazon.com/Carson%C2%AE-SureGrip-Acrylic-Magnifier-SG-14/dp/B0013KMW8Y/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1452291708&sr=8-6&keywords=magnifying+glass

Would I buy this thing again? Absolutely! It was expensive and I had to really think about it before spending that much money, but after using it for several days and sharpening a bunch of knives of different quality, I feel like it was worth every penny. I am planning on doing some sharpening services, and also some knife restoration services, so this device will easily pay for itself. For the average person that only needs to sharpen their own knives, there are cheaper devices such as the Lansky that will fill the need. If you want to professionally sharpen blades for some extra money (like me) or as a full-time job, this is probably the best way to get consistent "knife show quality" results.

NOTE: If you are planing to setup a permanent work area, and you can mount the vice directly to the workbench, then you can get the unit without a base and save yourself some money. If not, this stone base is very heavy and makes this unit very stable.

5

Review:
One of these was broken when I received the package. The tip had fallen out of the handle. Of course it was the only one I needed out of the pack. Simply a bad case of quality control.

I was quite disappointed in this set of TEKTON screwdrivers. I have one single 3.8mm straight blade in my Telecom/Ethernet tool kit at work. I don't know where it came from but I have had it for many years. It has been hammered on. It has been grabbed with pliers to get more torque on it. It has been used as a tiny crowbar. It has been a tough little screwdriver and it is one of my prized possessions. I really expected this set to live up to the reputation of that one old TEKTON screwdriver that I had.

Same Day Update: Russ from TEKTON saw this review and he has gotten with me to take care of this. I am impressed. :-)  I will update this review again after resolution.

I emailed Russ a couple of photos of the offending screwdriver, the set, and the fresh packaging and he promised to make it good. He is a man of his word. Russ shipped me a new set of TEKTON screwdrivers. They arrived today and I am happy with the quality of them. Every one of them is well fitted and none are loose. Russ did right by me and now, I will return the favor. I am editing this review to show that TEKTON made good on their product.

I understand that things slip by the Quality Control Department. It happens. If I had not stated here that I got a bad screwdriver, then TEKTON would not have known. They would not have had the chance to make it right. I am quite impressed that they have someone looking for reviews of these products and trying to contact dissatisfied customers. They wasted no time getting to the bottom of the problem and fixing it. That is what good customer service is all about.

If you received a bad set of these and you are not pleased with them, feel free to reply to Russ' comment on this review and give him a chance to make you happy.

Review:
First of all this track is a load of fun for younger kids and its great that it is expandable and can be added to a much larger track system.  You will not be disappointed with it if your kids are into hot wheels cars.

With that said I do have one major gripe, why did they not include another car in the package?  I mean it probably costs hotwheels Co. less than 50 cents to add another car and yet they make a track system that requires two cars for it to be useful and then give you only one!  Arggg oh well, just remember to order another car if your child does not have one available already.

So the way this track works, is that one car goes from the top tower and can trigger the launch of two more cars as it goes down the track.  Depending on how you assembled the track you can end up with different configurations of how each of the cars will exit the track and what they will do.  As I said before, you can join this into another set your child may have, so think of this track as a kind of nexus hub that can make a normal track layout much more interesting.  If you don't have another track it is still great because the layout is large and interesting on its own.  Just don't look for collisions etc. its not designed to be a smash up track but more of hub for creating interaction between multiple cars.

I am sorry that I had to take off one star on this one, because it is a really good toy, but it was very frustrating on the first night when we finally got it all setup and both of us realized that another car was needed to make any of the magic happen.  Once you know that your experience will be a lot more pleasant than ours because you will know to buy a second car.

Review:
Got this for my Son and he is having loads of fun recording things with it.
So far he has used it on his Hotwheels Track and that was no end of fun as he got a drivers eye view like a real race car driver, so he was thrilled with that.  He then moved on to using it as a probe for checking into small areas, he attached a string to the car and taped his little LED flashligh on it and proceeded to explore every hole he could find in the Yard, I was fearful that he might lose the car so I put a stop to that but I must say some of the video was very interesting, I had no idea what was in these little caves so it was cool to see inside.

In regards to video it's really pretty good, it's even better than I would expect on a $50 Toy.

Construction:  It's well built, it's lasted out it's first week and with my Son that's the ultimate test of Garbage VS Quality.  So I give the car and camera system high marks for quality.

Review:
This review will likely be updated as I continue to test this phone.

After about 3 years of using Samsung A930 and Verizon's $[...] payment to continue with their plan, and another $[...] rebate from LG, I have switched to LG-VX11000 at a final price of $[...].

Why?

Because the battery life with the Samsung phone was reduced to less than a day, and even after buying a new battery, it seemed to discharge very quickly. Secondly, writing the obligatory LOLs or OMGs without a QWERTY keyboard was really getting annoying, but this is strictly a secondary reason.

I looked at other Samsung phones, but the one I liked--the one with the eInk keyboard--did not have microUSB charger...it had its own charger. One lesson learned from the past is that chargers must be standardized, and microISB seems like a fair attempt at that. This LG phone use this standard, so it's easy and cheap to get a charger from a local general store. Coolness of eInk cannot surpass that.

Many other reviews have mentioned many cool things about this phone, but one perspective I'd like to bring to table that maybe new is this: When the phone is unfolded partially it seems to create a sound barrier to keep ambient noise out of the conversation.

UPDATE: (Sep. 26, 2010)
It's been a year now and I must say I continue to love this phone. I did come across a bit of an annoyance and found a fix relatively quickly. However I didn't see the fix in the Internet, so I decided to add this little note: It is possible that when you insert your MicroSD card, the phone does not recognize the memory card, and may say "CARD NOT INSERTED". At this point, simply take out the battery to let the phone reset itself such that it will recognize the card once you put the battery back in. I hope this is helpful for others.

Review:
I wanted to get a phone with a QWERTY keyboard and all those bells and whistles, which I wouldn't use but it looked cool. The truthiness of the necessity of buying such a phone got demolished by the price tag and I had to resort to something else that merely, yet completely, satisfied all of my needs. I settled on this phone: Samsung A930.

It is not without its disappointments, which mainly reside beyond the everything-you-need realm. Any criticism I have revolves around the Bluetooth technology. It would have been nice to hook up the phone to my computer via Bluetooth, however, the Verizon system with Samsung seem adamant to not allow this. USB cable, which you can buy from Verizon for $30 extra, however, works great and works great with a freeware software called BitPim, simply Google it and download the setup. This tool downloads/uploads everything from/to your phone: pictures, contacts, etc. I am also disappointed with most Bluetooth headphones. The ultimate test is with headphones inside a car while driving.

Samsung A930 has a lot of community support. The most impressive web site I found is ([...]). The discussion thread talks about secret menus, etc. Also more useful topics about Bluetooth, voice memo, camera usage among other things.

The camera, by the way, aside from taking snapshots and video stream, has a flash for taking better pictures.

Because of this camera's versatility and price, I bought another one for my wife. Having the same camera in the family has the added benefit of sharing the same charger, headphones, battery, USB cable, and memory cards.

I have been testing this phone for three days now and I haven't had to recharge it during this time.

Best regards.

Addendum: Nov. 28, 2008. I'm still using this phone and it's working great! Never once have I been temped to buy an iPhone because of this phone's performance.

Addendum: Saturday Aug. 8, 2009, the batteries (including a new one) don't seem to last more than a day after being fully charged. I'm switching over to LG VX-11000. A930 served me well over the years and as a phone it is great. Its robustness--that it didn't break even when dropped on the floor many times--had been its greatest strength.

Review:
What this is: an in-line GFCI "switch" for standard house voltage

This GFCI comes with clear and concise instructions for installation.  You can use a standard switch box with a rectangular face plate to install this.  It was fairly easy to install.

This unit is much like the plug receptacles that have a GFCI built-in, except it provides GFCI protection for all the circuits down-stream from it and has a 20 amp rating.  I was installing a water sterilizer in our well system, to do that I added in a box with one switched receptacle and 2 non-switched receptacles.  All three - and the switch - now protect the user from shock.  The sterilizer required GFCI, and I felt near the well works that all powered applications should be protected.

Review:
I loved this novel!  This is my 2nd occasion to spend time with characters in the Whiskey Creek Series following my first introduction to Whiskey Creek by reading Take Me Home for Christmas.  As I read the last page I wanted to get in my vehicle and drive to Whiskey Creek so I could spend more time with all of the characters but particularly with Presley Christensen.

The story begins as Presley (or Pres for short) has moved back to Whiskey Creek with her infant son Wyatt after a 2-year absence.  On the professional side of life, Presley is opening her own business and has all the excitement and uncertainties of a new entrepreneur.  There are questions on the personal side of life as well.  Is Presley ready for a new relationship  not only the first relationship since the birth of her son but the first relationship since she has made significant changes in her life or as the woman she is now in comparison to the girl she used to be.  But the primary question that continues to haunt the outcome of Presleys future  Will the paternity of her son Wyatt be revealed?

I mentioned this comment in an earlier Brenda Novak book review but it definitely deserves mention again.  One of the special delights of the Whiskey Creek Series is that each novel can be enjoyed as a stand-alone title.  There are some novels that are tiring to read as in order to move the current story forward, the author seems to provide a comprehensive review of the attributes and histories of all characters to date which interrupts the flow of the current novel and is more of a frustrating and distracting interruption to the reader  regardless if an independent title reader or series reader.  With each Brenda Novak novel, the story is fluid and the past is presented as gracefully as the oceans tide coming up to the beach shoreline and going back out as the rhythm of life continues forward.  And with that same ease and grace, the author shares one of the most noteworthy aspects of life that the course of each day leaves an imprint on our hearts and in our minds affecting each path forward of our life journey just as the ocean water leaves a residual imprint on the beach, however delicate and calm or stormy and forceful  each days tide affects the future.  With each conversation, with each interaction, with each learning opportunity and life experience, an individual has the opportunity to grow not only in terms of age by birthday celebrations but in the complexities of composition of their own maturity, values, and what each holds most dear in their personal and professional lives.

Come Home to Me is a beautiful and thoughtful glimpse of a very special time in Presleys life, a life-changing moment in time for Presleys sister Cheyenne, and a time of multiple decisions for the Amos brothers.  The novel is a thoughtful rendition to all that your attitude and your choices equal your life.  I do not present spoilers in any of my book reviews but I promise you will be intrigued by the multiple cliffhangers that arise during your reading time of Come Home to Me.  Enjoy!

Review:
This novel is a love story of vulnerabilities, honesty, and forgiveness. It tells the story of a woman aptly named Phoenix Fuller and a man named Riley Stinson. As I began reading, I've never wanted to read a book so quickly and yet so slowly. This novel is compelling and intense reading to the core of one's heart - especially if the reader has ever had to heal from heartache and "start over" or "begin again". Heartache can take many forms - it knows no boundaries - it crosses lines of gender and socio-economic class without definition and the timing is often unexpected. Anyone that hopes or wonders about second chances in life and especially second chances for love might want to begin their path forward by reading this novel.

I have read many of the novels in the Whiskey Creek Series and each time I've burrowed into the story, I ponder and muse that "this one" is my favorite. Then as a new novel in the series becomes available and I read the story, I change my mind and want to exclaim "this one" as my favorite. So until a new title is released, I share "this one" to savor, to hold dear to your heart, to delve in deeply to the vulnerabilities of the characters, to experience the courageous search for a path forward, to understand the depth of the love of a child, to cheer for perseverance, and to hope that love can be as resilient as it is in our hopes and dreams.

As with every novel in the Whiskey Creek series, there are characters from previous novels and once again the reader is enveloped in the strength of their mutual respect for one another, their genuine caring, and the depth of their friendships in good times and in sorrow. Without a doubt, Whiskey Creek is a special place where courage becomes stronger, perseverance and hard work build character, and life becomes richer with the blessings of friendship and love. I highly recommend a visit - you'll not be disappointed no matter the story you choose to begin reading.

I mentioned this comment in an earlier book review for the Whiskey Creek Series but it definitely deserves mention again.  One of the special delights of the series for this reader is that each novel can be enjoyed as a stand-alone title.  There are some novels that are tiring to read as in order to move the current story forward, the author seems to provide a comprehensive review of the attributes and histories of all characters to date which interrupts the flow of the current novel and is more of a frustrating and distracting interruption to the reader - regardless if an independent title reader or series reader.  As always, I look forward to my next visit with the characters in the Whiskey Creek Series.

Here are a couple of review-rating pairs of a user. Review: While some readers criticize the length and detail of Ravensbruck I really appreciate how comprehensive it is. While following the timeline of Ravensbruck from its foundation in 1939 through its many stages during the war years, we get to know about the officers and guards running it, the different populations of women incarcerated there, the introduction of slave labor, medical experiments, the transports for killing, and efforts to get the word out and organize rescue missions. In telling the complicated story of the camp, we get to learn about dozens of memorable women prisoners: how they coped and survived; how they helped each other; how they died or what happened to survivors after the war. Helm also discusses why the camp at Ravensbruck has been overlooked by scholars. This book helps to redress that lack of attention. I also recommend Helms A Life in Secrets: Vera Atkins and the Missing Agents of WWII. It is also quite detailed, yet through dozens of personal stories it conveys the drama and sacrifice and bravery of those who opposed the Nazis in the second world war. Both are rewarding reads. Review:
Churchill's line about Russia, that it was "a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma," is an apt description of this fascinating book about spymaster Vera Atkins and the missing agents of WWII. "A Life in Secrets" tells the riveting story of the heroic agents who parachuted into France to aid the anti-Nazi resistance. It painstakingly documents their movements behind the lines and their fates in the last years of the war. In the process, it slowly reveals the mysterious character of Vera Atkins, a Romanian-born Jew and, technically, an enemy alien, who recruited and trained women agents for the French section of Britain's Strategic Operations Executive.

"A Life in Secrets" is a great piece of investigative journalism and far more exciting (and heartbreaking) than any fictional spy novel I've read. Each chapter takes you deeper into the layers of personal danger and bureaucratic intrigue. Leads seem to take the story in one direction, only for it to be derailed or redirected elsewhere. Just when you think you know what has happened, more information is discovered that puts a different spin on things. Throughout the book, the heroism and sacrifice of the agents makes you ache for answers about their fates. And you root for Vera Atkins' persistent efforts to account for and honor her missing agents.

I agree with everyone here who has praised Sarah Helm's outstanding research and writing. The number of people she interviewed, the extensive war documents she quotes, and the multiple verifications she obtained to confirm information result in an extraordinary achievement. This book is so layered. It's not only an important history of Britain's spy network in France, it's a major biography of the mysterious Vera Atkins. It includes dozens of shorter biographies of secret agents, military officers, concentration camp survivors, SS officers and prison guards. There's perspective on the deteriorating circumstances of the Jewish community in Romania and Hungary in the 1930s and lots of information on the war crimes prosecutions in 1945-47.

My only warning to readers is to be patient and really take the time to carefully read this book. The large numbers of people, places and times can be daunting to keep track of but your patience will be rewarded. I've read it twice to fully appreciate it. The Anchor Books edition includes a map and list of characters at the beginning which are helpful references. Highly recommended.

Review:

Cons:
- No on/off switch

Review:
Wow. When a friend lent me a copy of this book, I had to buy myself one. This is such a terrific addition to literature and I am so enlightened to have read it. I read Codependent No More over and over with a 1980s copy, and I never would have guessed what Ms. Beattie went through to get where she's at today. Prostitution so she could get drugs, rape from drugged stupors, her arm being photographed with all its needle marks and used to show school children the horrors of drug use -- the clinicians certainly never thought she'd amount to anything, but she learned codependency is the root of all addiction.
A wonderful read. It will make you cry! It did me. A lot of people, men and women, will see themselves in her story. It really makes a person appreciate how she knows so much about codependency and is such an authority. Personal experience, that's what she has to share. I love her meditation books, too. Her humor in the book is especially wonderful because with all she went through, it makes one wonder what she could find to laugh about, and her humor just further brings home what an astounding woman Ms. Beattie is!

Review:
This drive is a wee bit different in appearance from the photo displayed on the Amazon page: the monitor light is red, not blue. That's really neither here nor there, but here's a something you do need to know. I was growing untrustworthy of a 750gb drive which was already 99% full anyway, so I bought this drive. Right away I started getting errors that this file or that was too large for the new drive. WTF? A little googling and investigating revealed the problem: the drive came formatted for the old FAT32 system which has maximum file sizes. As someone who shoots photos in RAW which are 12Mb big when shot on a 12Mb camera, and who also does a little video, the file size limitations prevented a lot of data from being transferred.

While the drive looks tough (and probably is) the first thing you should is reformat it to NTFS, the more modern file system which tolerates large files. It's simple and quick, but save yourself some grief: do it before you start putting data on it.

I haven't used the drive long enough to give it 5 stars, but I gave it 3 stars for the rather dumb idea of formatting it FAT32, forcing many of us to reformat the drive.

Review:
**I received this book from Random House Loveswept through NetGalley for an honest review.**

2.5 stars but I'll round up.

Broken Play centers around three main characters. Cass, he plays center for the team and hes also their leader/captain, Beau, hes the tight end and goes everywhere Cass does and Marian is the new assistant coach for the Rebels.

Cass and Beau are known for their extracurricular activities. They unfortunately have a tape of them and female floating around on YouTube so they are no strangers to sharing. Beau also had some past issues so to say that these two boys are really close would be an understatement. As best friends Cass takes it upon himself to ensure Beau keeps clean and stays out of trouble. Beau has secret feelings for Cass and when Marian enters the equation everything is put on the table. Marian has a past that she is still trying to deal with and she looks to these two to help her out.

Everyone is likeable in their own way. I found Cass to be a little bit of a douche but Beau made up for him. He was sweet even though he was kind of quiet. I did not always feel the connection of these three that was implied. Ill be honest and say the only thing I really enjoyed were the sexy times, especially chapter 29. For me this was one big bang with a lot of exploring. While it was good I just didn't feel connected to these three outside of that. There is a big secret that is fixed but I in no way found it believable for a solid solution.

Overall if you're looking for a steamy read I say go for it.

Brooke is an ex athlete who gets hired by Remington who is the star of a dangerous underground fighting circuit. Shes responsible for keeping his body in good working order so he can demolish his next opponent.

Ive always been a little cautious when it comes to books that are hyped up to the max. Overall I just didn't like the writing so maybe that also affected the way I felt about their story. The licking and scenting was just too much for my liking. I will say the little drama we got was pretty interesting. I didn't mind Mel for what she was.

Review:
My bike light died on me and after some trial and error, I searched Amazon and decided to give this one a go. I was originally very excited. Packaging was fantastic, it came with this postcard sized "personal" guarantee and assurance of quality and customer service. The two rear ruby lights were very bright especially if you look right at them dead on, in what I call "the sweet spot". The front torch is actually slightly less bright than I hoped it would be given it's advertised lumens, but decent enough. Sadly, due to some really absent minded behaviour from me. I lost the front torch and the two USB batteries. I have since bought the following bicycle light set :

Bright Eyes 300 Lumen 2-pack LED Bicycle Headlight - Includes Second Set For FREE - Mounts in Seconds With No Tools Required - LIFETIME WARRANTY

I believe it has better value in that it is only two thirds the prices, yet you get 4, not 3, lights. I have written a review for that set too.

However, this is a review about the Magnus light set, so let's go.

The Good:
========

- Although I think the set is overpriced, there's no denying that it works and is attractive. And if you haven't seen those push button type ruby lights before, you'll just gaze into them, mesmerised, thinking it looks so cool.

- But the best thing about it are the USB batteries. I have neveer seen such batteries before, and can't find any mention of anyone selling them individually, which is a darn pity because they are very practical. Before I lost the torch, I took it and both USB 18650 batteries overseas for a couple of nights hikes. I had my USB charger with me, and it was nice to not have to bring extra cables, or the boxy battery charger in addition to the USB charger.

Wait, you ask...what the heck is a "USB" battery? Batteries can't plug into USB slots, right?

Well, it seems yes they can, but only with the special Magnus design. Here's how it works. See the picture with the front torch on it's holder, the two red lights and two batteries standing upright? About 20% down from the top of the battery is a silver/chrome horizontal ring around it. At first glance, this looks decorative. But in fact it's not. You see the ring because that's where the main battery body and the cap/lid meet. That's right, the top 1cm actually comes off, revealing the battery cylinder and a USB male part socket. But wait!, you say. The top of the battery looks like a real battery...that's where it touches the torch inside the battery compartment. Yes indeed, that is exactly what it looks like and is. But it's still part of the lid.

Now, there's a trick to taking off the top. The lid is actually attached to a thin piece of string, to hold the lid to the battery. The lid fits quite snugly to the battery, so you might apply a bit of brute force, like a certain macho man, whom we shall call "A", and finally rip the lid off, but at the same time, break the string. With the benefit of experience (which means I screwed up in the past), I avoided breaking the string in the second one.

WOW! you exclaim. That's amazing. Yes it is, but there's more! When you lplug in the battery to the USB port, a LED light next to the USB male part socket lights up. It's been too long for me to remember which is which, but when it's not fully charged, it's one colour, and when fully charged, it's another.  Pretty cool, right?

So I think the best part of this set are the batteries. Really wish I hadn't lost them.

- The lights are quite decent, cars should notice you easily. The torch holder rotates so it's flexible

- Everything attaches quite easily to the bike.

Things to be aware of :
=================

- See above for USB battery lids and the strings
- The lanyard attached to the end of the torch makes it slightly inconvenient to slide the torch into the holder. You have to pull the lanyard through first. Minor but if you don't, it'll jam in the torch holder hole.
- The lanyard doesn't have a sliding ..."thing" in it, which allows you to tighen it against your wrist so if you use the torch as a torch and hold it in your hand, it has less chance to slip off.

That's all I can remember. I suspect the price is more a reflection of the USB batteries than the lights' price. If you have the money, you might want to consider buying TWO sets. Why? Because the more lights on your bicycle, the safer you will be (cars have huge lights to prevent 1500kg metal projectiles from hitting them- why shouldn't you? The only physical defence a bicycle has are airbags, but without the "bag" part.) and you will get 4 of those batteries. I know I know...it's a lot of money. But I love their batteries! It's only a suggestion people.  But regardless, enjoy your night cycling and be safe!
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
Ever since the 500 lumen torch my Dad bought for me died, I've been looking for a front light replacement. I bought a 2000 lumen one which burnt through batteries in 10 minutes, several white smaller ones (you can see them in Amazon as ruby red round ones) which are great for getting people to notice you, but pretty poor for lighting up the road, and another 300 lumen torch, which I lost just prior to a bicycle tour!  So after a search through amazon, I bought this set of lights based on the price and how many lights they include in the pack. Overall it is quite good, but not perfect.

The Good:
--------------

- Price - 4 lights for about USD$40. Don't often see a waterproof light fornt or rear for USD$10. Good value. Certainly can do worse.

- You get 4 lights. For night cycling, the more lights the better. The lights have 2 aims....to make sure cars and see you and not hit/kill/cripple you, and to see the road ahead. I've never understood why people use a single tiny dull light on each end of the bike. Cars have huge lights to avoid being hit by 1500kg hunks of metal. Why shouldn't you? I've put a light on my wheel spokes too for side visiblity. 300 lumens is the minimum for good illumination to see the road in front of you on a dark road.

- Quality. The front and rear lights are well made and waterproof. The front light holders seem quite cheap..or at least lack refinement. Screws were rusty at box opening. Other reviewers have noticed this as well. Lanyards on torches are ok, but one with a sliding piece which can tighten around the wrist would be better. I will be using these torches for hiking at night too.

- Rear lights have several settings and the silicone is opaque so light can be seen in all directions. not just the back. TOrches only shine light at the front.

- Presentation counts. The box is attractive, no manual inside though. All lights firmly held in place in their foam insets.

Less Good:
---------------

- the rear lights only have a single clip. It cannot be adjusted for wrapping around thinner parts of the bike. So if you have a bike rack which attaches to the seat post, or a normal rack but carrying a load, then the light can't be attached, or can't be seen.

- the front torch holders do the job, but do not allow rotation. I like to turn my lights a little to the side so I can spread the light wider, and so cars on the side have a better chance of seeing me.

Overall it's a decent buy for some reasonable bicycle lights. I've changed my torch holders and have a pretty nice set up now.

Thanks for reading, and I hope you enjoy your night cycling!

Review:
Don't get me wrong, this book is awesome. If I had read it before any of the author's previous works though, I would have completely dismissed it.

I had always taken the ancient astronaut idea with a grain of salt. Anyone who hears the stories of Quetzecoatl and a few others can see that it is possible, even likely that travelers have visited Earth in the past. The modern question of aliens is not a subject covered here, nor should it be.

This book is basically an investigation of esoteric myth and science combined with a modern understanding of physics. To see if they converge at all. And they do, fantastically.

The place to really start though is not here. After reading the book: "SS: Brotherhood of the Bell" by the same author, I was convinced that Dr. Farrell is doing his homework. That subject I am very familiar with, which enabled me to verify and trust the author's work. In that book, he kept referring to the Giza Death Star Series and Reich of the Black Sun, which I had to read because SS Brotherhood was so awesome. I was not disappointed.

After reading and thoroughly enjoying SS: Brotherhood of the Bell, I read and really took seriously the Giza Death Star books (3 of them). I have become convinced through this author's arguments that something took place in our solar sytem long, long ago. That the pyramids represent proof of a highly advanced form of physics involved with their technological purpose: weaponry.

It is far-fetched, but actually pretty reasonable if you read the arguments and try to understand the science.

This book follows the Giza Death Star books and may not be the best place to start, unless your already at a place where this stuff seems reasonable. Then by all means. Either way, don't pass it up. It's an extremely valuable nugget of that piece we are all looking for:  Meaning.

Review:
Let's get the bad stuff out of the way first.  An M-60 machine gun fires 7.62 NATO rounds.  Not 50 caliber.  A revolver used by police does not have a safety.  Your booger digit is the safety.  A Barret rifle is not greater than 50 caliber.

Now all of that might not be a big deal.  And, in most fiction, it isn't that big of a deal.  Just a pet peeve.  However, when the novel is exhaustively researched as this novel was purported to be, these obvious errors cast some doubt on the research and how "exhaustive" it might have been.  I'd also go along with a number of other reviewers who state the Spanish 'vernacular' used throughout the novel is misspelled, fails idiomatically and is poor syntactically.  It looks more like Google Translate than real Spanish.  How hard would it have been to find a Latino to proof these sentences?

Now, the good stuff.  I thoroughly enjoyed the novel.  A number of events are taken from real life and are portrayed effectively.  The role of the CIA in Central America and their use of the drug trade for financing and wet work is realistic.  Most Americans are only familiar with Iran-Contra.  It went deeper than that and continues to effect our lives on a daily basis.  The War on Drugs has been a fraud on the citizens of this country for a very long time.

Overall, I'd say it's a great read for someone who is interested in history of the period.  It certainly will revise one's thinking about American Exceptionalism.  As I closed the book, I had a song running around in my head....Bruce Cockburn's "If I had a Rocket Launcher".  If the book ever made it to film, it would be my pick for music during the trailers.

4

Review:
I was in the market for a hard drive-based music player and didn't want to go the normal iPxx route, so I began checking into different brands.  I had a list of criteria that the player had to meet:

-EXCELLENT SOUND.  This is critical.  A SnR (Signal to Noise Ratio) of 95db or better

-Excellent battery life.  At least 15 hours

-At least 20 GB

-A color screen

-Sturdy build

-As little touch-sensitive controlling as possible.  Click wheels are inaccurate and bothersome.

-Ease of use.  Drag and drop is preferred.

-AC adapter for charging on the road or from an AC converter in a car

This player meets all of those needs.  The SnR is 97db, I've gotten 18 hours out of the battery (remember that increased settings like equalizers and higher bitrates mean lower battery life for ALL players), the case is solid and brushed aluminum, the screen is pretty and quite sharp, only one touch-sensitive control is present, the player CAN drag and drop through Win XP, and it comes with a wall adapter.

I love the powerful sound this puts out and it can drive my big headphones with no problem.  It can, like most HDD players, set aside a partition for storage.  It has a good FM tuner, recording of FM and a little mic for voice notes.  It can even sync with Outlook for contacts and other info.  The hard disk seems fast and

Now for the drawbacks:

-You can't watch 15fps video on a tiny screen and reduce your battery life by 67%

-The USB cable is proprietary...no mini USB!

-The wall charger cable plugs into the USB cable...this means two cables for recharging from the wall

-Looking at photos and playing music at the same time is not possible

-Creative software is always iffy.  Thankfully, in Win XP, you can open the player from My Computer and access its contents directly with non-DRM music and photos.

-Battery is NON-USER REPLACEABLE.  This is odd for Creative.

-No mention of this on the Creative website.  Thankfully, updated drivers ARE available from support.

This player would have been state-of-the-art about a year ago, but has been eclipsed by its bigger brother the Zen Vision with 30 and 60GB drives and video...however, if you're not buying into the "kill your eyes with tiny video on tiny screens" and just want a SOLID and RELIABLE player with booming sound, this is it!!!  You can tell it's custom-made for Windows (it's MTP, not UMS for any computer), but if you're running XP, then it's a solid choice because you can skip the Creative software and just load music on it.

If you can get it on sale like I did, snatch it up.  This is a little gem of a player!

Review:
I got this for both recording some voice files in Audacity (reading stuff for foreign friends) and also high quality audio when I Skype called.  Although the price point is lower than some other USB microphones, the quality is great!  It sounds great and has an integral amplifier and headphone monitor jack.  I also like the little tripod it comes with.  It's sturdier than it looks and is adjustable.  The only downside is that this is pretty sensitive to ambient noise so if your fridge is running in the background while you record audio, you will be able to hear it if you listen carefully.  However, it has a good bass response and captures the totality of a human voice very well.  It's good for acoustic instruments, too.  The frequency response of 40hz to 18khz is almost the full range of human hearing and is good enough for the price.

A definite recommend!

PS-  It's USB and installs easily the first time
