Review:
Always on the prowl for new bands to listen to, and always trying to improve my playlist of female fronted bands, I stumbled across Hydrogyn, and since then there's been no looking back.  Hydrogyn provides a unique feel to the Alternative/Hard Rock scene, and their sound has truly grown on me to provide a listening experience rock fans may come to appreciate if given enough time and exposure to the group.

Hydrogyn is lead by their female vocalist Julie Westlake, a "Bombshell" looking blond with singing talents to backup her looks.  She's every bit as talented as she is sexy, something that is quite rare in the music world.  Her pipes explode with enthusiasm, hitting notes perfectly, and keeping rhythm quite well.

The album jumps off with a bang.  "Rejection" is a well done, fast paced track that showcases the band's musical skills.  The guitar work is well structured, with great sounding, heavy riffs, and great drum patterns.  The solo that comes in halfway through the song adds further intensity to this opening track, setting the stage for the remainder of the album.  Julie's voice is almost angelic, rolling smoothly over the guitar work.

From here, the next track "On and On" slows things down a bit.  This song is much slower, and more along the lines of Alternative Rock, beginning with Julie slowly whispering before going into the transition singing of the track.  The guitar and drums kick in, upping the tempo and rhythm beautifully, then slowing down again.  The tempo changes occur so naturally, fitting the band's style and Julie's vocals like a glove.

The album has great songs, from start to finish, but stand out tracks are plenty and include: "On and On", and the beautifully done "Candles Light Your Face".  These tracks slow things down, and showcase Julie's voice to a higher degree than other tracks on "Deadly Passions".  "Candles Light Your Face" is a slow song that consists of acoustic guitar work, which complements the vocals unlike any other song on the album.  The slower songs seem to allow Julie to use her voice in a much smoother, and harmonic manner.

"Deadly Passions" continues to provide a transition between Hard Rock and Alternative Rock, and manages to keep a good balance between the styles.  The instrument work remains consistent, and the vocals and lyrics provide another dimension to the band that is hard to come by.  Female fronted bands always provide a unique sound that I have grown to love, but there's something about the sound of Julie's voice that has me coming back over and over again.

5

Review:
Three Days Grace is an alternative metal band that has managed to appeal to a wide demographic for quite some time.  From more hardened metal fans, to females, to people just getting into the rock genre, their style of music is open enough and friendly enough to the ears that almost anyone can get into their music.  With each passing album, the band has tended to lean more towards a softer, more alternative sound than their previous releases.

As the band has matured, so as their sound.  "Life Starts Now" embraces a much softer side to Three Days Grace, while still managing to bring out some great hard rock songs from time to time as well.  The album gets things started with "Bitter Taste".  The track contains a great hook and melody that may have listeners singing along and tapping their feet to the rhythm and lyrics in no time.  Whereas this track embodies the feelings one may have during a tough breakup, the following track "Break" leans in the opposite direction.  "Break" is a great song with a pretty positive message about making the best out of what you have and taking advantage of every situation you get.

From here, the songs continue to echo the same types of feelings, and the toe tapping resumes throughout the album's play-length.  Even the slower songs, such as "World So Cold" and "Someone Who Cares" have enough melody and rhythm going on that it's sure to entrap the listener and have them singing the tracks long after the album is over.

Stand out tracks include: "Someone Who Cares" and "Last to Know" due to the fact that they stray so much from the remainder of the album's formula.  Following a much slower, soothing sound in both instances, each of these two tracks is unique and worth listening to multiple times.  At first, the departure of sound may be a turn off to some for these two tracks, but after several playbacks, the style stands out from the rest of the songs found on "Life Starts Now".

The majority of the album tends to lean towards the subject matters of love and the loss of love.  Tracks like "Bitter Taste", "Last to Know" and "Someone Who Cares" talk about love and how losing love or trying to regain it can be a difficult task.  Other songs such as "Break" and "Life Starts Now" tend to have much "peppier" tempos and subject matters when compared to the majority of the tracks on the album.

Overall, however, the album is a great listen from start to finish.  Whether you're looking for a new alternative album to add to your collection, or are just getting into the genre, Three Days Grace's "Life Starts Now" is a great album to purchase.  The catchy hooks, strong, emotional lyrics, and overall feeling of the album is bound to stick with the listener each time the album is played.

Review:
John Kenneth Galbraith was one of the great public intellectuals of 20th century America.  He advised Presidents and politicians, wrote best-selling books, taught economics at Harvard, appeared on TV, and served as the U.S. Ambassador to India.  Nevertheless, mainstream economists looked down their noses at him.  They scoffed at his sweeping generalizations.  They questioned his technical prowess, noting that his books had no math.  Many suspected that he was a "mere sociologist" masquarading as an economist.

These critics may have been jealous of Galbraith's literary fame and towering public profile.  In any event, they certainly misconstrued his significance in American intellectual life.  Galbraith's great gift as a thinker was his razor-sharp eye for cant.  He knew where economic ideas came from, how they supported vested interests, and where they diverged from the plain facts of everyday life -- and he conveyed these lessons to educated general readers in elegant prose.  In the end, he may have been a gadfly and critic, not a model builder -- but so what?  If mainsteam economists taught us how to think about markets, Galbraith taught us how to think about mainstream economics.

"The Affluent Society" is one of his masterpieces.  Written in the 1950s, ideas fly from its pages, touching on everything from Ricardian economics to oligopolies and inflation.  The central idea, however, is arresting.  Galbraith argued that modern economics was forged in the austere world of the 19th century, when national economies struggled simply to feed and clothe their populations.  Sensible at the time, the core assumptions of economics were carried over to a different century facing a different set of problems.  In the 20th century, supermarkets bursted with unnecessary soaps and cereals, car models changed every year, and billions of advertising dollars were spent on campaigns to convince consumers that they needed items they never even knew they wanted.

Galbraith argued that, with the problem of scarcity more or less solved, society was free to loosen the connection between income and labor, and to spend more money on public goods such as schools, hospitals, and clean air.  He rejected as anachronistic the objection that such measures would reduce economic efficiency by mandating higher taxes or rewarding idleness:  what was the value of having an efficient economic system if the goods it produced answered no urgent human needs?  Galbraith thought that society should focus on the development of human capacities and the building of decent communities and workplaces, and not fret unduly over allocative efficiency.

Galbraith was wrong about many things, but he was always thought-provoking and mind-expanding.  The continuing force of "The Affluent Society" will be clear to anyone who reflects on the crazy popularity of SUVs or tallies up the money we lavish on pets -- in a day and age when American cats get better medical care than most African children, it's safe to say that the supply side problem has finally been solved (at least for us and our pets).  The book should be read by all serious students of economics or 20th century American society, and it belongs on any bookshelf of social criticism next to the works of Thorstein Veblen and C. Wright Mills.

5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
John Kenneth Galbraith didn't respect the literary conventions of economics.  He didn't express himself in math, he made sweeping generalizations about society (not always backed by strong evidence), and he freely drew on the insights of history, sociology, and politics, paying little heed to interdisciplinary boundaries.  For that reason, many economists looked down their noses at him.  And for that reason, his books are still in print and enjoyed by readers decades after they first appeared.  Galbraith was more than an economist.  He was a great social critic, a great debunker of cant, and a superb prose stylist.  He was the Veblen of post-World War II America.

He was at the top of his powers when he wrote "The New Industrial State" in the 1960s.  The book came as close as anything did to summarizing the Galbraithian "system."  Parts of it are outdated, such as the assertion that financial markets have little influence on big corporations, or the strained argument that the American and Soviet economic systems were "converging."  Other parts, however, are as relevant today as they were 40 years ago, such as the critique of advertising and consumerism, or the analysis of how our gigantic defense industry shapes policy and influences the Pentagon.  In a time when the Federal Reserve is bailing out banks and scrambling to protect the economy from the miscalculations of the financial sector, it's good to be reminded that the private sector looks to government to keep the economy on a even keel, no matter what the official ideology of the private sector may be.

Most of all, "The New Industrial State" displayed Galbraith's genius for stepping back and asking big questions.  These continue to haunt economics, even though textbook writers bury them in footnotes.  Why DO we treat GDP is an adequate measure of social welfare?  Why DO we choose to consume higher productivity in the form of goods rather than leisure?  Why DOES our pedagogy emphasize "perfect competition" when the economy is dominated by big firms?  Why DO we assume that workers and managers are motivated solely by pecuniary considerations?  And on and on.

"The New Industrial State" is a trove of intellectual riches, expressed in masterful and witty prose.  Every undergraduate economics student should read it.  So should every educated citizen.  It's a 20th century classic.

Review:
I'm kind of glad that I read Janice Erlbaum's second memoir, Have You Found Her, first. It allowed me to read her first one and not have to worry too much that she got seriously hurt. Or went crazy, which is what I think I would have done in her circumstances. Instead, Erlbaum left home, and turned to drugs and sex as a teenager, and she relates her experiences with both with a candor that is unapologetic at the same time it is tinged with regret.

Erlbaum's problems at this time of her life seem to stem from a combination of poor parenting and poor decision-making. Unfortunately, neither the shelter nor the group home into which she is placed seem well-equipped to really help her with either of those problems. It almost seems as though by leaving home she's gone from the frying pan into the fire. It all catches up with her at the end, though, and at the close of this memoir we begin to see the more mature woman that we got to know in her second memoir. I hope she writes a third so that we can continue to share her story.

Review:
What an amazing, amazing book.  I had to keep reminding myself that it was about real people!

In this, her second memoir, Janice tells the story of volunteering at the shelter she lived in briefly as a teenage and of meeting Sam.  Although the relationship she forms with Sam may ultimately have been good for her, showing her that she had internal strength she would never have guessed out.  It makes for a very powerful story.

I think the most interesting part of this book was Janice's honesty about her negative feelings toward Sam.  To be able to say that you're angry at a person in Sam's position takes a lot of strength.  The same to admit that you have doubts about  the truth of what someone you care about says to you.

And this is a memoir that is easy to read.  One might always be skeptical of the claim that a memoir reads like a novel, but in this case, I found that it did.  I was drawn in from the very beginning, and ended the book hoping that Ms. Erlbaum will write another memoir in the future.

Review:
I had to replace an atomic clock as it was programmed with the old time zone dates and it would change before the appropriate time.  We do good enough remembering when the two DST days are.  The old clock had large white digits.  It would cast a shine on low.  I decided to try a different color, knowing that red and green are good lights when fishing at night.  The digits are really large on this clock. At first I started laughing. When I put it on dim, there was no shine cast our at night.  Excellent.  I can deal with bigger letters and after a week like them. I can see the time easy at night without needing my eyeglasses .  The gradual timer is nice. I had this once on bose sound machine that broke.  i can't stand a blasting alarm clark. This has a prolonged gradual increase, maybe 12 alarms to the loudest...  The radios and alarms are easy to program, just follow the instructions.  For accessing programmed channels, you need to cycle through 10 presets.  I don't mind as I rarely will use this for a radio.  Nice clock.

Review:
I feel duped not once but twice by this author. This is the second time I've purchased a book by her that I assumed featured an interracial couple. The first was a book from her Alien Abduction series. Sorry but a relationship between a caucasian and a purple alien is NOT interracial/multicultural but interspecies! And now this. Even though we don't find out what the hero and herione look like until AFTER the free preview,  clearly both characters are Caucasian.  Tammy has "curly hair, freckles and pale skin." Reid not even sure other than he's big and his cousin has blond hair and blue eyes. I don't see much of a military theme either other than a mention of him "serving overseas years ago."

I know other readers will slay me over this, but I don't like characters described so vaguely they can be pretty much anything and I don't like to be deceived. It's akin to thinking you're going to read a M/M romance but you get a M/F, and I biught this book because I wanted to read about an interracial couple.

Review:
This book is split into two main sections: general information on owls and species profiles.  The first section deals with the general information and it is written in a way that is easy to understand and very informative.  After the author discusses something generally about owls, it is often followed up with specific examples of which owls that information applies to.  There is some information that can be applied more generally to birds of prey, but, of course, everything mentioned is related to owls.

I tend to read a lot about owls and diurnal birds of prey, and when I spotted this book in the store, I kept thinking, do I really need yet another book on owls?  Despite that, I could not pass the book up, and I'm glad I did not.  And speaking from the point of view of someone who has read extensively on owls/birds of prey, I think this book would be great for anyone, from the person who is new to the subject of owls or for someone who is more of an expert.

Review:
This book combines the personal experiences of the author with detailed information about the owls that live in the United States and Canada.  The background information given in this book can be applied to more than one species of owls, and in some cases, it could be applied more generally to birds of prey.  There are comparisons between humans and owls to give the reader a better image of what the author is describing.  When there is a piece of general information given, the author gives examples of which owls that piece of information might be applied.  The book is filled with wonderful photos, and includes a guide of owls that is located between the first two chapters.

This is one of the best books about owls that I have read.

Review:
I fell in love with Megan and Garrett's story over a year ago when the novella appeared in an anthology and I finally got my wish for more!! I loved their full story!

When her young daughter is badly injured in a car accident, Megan Campbell is grateful for Garrett Kristoff, former high school classmate and well-respected surgeon. She is devastated by the secrets that have come out about her husband but is trying to focus solely on her daughter. Now, Megan is going to have to put all her faith in Garrett's ability to help her little girl walk again.

Garrett has never forgotten his crush from high school and loves seeing her again but hates the circumstances. He only hopes he can be the hero she and her little girl need. And although the timing isn't great, maybe he will get the chance to show Megan how he has always felt and be there for her when her world has been turned upside down.

Will Megan and her little girl get the miracle they need? Have they found a safe place to stay awhile?

What a truly heartrenching yet heartwarming story!! Megan and Garrett are both great main characters and I loved them both. And Megan's little girl, Laney, is totally adorable. The twists and turns of this story kept my interest from beginning to end. I love Gia Riley's books and this one is no different. She writes stories that easily make me attached to the characters and makes me sad when the story is over. Love Gia Riley and I would recommend her books to everyone!

Review:
The one thing I know for certain I'll have when I read one of Ms Lane's books is pure, unadulterated flaring, flaming, LOVE and emotion.  My very very favorite part of this 2nd in this wonderful Sugar Rush series was at the very end, the things that both Hannah and Evan say to each other, but mainly Evan's amazingly "heart-shattering" (appropriate given the circumstances) profession to Hannah.  Ms Lane can dialogue romance like no other.  After the Spiral of Bliss series (which I am unashamed to admit I read a multitude of times), I've found few other authors who can express feelings of the heart as can Nina Lane.  Sweet Escape flows wonderfully into the "Sugar Rush" theme, and Evan, as the second of the famous Stone Brothers, does not disappoint on any level.  Especially refreshing is how the author entwines each of the former characters into the current storyline, giving the reader bits and pieces of more of the family dynamic, the Rainesville community connection, and wraps it up in a nice, sweet package!!!  I cannot wait for the next installment and the story of the next Stone brother!!

Review:
I'm not understanding the problem readers seem to have with this book.  This is a stand alone story of Porsche.  It didn't need to bring back any other character because the story developed all on it's own.  How this young girl (although I did feel she was a little TOO young for decisions she made) found the way to fight for herself and her family.  Really, the story outlined what it was like in her household, fighting to be seen and loved by the family members she cherished.  Porsche fought hard only so she could get back to 'her safe haven', because what she had was better than nothing.  She didn't understand why her family wasn't there fighting for her, trying to save her, get her back.  And she knew if it had been her older sister someone would have done something to save her.  Porsche felt she was thrown away and her life was dedicated to making that not true. It's funny that because it wasn't like Sister Souljah's earlier books that this one was 'less than'. Simply not true.  It was full of poetry and symmetry, a world of pain, loneliness and fear.  This little girl was made to be self sufficient, to rely on her own wits, to 'be like' those she admired so they would accept her, bring her back into the only world she knew.  Not only was she disappointed over and over again, she continued to fight for that love when the odds were completely against her.  Most of what she survived happened at an unbelievably young age but it didn't diminish the raw pain and desperation of wanting to belong, to be loved.  I think Sister Souljah did another outstanding job, creating another unique story that draws you in and leaves you wanting more.  She's an excellent writer, a masterful storyteller and A Deeper Love Inside is proudly sitting on my bookshelf with other fierce authors!  Keep them coming, Sister!
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This album is notable for many things, the least interesting being her disco duet with Donna Summer. Unlike the purists, I don't mind the foray, or her takes on Splish Splash and I Aint Gonna Cry Tonight, since they are yet again proof of Barbra's eclectic choices. However for me, the pluses of this album are the beautiful Lee Holdridge orchestrated arrangments of the ballads, and the almost tragic idea that this was the voice that we could have had doing the film of Evita. When Robert Stigwood had director Ken Russell on board, he wanted Barbra, but she turned it down, primarily because she disliked Don't Cry for Me Argentina, but also because she was in pre-production on Yentl. One would hardly want to deny Barbra fulfilling her long cherished Yentl dream. And one could also dismiss the idea that at her age of 37 she was too old to play Eva Peron. But at 27 she was considered too young to play Dolly Levi in Hello, Dolly but she was cast because of her voice, and this !is the voice that Evita deserved. (Barbra's vocals for her next album, Guilty, were lesser, for her at least). Not to mention that the role of Evita suited Barbra's androgynous persona, and that the she resembles the real Eva Peron. The only redemptive element of being eventually saddled with Alan Parker directing Madonna, is Tim Rice returning to Andrew Lloyd Webber to write You Must Love Me, similar to how Jerry Herman wrote Love is Only Love for Barbra's Dolly. Oh well. Of this album, it can be noted that Barbra cowrote the title track, in one of her rare songwriting efforts, but my favourite here is On Rainy Afternoons, a never repeated exploration of Lalo Schifrin material. It is said at the time that Streisand was outbid by Richard Clayderman for the rights to an album of Schifrin love songs. This, and her pass on Evita, is perhaps too much to bear.

4

Review:
Whilst still grappling with Jon Peters and her record company's need for her to be commercially viable, Streisand's Songbird album is further evidence of the range of Barbra's voice at the time. If a lot of these songs are of lesser material, this is nothing new for Streisand, since her choice of material has always been eclectic, even in her early recording days, and perhaps a reminder of the attitude of her mentor Barry Dennen, who was more interested in the singer drawing attention to herself rather than subjugating to the song. (This argument was sweetly defended by saying she was "acting" the songs). Examples of this mentality here are One More Night and Deep in the Night, where the greatest pleasure is in hearing her histrionic climbs. Honey, Can I Put on Your Clothes, prefigures Barbra's transvestite interest in Yentl, though it's telling that she got the greenlight for Yentl at the cost of Peters. The title track is probably the strongest song melodically, since it uses her favoured three act structure. Her rethinking of Tomorrow, a reminder of the reinterpreting of standards a la Happy Days are Here Again, with her version understated yet still emotional. And her solo You Don't Bring Me Flowers, evidence that Neil Diamond was never needed, and also why she is considered to have one of the greatest voices of the twentieth century.

Review:
If you are an English or Irish Breakfast Tea drinker and enjoy the heavier/maltier side of the tea spectrum, this may be a nice choice for you.  The is particularly true if you drink your English Breakfast tea in bags or pouches (you owe it to yourself to get a good infuser like this one: http://www.amazon.com/Adagio-Teas-ingenuiTEA-Bottom-Dispensing-Teapot/dp/B000FPN8TK

Some reviewers have complained that this tea comes as mostly dust and fannings, but I did not find that to be the case with my package.  It definitely contained more dust/fannings than some of the finer grade Assam I buy from a local tea shop, but I'd attribute that more to the fact that it is being mail-ordered in small quantities and not being graded again after receipt.  (see photo for the character of my batch at the bottom of the bag once I'd consumed most of the tea in the bag).

As to the flavor profile and character, I should first say that my taste preference is on the extreme side of earthy/malty with as little astringency (tannin) as possible.  I drink my tea with milk and agave syrup as a general rule.  My typical favorites are certain Assam teas (which I typically brew heavy but short) and Irish or Scottish Breakfast blends.  I also generally enjoy good quality Keemun and Dianhong teas.

My general reaction to this particular tea blend is that it stands up well to a heavier brew (the way I like) but it is very sensitive to over-brewing.  The directions say 3-5 minutes, but I found that a 3 minute brew at 195 to be just at the edge of my preference for astringency, but having a great full body, malty character, and more exotic/floral notes than a typical Assam or Breakfast blend.  The smell of the dried leaves almost seems like there is some bergamot (what gives Earl Grey its distinct flavor) but there is no mention of any additives to this tea blend, so I have to assume that it is coming from one of the more exotic varieties of tea used in this blend.  Speaking of additives, I've poked through the leaf mix and there is nothing in this blend besides tea leaves, so please ignore reviewers that mention bits of citrus or other additives - this looks to be a pure tea blend (and this is also stated by the producer).

In summary, if you like a good hearty cup of tea and are looking for something with a bit more complexity and a different flavor profile, but still with the maltiness and caffeine kick of a good Breakfast tea, give this one a try.  But do yourself a favor and throw away that "ball" type infuser and get a full-cup infuser like the one I linked to above!

Review:
Great full-bodied English Breakfast tea.  No discernible bitterness.  Full-bodied with good medium malty flavor and an earthy finish.  Not as malty as the Assam, but darker and slightly more tannic.  Not as full-bodied as the Irish Breakfast.

My recommendation for brewing (I like my tea strong and full-bodied with a bit of sweetener and milk, Indian or English style):  1 level teaspoon per 8 fl oz of filtered water that has been brought JUST to the boil.  Put into a large brewing vessel like the Teavana Perfect Tea Maker http://www.amazon.com/Teavana-PerfecTea-Tea-Maker-16oz/dp/B004X7DIHI/

Steep no longer than 3 minutes and dispense into a big mug that has been warmed.  Add milk and sweetener to taste - a great way to start any day!  :-)

Some people like to use less tea and brew for a longer time, but this will make fore a much more bitter and less flavorful cup of tea

Review:
I believe that this is the best helicopter in its size for the money.  Truly 4 channels, and very easy to fly.  Also, hard to break!  Just don't lose your tail propeller, my original kept falling off when I would crash, but I replaced it with a new one and it stays on just fine now.

UPDATE 8-18-2013:  I found a GREAT upgrade for this helicopter.  You'll notice that the tail motor just isn't strong enough and will blow out on you during throttle spikes, when flying in wind, and when trying to execute a turn while gliding sideways.  I had this Helimax Axe CP 100 tail motor laying around, and put it on my V911 after I burned out my V911 tail motor by running about 10 batteries in a row (the motor got HOT and stopped spinning).

What you'll need:
-Helimax Axe CP 100 tail motor (I got the whole tailshaft with motor for about 4 bucks from tower)
-Basic soldering iron
-Superglue
-X-acto knife
-Small wire cutter/stripper (can  also use use the razor blade to cut/strip, and use the soldering iron to burn wire insulation off)
-Any kind of tape for the first test flight (before you permanently seal solder joints

Here are some basic instructions:

-Cut old V911 tail motor wires right at the motor (so you have as much as possible to work with)
-Cut new Helimax tail motor wires where the little splice is (where it goes from the Red/Black wires coming out of the motor and connects to the shiny wires that run down the tail shaft)
-Carefully strip the ends of all wires, and tin them up with some fresh solder (by tin them up I mean expose about 0.5-1mm of copper wire, and feed it some heat and solder so its nice and silver and ready to stick to other solder - If you skip this step and try to solder bare copper wires together, it will be more difficult).
-To remove old tail motor from V911, you need to pry up on the back of the motor to get it past the little lip that retains it in the V911 tail.  NOTE:  This little lip needs to be carefully shaved off with your X-Acto blade - The Helimax motor is slightly longer and will not fit without this lip being cut off.  Shave it off until it is perfectly flat with the dished section that the motor sits in.
-Once you've shaved the lip off, you can easily slide the Helimax motor into the V911 tail.  Test fit it and make sure it sits flat against the housing.
-Once you've test fitted the tail motor, and are happy with its orientation (making sure new motor wires are able to reach the wires coming out of V911 tail), remove the motor, put a drop of superglue in the tail, in the black plastic dished-out section where the motor sits.  Now slide the motor in, AT AN ANGLE at first, so you don't accidentally bulldoze the superglue with the end of the motor.
-Once the motor is all the way in, squeeze it against he tail real hard and hold it there for a minute to let the superglue dry.  I used my little pliers to squeeze it, but don't squeeze too hard.  You can dent these motors if you're not careful.
-Now, solder the wires back together.  I found that getting a little solder on the end of my iron, holding the two wire ends together and then just touching them with the solder ball on my iron worked well.
-Once I soldered both wires, I used a little bit of tape to protect them for a test flight, then I actually superglued the joints to protect them, and put a tiny rubber band around the motor to hold them stationary.  MAKE SURE they don't short out.  You could blow your circuit board and then you need to spend 5 bucks on another one and wait a week for  it to come from China.
-I used my original V911 tail blade - Remember this blade goes on one way, if you are spinning out of control, flip the blade so the other side is pointing out.  I might try the Helimax tail blade at some point but I'm very happy with the original right now.

My V911 ROCKS now!  The tail no longer blows out on me during throttle spikes and while gliding sideways into heavy wind.  I can make excellent spins to the left or right while gliding sideways at any speed.  This upgrade made my little V911 into TWICE the helicopter it was before!
Score:
5

There are much better micro helis out there for the price.  Not worth buying.

Review:
Wild! I was just on an epic journey and I don't even think anyone has even noticed how my heart is racing, or my hands are sweaty; I am a torn happy bundle of nerves. Yes I know, torn happy can be considered an oxymoron, but Im like a pendulum swinging from one extreme to the next. I really am completely surprised how this story has unfolded. I enjoyed every moment. Every joy, every sorrow. Every Kiss.
Bo and Half-pint are my new favorite couple. And really they are a package deal, you cant love one without the other, or be mad at one without the other. I will be honest there were times where I wanted to strangle them both. The passion they have for each other quickly diminished those thoughts just as quick as I had them.
THE PASSION.
WOW.
Bordering on being compulsive the feelings of complete adoration between all the characters is what will make you fall in love with this book. Complicate me is a journey, a passage of life between 5 kids; 4 boys and 1 girl, who experience everything together, Their individual firsts becoming another bond that holds them together, whether it be wonder or lust, death, rip your heart out love, or just plain ol growing up, these good ol boys and Alex will sink their claws into you and bring you with them through the swirls and spray of life. M. Robinson makes you have All. Those. Feels. without apology or reservation. She wrote this life tale making me at one point not like her very much because I couldn't handle where she was taking me. Its ok. Ive made peace with her  How could I not? Complicate Me is simply, beautiful. This story makes you realize what you have or what you could have from the things you never knew you wanted. I have two favorite quotes, and from the moment I read them at two very different stages of the story they jump out at me completely encompassing the soul of the story:

Surfing, the boys, and Alex. That was my life.

I didn't need to embrace her for her to feel me; she held my entire world in her arms. ~~ Lucas POV

If you're looking for that epic tale of friendships and love with every emotion and experience in between, Complicate Me is that story for you. The first book in The Good Ol Boys Series, I am excited that we will soon have the second book that tells the story of forbidden love.

***I was given an advanced readers copy in exchange for my honest experience @ All Is Read Blog

5

Review:
Without a doubt, One is one of the funniest, snarkiest, laugh out loud books Ive read in a long time. Sexy. Oh my words this story was sexy! I completely fell in love with not just the main characters but all the characters. Every single person that was described or that had a voice was intricately woven and needed to make this story one thatll be a long lasting favorite.

Do you believe in fate? Do you believe that there is one person for everyone and one moment that will define who you're supposed to be connected too; who grounds you? For Lake Jones, she met her person at the worst possible timing in the world. Cage Monaghan, the nations star, was it for Lake. They shared one moment in a series of moments only to have life keep them separate.

Fast forward years later, Cage fumbles back into Lakes life. Let me say now that I love me some Cage!! He is that guy! That guy whos perfect yet flawed at the same time. You will fall in love with him, hook line and sinker!! The way he loves Lake, oh my, and the teasing he dishes out, so funny!

Funny? I cant even count the many times that I laughed out loud while reading! There were a few times that I went running to my husband to share with him the one liners that just kept me in a fit of giggles.

Through all the good times while reading I was also brought into some very real struggles these characters had that not only made me hyper aware but also made me sit in awe of the inspiring strength that lay hidden within the words. Once I started reading, I didn't stop. I needed to just be in this world that took me away from reality and I couldn't be happier with my time spent with these characters. The writing was great, the flow was perfect and the conflicts were as real as I sit here writing.  The passion these characters go through to overcome what society deems to label and say whats appropriate in life was awesome to read unfold.

If you love second chance romances, or if you love stories with a sports theme, One is for you. If you like to have a sexy story that also makes you laugh, One is that book for you. If you love to have your heart beating so fast you don't know how long youve been lost in all the feelings, start reading now. If you love to be surprised at each turn of the page, you will not be disappointed at any one time while reading this beauty!

Review:
As a mother of a dyslexic pre-teen, I'm always looking for exciting new fodder to excite my son about reading and The House on the Corner has the potential to be an excellent candidate. Unfortunately, THonC doesn't live up to that potential. The writing is fractured and hard to follow. The premise is also fractured and hard to follow: are Chester and gang fighting evil, facilitating scientific leaps, or just on a mad dash across the country in search of like-minded crazies? Ultimately I was left wondering if this book is meant to be fun or a religious/social commentary. Definitely not something the son would enjoy.
That being said, I must come to the defense of this book in one area. As a social commentary it caught my attention. Have y'all heard of the creep (not a creep, the creep)? `The creep' is what I call the quiet burrowing-in of previously unknown or unacceptable ideas into our common societal mentality. Some examples of the creep include the regularity of interracial dating/marriage, the acceptance of homosexuality, the burgeoning criticism of the overweight and the barely disguised hostility towards the Christian community. What once was taboo has, through quiet, consistent bombardment, become acceptable. While we weren't paying attention. Mr. Rains describes it perfectly as follows: "Imagine a country invades another country, and they win, and march in and change all the rules and blow up all the buildings. That would be a terrible thing, wouldn't it?" Chester had heard about this, and seen some bits of old war movies on TV. It did seem rather horrible. Auntie continued. "But imagine that there is no army, and there is no invasion, no millions of soldiers marching through the streets and firing cannons and blowing things up, but then things are changing anyways. Only nobody notices, because like we said, there is no army. But things are changing, and changing, and soon nobody remembers how it was and what they loved so much, so much that they would have fought a whole army to hold onto it before." Books are magic; even the bad ones have something to say.
I received this book free from the publisher through the BookSneeze.com book review bloggers program. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission's 16 CFR, Part 255: "Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising."

Review:
This knife is SHARP, lightweight, and comfortable. It's about as close to perfect a knife as I've ever used, and I've used some fancy dancy knives.

My mom has a Victorinox chef's knife which I really really dislike. The handle on that one is too big, and the whole thing feels awkward. (I should note here that I do prefer santoku to chef for nearly every application.) I didn't have high hopes for this knife as a result.

However, the handle on this is much thinner, and fits my (very small) hands almost perfectly. It's also a lot smaller than the handle of my Calphalon Contemporary 7" Santoku, and the combination of handle size and weight makes this a lot more comfortable for prolonged chopping than with the Calphalon. I think the blade is also thinner on this one, which I guess has pros and cons, but so far I've only experienced the pros. Despite the weight and thinness, it feels very sturdy. The most impressive task this has accomplished so far was slicing frozen sausage into 1/4" rounds where the Calphalon failed.

Overall, highly recommended, especially given its competitive price point.

Review:
Like the Victorinix santoku, this knife is SHARP and lightweight. Unfortunately, for me (tiny hands), it's not that comfortable, although the santoku is.

I should say that my mom has this same knife, and hands the same size as mine, and she loves it, so your mileage may vary. For me, this handle is too big, and I feel like my wrist is an awkward angle. I don't know why it's different for her.

All that said, I love this line of knives. they're thin, lightweight, super sharp, and super sturdy. They seem like a different theory in knives than thicker and heaving blades like Henckels, but, honestly, I prefer these, and I suspect they'll last just as long.

Overall, highly recommended, especially given its competitive price point, but beware that the handle may not be ideal for small hands.

Review:
The book started out fairly enjoyable, but by about the middle of the book I was so sick of reading about Eva's green, mesmerizing eyes and Etahn's deep blue eyes, I couldn't wait to just be finished with it. The constant changing points of view throughout the book was irritating...I had to constantly stop and think about who was talking at any one time. Honestly, it cannot be that hard to write from one POV, or at least to make it clear who is talking. The characters are not well developed at all,and since this is such a long book, the author had plenty of time to develop them. The other irritating part for me was the controlling nature of Ethan. It is hard to believe that any woman would want to be talked to the way he spoke to her (and everyone else)...I'm surprised someone didn't knock him off sometime in the journey. I would consider him to be abusive in real life. All in all, I'm sorry I wasted a couple of days reading this.

Review:
What a DE-LIGHT-FUL book!!  Goodness, this is my first time reading Alexander's work, but I sensed something SOOOOOO special about this story I couldn't pass it up.....indeed, EVERY part of this book was wonderfully written and tangibly enjoyed from the FIRST page!  I am NOT a fan of pink, but I couldn't stop looking at that BEAUTIFUL cover while reading and the story never failed to keep my attention through almost 500 pages.  It was such an amazing read that I even forgot to take notes!  Yes, this book is FILLED with excellent food and dishes, but mostly it appeals to the reader's heart through Eleanor and the amazing character she is.

The book begins with Eleanor being a volunteer for the wounded during war in 1864 and this entire scene resonates with her in such a way that she remembers it throughout the story.  She even makes a promise to one dying soldier and she doesn't give up the unlikelihood of fulfilling this promise no matter how many years it takes to do so.

Eleanor must move in with her aunt later in the story after leaving her father and his ailing mind in an asylum; the scene is powerfully written and my heart ached EXACTLY as Eleanor did in leaving her precious Papa to the hands of the capable medical staff.  My heart broke even as I read that part.

I do have to say regarding Aunt Adelicia that I was surprised at how welcoming her aunt is when Eleanor moves in.  I really thought the aunt would be cordial, cold, and distant, but she is quite the opposite.  Even with her own agenda to guide Eleanor with, this aunt really felt like a surrogate mom in so many ways.  I didn't always agree with her methods/intentions, but I respected their relationship and believed that Adelicia was truly determined to see Eleanor entrusted in a solid arrangement.  Though she was not my favorite character in the story, she did keep the plot interesting.

I have no interest in Botany or plant life, but I was taken in with Marcus's passion towards flowers and his brilliant ways of creating the perfect specimens.  I didn't agree with keeping his secrets so tightly hidden, but I did understand his reasons.  More than once he had my sympathies and I had no trouble falling for his character as the man for Eleanor.  He really was Mr. Darcy to Eleanor's Elizabeth! (I found Eleanor very similar to Elizabeth Bennett, especially in how she enjoyed walking so much)  He understood everything about her heart and endeavored to give her whatever her heart desired, it became his mission throughout to make her smile.

My heart melted over and over again at Eleanor's cooking for the widows and the children.  Oh my, this book is so utterly touching and honoring to fallen soldiers.  With the incredible descriptions, the reader feels like you're THERE with these beautiful souls that Eleanor comes to love as her own family.  Mr. Stover, Naomi and Caleb, Mr. Fitch (wow to those donuts), and even Nurse Smith who takes care of Theodore.....I was amazed by the resilience of this community as they blessed Eleanor and made her dreams come true in a TOTALLY different way than she expected!

Without a doubt, Eleanor was my hero through and through!  She is compassionate, diligent, fiercely independent, giving, has an amazing heart that would rival ANY royal, faithful, trustworthy, has an adorable sense of humor, utterly intelligent, hardworking, passionate for people and cooking, and always determined to do the right thing.  I never ONCE saw her as plain or unappealing, she is so very tall and completely unconventional as a Southern woman, but that only made her MORE appealing and special!  Seeing the world through her eyes in this novel moved me more than once and touched me more than I would've thought possible for a fictional character.  This is my first read by Alexander, but I'm convinced it won't be my last.  I highly recommend this book even if historical fiction is not your typical genre, it will definitely win you over and leave you smiling.  Every single part of the plot was addressed, each character got their individual conclusions, and the ending to this story leaves you feeling warm all over.  I'm thrilled I got the chance to review this and I'm grateful for the love found in these pages.  *also included are discussion questions and a note from the author describing historical facts in the book*

I want to thank the author and Bethany House Publishers for the review copy provided.  I was not required to write a positive review.  The opinions expressed are my own.
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
I have a number of devices that require charging: IPad, IPhone, IPod, Kindle, etc.. This multi USB charger is has enough amperage capacity to charge multiple devices at one time with an amperage capacity of 6.8 amps. Every device that I know of charges at 5 volts. So the 5 volts divided by the resistance of the device or total resistance of all devices equals the current (amperage) draw. This will be in the thousandths of an ampere total. Therefore, the current carrying capacity is there but you will probably never come near using anywhere near the maximum.

Also, using this type of charger or any wall outlet charger lets you charge the device without opening apps on your computer like ITunes or GPS or other auto-update programs. Use the computer USB port only when you need to.

Review:
Perfect.
I absolutely loved this book. What a great start to what is no doubt going to be another fantastic Sloane Kennedy series. This book has it all and will take you on a roller coaster of emotions. I fell so hard for both Dallas and Nolan. These are two incredible men with big hearts and a lot of love to give. They've both had a rough time of it in the past and can't seem to catch a break. And they have some obstacles to climb on the road to their HEA. Be warned: This book will definitely cause you to shed some tears. But that ending...it's everything!!
I can't recommend this book enough. It's well written and has fantastic characters (including some amazing animals, the story revolves around a wildlife rescue/sanctuary after all). I loved a few of these secondary characters and am hoping we see books for them in the future. I know we get a Maddox and Isaac book next. I really liked the illustrations.  It was happy and easy on the eyes.  Moreover, the story started off great with a tone that alluded to a moral message.  It starred a Richie Rich-like protagonist, Candice Wellesley Wellington, Candy for short.  Candy's father was often found too busy to spend time with her so his solution was to shower Candy with rare toys to keep her busy.  One day, Mr. Wellington even managed to find a dinosaur ..yep, Cankersaur Rex, for Candy.  Sweet young Candy of course wanted to train Cank (nickname she called him) to be nice and not bite.  Top that with a jealous boy (Chucky) next door vying for Candy's attention and you've rounded up an interesting crew and potential learning story. However, the ending didn't wow me as I'd hoped.  It was a cute and happy ending but something was off.  Perhaps it wrapped up too quickly and neat and the moral message didn't quite flow with the note that I sensed in the beginning of the book.  My 6yo daughter (she read this too) must have sensed something also because when I asked her how much she liked it, she said it was "in the middle".

The best part of the story that I liked was when Candy's father took the time to help Candy and Chucky find Cank.  It was a moment that a parent can pause to point out to his child that Candy's father really does love Candy and took time for her.  I suppose I wanted that same greatness for the ending, instead it ended with a different sort of goodness.

***A PDF eARC was provided to me by the author in exchange for an honest review.

Review:
I thought this was going to be one of those collections of offbeat and interesting information. It isn't. This is a wonderfully written, quite serious account of how we look at and think about heads. Larson is an anthropologist by training, and this book is thoroughly researched, but she has a sure and wry touch. This is important because while the book starts with the three-century career of Oliver Cromwell's head, some of the book details what could be excruciatingly boring material, the Victorian academic vogue for collecting skulls, but manages to make it fascinating.

The book is full of surprises. She considers the shrunken heads at the Pitt Rivers Museum (British) where she's worked. Several aren't human, but the ones that are may be items of commerce, heads of people murdered and shrunken for a lively trade in the jungles, a head for  a gun. The practice of shrinking was originally connected to religious practice, but proved adaptable to the market.

Chapter 2 is on trophy heads, and rather wide-ranging. American soldiers took enemy heads in several Asian wars. One photograph shows the crew of MTB 341 grinning while a member of the crew puts a cigarette in the jaws of a Japanese skull, the boat's mascot. This can get sobering, because of an undercurrent of vicious racism--they didn't take German heads. There's a photo, which was a Life Magazine photo of the week in 1944, of a GI's girlfriend peering at a Japanese skull her boyfriend had sent her. More amazing trivia--for more than 300 years there was a Keeper of the Heads who lived in the gatehouse on London Bridge, whose job was to arrange heads and body parts to maximum advantage (the body parts from executed prisoners).

There's a chapter on deposed heads, of aristocrats via guillotine and other contexts. There was a large market for guillotine portraits, sketched just after decapitation and sold, apparently something like broadsides. A fascination for executions and  other such macabre things was characteristic; she writes that the Paris morgue was among the main attractions of the city, drawing a million visits a year. Larson discusses Madame Tussaud, who had connections so she was able to make death masks just after execution of Louis XVI and Marie Antionette.

Chapter 5 is on potent heads, largely those of saints, relics of sanctity. Chapter 6 concerns bone heads, that is skulls, and this is the chapter detailing the amazing Victorian vogue for collecting skulls, many many collections (most of which currently reside in museums), and largely for the study of racial differences--the "science" was closely connected with phrenology (which largely was concerned with living heads, judging character by shape and bump). Chapter 8 considers living heads. This is of two kinds, the decapitation and freezing of living heads in the hope of becoming alive again at some point in the future, and of what fleeting consciousness is there in heads just decapitated.

You don't have to read the book straight through as I did. The chapters can be read separately. I think that the most interesting are the first chapter with Cromwell's head, and Chapter 2, on trophy heads.

5

Review:
This is a wonderful idea for a book, and it provides a great deal of information, but I never quite could figure out what the purpose of the book is. It's sort of a collection of essays about bad clowns.

Radford starts off with a bit of history, and he puts together in the clown category some aspects I would not have thought of, but that make sense. The Punch and Judy puppet shows of course feature Punch's gratuitous violence to all and sundry, but I would not have seen a connection with the figure of Harlequin in commedia del'arte or the ancient business of kings having fools and jesters who can get away with criticism by dint of their defined role. Then there's the British clown Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) whose troubled life apparently is reflected in his memoirs, edited by one Charles Dickens, and Dickens seems to have much to do with the development of the bad clown trope (I must have missed those novels).

Other chapters address many related topics. Chapter 4 discusses irrational fear of clowns. Chapter 5 examines bad clowns in ink, largely comics. I had never heard of comics specializing in bad clowns and evil clown characters. Based on Radford's reporting, I'd say it is an acquired taste. Chapter 6 looks at "bad clowns of the screen" including film but also television (and now one assumes in social media), including The Simpsons. Chapter 7 discusses bad clowns in music--apparently bad clowns show up in contemporary music of the sort older adults like me are blissfully unaware of. Chapter 8 discusses clown porn--discusses, with no examples or illustrations, thankfully.

Chapter 9 covers creepy clowns and killer clowns, including some real killers. Chapter 10 covers activist clowns, clowns who use their humr and techniques for partisan views, which must hearken back to court jesters. Chapter 11 covers dip clowns, persons in clown costume suspended above a water tank; these insult passersby to the point they buy several baseball tosses to dunk the clown. Chapter 12 which is brief, looks at phantom clowns. These seem to be a few furtive individuals lurking in some form of clown costume and just plain phantoms existing in the minds and perceptions of people. Chapter 13 discusses trolls and the future of bad clowns--internet trolling is an interesting connection to make with clowns.

Review:
It's a great concept but I'm not sure it's ready for prime time.  At this price, all the features should work flawlessly and seamlessly.  They just don't.  To begin with, the internet connection is, at best, intermittent and it seems to require password input every few minutes.  The Sound Station is connected (at least some of the time) to our security-enabled wireless network.  It's in the same room as my TiVo and my computer, neither of which has problems with connectivity but the Sound Station loses the connection regularly.

Several of the buttons are unresponsive.  Touch them and absolutely nothing happens.  The alarm button, for example, does nothing when pushed so I haven't been able to test the alarm feature at all.  Some of the other buttons will react at times but not at others.  The "copy" function certainly has a mind of its own; sometimes it will save a file to memory, at other times, it just ignores the command.

In addition, there are several of what I would call design flaws.  For example, there is no ability to save media in folders or to set up playlists.  The Sound Station allows you to sort only alphabetically or chronologically, either ascending or descending, which limits the ability to play an entire album in order or to play a symphony as it was written.  The foregoing is theoretical.  In fact, my machine sorts everything by date no matter which selection I choose.  There's also no way to search or to locate a selection intuitively.  In order to "scroll" through the contents on a flash drive you must swipe your finger from the bottom of the page to the top.  When you have many, many pages, this is not only tedious, it can make you crazy and you still don't have the ability to choose the order of your music or pictures.

I've also found the USB port to be finicky.  It will accept one of my 16GB thumb drives but not another of the same make and capacity.  My computer recognizes both but not Aura.

I hope that these problems get ironed out because there is a lot to like about the Aura Sound Station.  Assuming that it was working as intended, it has a lot of convenient features and I think the sound is quite decent for a system of this kind.  The little remote, while limited in function,  is very responsive and the station is sleek and good-looking.

Review:
The program caused problems on my system from the very start.  I installed it on a barely two month old Toshiba laptop  (Intel Core 2 Duo 2.80 GHz, 6 GB RAM, Vista Home Premium, 64 bit) which up until then, was running like a dream.  Trend Micro first had me uninstall my previous AV software (AVG Free) and Spybot Search and Destroy which I did.  I closed all open applications and ran the installation disk.  But even at that, things did not go smoothly.  After the installation was complete the first thing I tried was to access the UI but clicking on the icon in the system tray elicited no response; right click, left click, it didn't matter, nothing happened.  While I was considering my options, I noticed that the firewall was turned off.  Since I couldn't get into the interface, and trying to turn it on via the control panel was unsuccessful, I re-booted the computer hoping that would make things right.  Nope.  A second re-boot produced the same results.

I'm pretty stubborn and I really wanted to try out the features in this software but one thing convinced me that perhaps it just wasn't for me.  My system, previously so fast and responsive was behaving as if someone had poured molasses into the processor.  It was sluggish in the extreme and even the simple process of opening a browser window took eons.  It was at that point that I decided to uninstall the program.

I don't know if the problems I had with Trend Micro resulted from Vista, as some have suggested (doubtful since many other Vista users have reported success) or whether they're caused by a conflict with some of the other programs I'm running.  I do know that although Trend Micro has worked very well for others, it just does not agree with my system.

I hesitated over the star rating to give this product since I wasn't able to evaluate it fairly.  I would have preferred to omit the rating entirely but since that isn't an option, I'm giving it two stars which I hope reflects both its incompatibility with my computer and the success that others have reported in using the program.

Taylor is a computer genius. She's great with computers, she should be she's on line most of her life. She is asked by a friend to be Loch's guide while he is in New York. Loch quickly realizes Taylor has many male admirers. Even with them being polar opposites, Loch understands why. Taylor is sweet, funny and gorgeous, and she's just the distraction he needs. Between work and the gaming community, she has a fellow gamer with an unhealthy obsession stalking her, whom has also become a stage 5 clinger. Loch finds himself pursuing Taylor. He has never pursued a woman before, but Taylor is different and right now different feels right to him. Loch doesn't want to be chosen as the new King, so he devises a plan to keep himself off the throne. Taylor seems to be falling hard for him. Is Loch having similar feelings, or is it just wishful thinking on her part? It doesn't really matter. Loch is used to getting what he wants...damn the consequences. Review:
If you need a headset while on the computer, and don't care about compatibility with gaming consoles, the Creative Sound Blaster Tactic3D Rage brings some powerful audio clarity to the table, and comes at a generally affordable price point. What keeps it down is how it's built and the lack of comfort. Audio-wise, these are awesome to use when listening to music. It takes me back to the mid-90s when I would come home from school and just lay back, put on some music and put on a huge pair of headphones, hearing every little change in tone as the tracks went on. Things like Skype calls and games fare just as well. It's great that this headset stays true to its word when it comes to the battery life. A full charge will last you a good amount of time, and even a half charge should get you through 7 hours or so of continuous use at normal levels.

The big issue I have with this headset is how uncomfortable it is. I've used several over the ear headsets and headphones over the last year, and none have been this uncomfortable. From how snug the actual pieces that go over your ears are, to how they cause glasses to dig into the sides of your head, I can't stand to wear these things for more than 20 minutes at a time. If you don't wear glasses, or have extremely slim frames, then this shouldn't be an issue. The removable microphone could have been made better too, and bending it to move it out of the way when needed for just a moment can take longer than it should. And you can kiss the foam covering for the mic goodbye too after anything barely taps it. It constantly falls off, causing me to give up on that little thing almost entirely.

There are a lot of other small problems that I can see becoming big ones as time goes on too. A couple of other reviewers, who have owned this headset for a few months, have mentioned parts falling off and the faux leather pads that go over your ears hardening over time. Things like that make the big price drop that the headset gets every couple of weeks seem justified. It just doesn't seem like a quality product, especially when there are better options out there for around the same price. This thing looks cheap in the box, and feels cheap when you're holding it. And yet it manages to have great sound quality!
Score:
3

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
I've never used a gaming headset before, although I've been getting slightly more interested in them after seeing some of the more respectable top fighting game players using them. Granted, there aren't many people who I play with online that also have headsets, and I don't play that many games that are team based or require much communication, but it's always nice to be able to do so in something like say, Borderlands 2. When I was offered a chance to get one of these RIG headsets, I figured now was the time to give it a shot. Given that this is the first one I've used, I can't say that it's the best out there, or worth its price. I -can- say that this sucker is comfortable, clear and makes for an enjoyable gaming experience, letting you hear all the game's audio while talking to your friends. As an added bonus, you can even listen to music on your phone or mp3 player with it with the right jack.

It may seem gimmicky to include a port for your phone, and I can safely assume that most people won't be using this feature. However, it's still nice to have in case you're waiting for an important call, or have a job position where people are calling you frequently. Both the mic that flips out of the headset, and the one that hangs from the cord are great and worked without any problems.

If I had something to compare this to, I'd give a more detailed review. Since it's my first item like this, it'll serve as the standard if I get another one. I haven't used it a whole lot for games since I don't play many multiplayer ones, given my work schedule, but for anyone who's looking for a quality headset that isn't going to break the bank, this would be an optimal choice.

Review:
8th studio album by power/neoclassical metal band "Rhapsody of fire"; `The frozen tears of angels' was my introduction to the music of the band (although I have followed the side careers Luca Turilli and Fabio Lione) which is indeed a very memorable album.

What I found largely appealing on `The frozen tears of angels' is the fact that no instrument is obscured by any other; throughout `The frozen tears of angels', all five musicians take the opportunity to shine and their respective performances are equally important for the sound of the album.

It has to be said however that the tempo plays in the two extremes for the biggest part of the album; it goes either incredibly fast or very slow while this switching often occurs halfway through the song. Still all instruments masterfully adapt to these variations; in fact Turilli throws in some of the fastest power metal riffs one has heard in a long time; Alex Staropoli's keyboards are more than ambitious contributing both rhythm and melodic sections.
Lione does a masterful job on the vocals, as always, still one might find it hard to follow the lyrics when sung choir-like at full speed (yet this also stands as a complement for the band's technical ability). Never forgetting Alex Holzwart who wages wars behind his drum set, while it often seems as his playing is actually leading the band through the song.

Favourite songs include the dramatic `Sea of fate', the orchestral/neoclassical `Crystal Moonlight' and the extra melodic `Raging Starfire'.

Furthermore placing Sasha Paeth on the mixing board was a clever move; having worked with multi-track project such as `Avantasia', Paeth in away stands as a guarantee that all instruments and voices will come clearly through the mix, displayed at similar volume.

Any way you look at it, `The frozen tears of angels' is a heavy hitting power metal album; some of the fastest and most aggressive instrumentations are to be found on this release while also retaining the highest standards in terms of musicianship and production.

"Metal Hammer" Greek magazine (issue 305) marks this album with 7/10 commenting: "`Rhapsody of fire' are now focusing on speed and aggression which makes for a more guitar oriented sound."
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
"Heavenly ecstasy" is the brand new 5th studio album by Norwegian progressive/power metal band "Pagan's mind". Four years past their previous studio effort "God's equation" the line up of singer Nils K. Rue, guitarist Jorn Viggo Lofstad, bassist Steinar Krokmo, drummer Stian Kristoffersen and keyboardist Ronny Tegner re-emerge under a somewhat new musical approach.

On "Heavenly ecstasy" the group takes a considerable musical turn towards melodic metal, suppressing the progressive element on most songs on the album. You can always expect instrumental twists and turns but for the biggest part the musical structures have been simplified making "Heavenly ecstasy" a catchier and perhaps more direct album. Possibly the change in artistic direction could be partly attributed to the change in record label; having left "LMP", the group signed with the renowned "SPV" which might also explain why it took this long for "...Ecstasy" to be released.

It has to be addressed that the band does retain its heaviness as the production qualities are similar to previous "Pagan's mind" albums. Having said that, on some songs the main passages come out so clean that, believe it or not, deliver an AOR-essence; such tunes are "Intermission", "Follow your way", "Walk away in silence" and "Live your life like a dream".

Indeed "Heavenly..." is probably the catchiest "Pagan's Mind" album to date without completely disregarding their progressive nature. Overall "Heavenly Ecstacy" should appeal to long-term admirers of the band while possibly attracting fans of related bands such as "Jorn" and "Firewind".

Review:
This is a fine little mug. The selling point for me was the carabiner-style handle. Very glad I did, as it works as a snap hanger on a pack, cool storage options, or even just a fiddle object (which i employ a lot). The beverage stays at temperature for a surprising long time, and that functionality hasn't faded in almost a year.
The lid employs the form factor of an older thermos-style spigot, yet opens by the flip of a thumb. It clicks down to lid for staying open, or a finger will release and reseal it. This helps round out the design making it a functional and sensible product. Tricky to clean though, so i soak it first. I dropped it in the vehicle with good results. It will stay sealed from about a two foot drop to a seat, or  continued three foot total drop to floor. For extra drop detail, a drop and bounce on a trail has done quite well bouncing over down basic rocks. I wouldn't throw it though, but I'd expect the same.
Finally, when drinking, there is little to no splash through during rough or jarring motion. I do share the occasional drip on my nose, because of the rubber 'cork' in the seal, normally only on full cups and very sleepy!
I totally recommend this product to anyone that asks about it.

Review:
I thought I was a well read Christian, but I had never even heard of this book. A dear friend recommended it, saying it had helped her in her spiritual growth and progress.
I was not able to find this book anywhere  in the St. Louis area libraries, so I purchased this copy.
About the book  - I found it to be an incredibly helpful resource in gaining a deeper  understanding of our spiritual mission on this earth. And it is a very  interesting book.
The author really lays her heart on the line - and  tells in wonderfully frank language how hard it is to truly live the  spiritual axiom - "Not my will - but thine be done."
And it  also sums up Maya Angelou's maxim that "we are all more alike than we  are different."
"Stepping Heavenward" was so close to my  own life that I felt compelled to keep reading it and find out how  everything turned out! I read the book in two days, snatching every spare  moment I could to race back to the book and see what happened next!
I  loved it. I'd highly recommend this book to anyone and everyone. In fact,  I'm buying more copies for Christmas presents and I've handed it off to a  school teacher hoping that she'll consider putting it on the required  reading list.
If you only buy three Christian books this year - I'd  recommend this book, Stepping Heavenward, along with "What's so  Amazing About Grace" and "Science and Health with Key to the  Scriptures."
Three powerful books. Along with the Bible, of course,  but EVERYONE has a Bible.  :-)
If you order "Stepping  Heavenward" you won't be disappointed. And if you are, donate it to  the local library. This book will be the answer to many people's prayers.

My two largest knives and various small utensils reside on it, and it holds up everything just fine.  It's a blessing not to have to search through a full drawer to find those small utensils now.

Review:
The Conventions and Craft: Grade 1 Teachers Kit by Scholastic is a good structured plan for Grammer, Sentence Structure, and Word Study for First Graders. The set comes with six paperback book, one collection of magazine articles for kids to read, and a teachers guide. The guide has a year long lesson plan based around a ten month school enrollment period and is broken down into five main categories with multiple subcategories of lessons within those five main lessons. Within each sublesson, the teaching material is broken down into five days of instruction. Day one focuses on studying the mentor text (the books listed), day two is modeling the target understanding, day three is analyzing the student's writings, day four is inviting application, and day five focuses on review of the subject matter. There are many examples on how to introduce the works to the kids, how to encourage the kids to talk about what they learned and how it applies to what they read, and how to utilize what they learned in writing of their own. The subject matter is listed down below:

Getting Started
1.  Say the Message, Write the Message
2.  Visualize and Draw before Writing
3.  Spell Phonetically
4.  Include All the Words in a Message
5.  Watch Word Spacing
6.  Use the Entire Page

Build Strong Sentences
1. Write Complete Sentences
2.  Expand Short Sentences
3.  Create Compound Sentences
4.  Capture Attention with Exclamatory Sentences
5.  Vary Sentence Beginnings
6.  Vary Sentence Lengths
7.  Craft Strong Leads
8.  Craft Strong Conclusions.

Power Up Grammar and Word Knowledge
1.  Use Adjectives to Add Details
2.  Create Action with Powerful Verbs
3.  Convey Shades of Meaning
4.  Create Voice with Onomatopoeia
5.  Show Order with Temporal Words
6.  Use Comparatives
7.  Build Connections with Prepositions
8.  Form Plural Nowns
9.  Show Ownership with Possessive Pronouns
10.  Maintain Subject Verb Agreement
11.  Control Verb Tenses
12.  Understand Personal Pronouns
13.  Follow Pronoun Order
14.  Include Demonstratives
15.  Understand Compound Words and Words with Affixes
16.  Identify Root Words and Endings

Master Punctuation and Capitalization
1.  Use Question Marks in Interrogative Sentences
2.  Capitalize Proper Nouns
3.  Use Commas in a Series
4.  Use Apostrophes to Create Possessive Nouns

Edit Like an Expert
1.  Use Layout and Spacing in Interesting Ways
2.  Reread for Each Editing Point
3.  Use Syllabication for Spelling
4.  Take Advantage of Resources

This book also includes and appendix that feature support pages for the learning material such as a page listing all of the conjunctions (for and nor but or yet so), commonly confused words (are our hour, by bye, buy, etc), assessment tools such as editing checklists and self assessments, as well as record keeping tools for teachers on how well the students are progressing. For those who are looking for a teaching guide that includes printable worksheets or a variety of activities to teach the material, this set does not come with those materials. The model for learning with this set revolves a lot around having the students working together to identify the issues with the sample writings, and with teachers reviewing the students free writing. Overall, I found this set to be good for both homeschooling and classroom teaching environments, but found the material to be a bit too redundant in teaching style and a bit too structured. With books this short in length and limited to the six books and fourteen 1-2 page magazine articles, I would imagine the kids would get bored quickly unless you supplement with other reading and teaching materials. Overall, this is a good basis for teaching grammar, sentence structure, and writing, but I would definitely supplement with other resources as well to keep things interesting.
Score:
4

</EXAMPLES>

Review:
This is the first book I've read by J.M. LaRocca, and I was honored to receive a complimentary copy from the author!

Sadie has to be one of my favorite heroines. I liked that she didn't make excuses for why things happened the way they did in her life. She believed that everything in life happens for a reason, and those words proved to be true when she crossed paths with Landon. But things didn't start out as smoothly as one would hope. It took a lot of time and patience on Sadie's part before Landon finally showed a side of him that no one had seen before.

While signing up for courses at a new school, Sadie befriends Lisa, who works at a local farm with her boyfriend. Lisa offers to help her get a job on the farm, but little did she know she'd be working beside bad boy Landon, who had a bit of a reputation for hooking up with girls and lived life in the fast lane. It's clear that Sadie is attracted to him, but seeing how her last relationship ended, she isn't looking for anything serious. Landon can be a dick at times, but after peeling back his layers and allowing himself to open up to her, they develop a friendship that quickly turn into more than either of them expected.

I don't want to go into too much detail because I want everyone to enjoy this book as much as I did, but the endOMG...gut-wrenching doesn't even begin to describe what that ending did to me. I really enjoyed reading Drifting into Darkness, and even cried like a little baby (I'm not ashamed to admit that!). Sadie and Landon's story is one that will stick with me for a very long time and I highly recommend it!
Score:
5

Review:
The 6540 Wheel Master Pro is worth its name. I base this review upon ease-of-use, comfort (even for a shorter person), and storage.

The Wheel Master is extremely easy to set-up and use, straight out of the box. Once the handle is snapped into place, the unit is ready to use. It comes with a wrist-strap and a trigger-like handle that is designed with some good ergonomics. When your hand is holding the trigger handle, the brake is easy to press without losing grip of the handle, as is the reset button. It glides great and stops on a dime, making accurate measurements easy. Collapsing the unit from its 38" to 19" for carrying and storage is performed by pressing a button towards the base of the handle. Where the handle folds is a second, built-in handle for carrying the unit once it is collapsed. It is very light-weight (around 4 lbs.), but still feels sturdy.

The unit comes with a kick-stand. The utility of the stand depends on your usage. For measuring straight distances, the kick-stand may not be necessary, but if you have incremental measurements where you may need to stop and mark something every X feet or so, the kick-stand may be useful for you.

The box I received also has a convenient carrying case for carrying around the unit or storing in between use. Just collapse the handle and insert the entire unit. It fits in with minimal manipulations. However, when the unit is folded down, as mentioned, it has a carrying handle, so the case is not necessary, but is a nice bonus feature for storage or if the wheel gets dirty (you can toss it in the case and then carry it without worrying about dirt getting on your clothes). The case appears to be machine washable, but I haven't actually tried it yet. It is made out of heavy-duty weaved nylon and has two straps, so that the unit can be worn and carried like a back-pack, if desired.

Overall, the measuring wheel works great. The only drawback is that the units of measure are in feet and inches, with no metric option. If you need a metric measurer, you will either need to convert it or buy a different one.
Score:
5

</EXAMPLES>
